loans.name: Unidas Venceremos 1 Group

texts.en:
This Bank of Hope group is requesting their 7th loan for their micro business. They have shown great responsibility paying their previous loans so Esperanza has approved the amounts they have requested. They think this new loan will help them continue with the stability they've had in their activities ever since they've been Esperanza clients.

Nuris D. is the group coordinator and she sells clothing and shoes. She will use this loan to purchase clothes and shoes her customers have already requested. She's made this her sales method to ensure she doesn't buy more merchandise than necessary or more than she is certain she will sell.

Nuris hopes to improve her economic condition and give her teenage children better opportunities than the ones she had. Her main goal is to take 50,000 pesos in an upcoming loan to set up a store (her current loan is for 15,000 pesos). Please help us continue support these entrepreneurs through this Kiva loan. Thank you!

loans.use: Purchase clothes and shoes for resale

loans.name: Hilda

texts.en:
Hilda M. C. is 28 years old and lives with her common-law husband and their two young children. She sells shoes 6 days a week in the main market of Urubamba, a town in the Sacred Valley, about an hour outside of the city of Cusco. She has been in this business for the past 6 years.

Hilda is a member of the Sayhua 2 Village Bank, an experienced group that has been taking out loans from Asociación Arariwa for years. She is requesting a loan of 3,500 nuevos soles to buy a variety of different shoes for men, women, and children. She has pledged to repay her Kiva loan in full and on time. Her goals for the future are to expand her business and save up enough money to buy her own house.

loans.use: Buy shoes for men, women, and children

loans.name: Cirilo Alejandro

texts.es: El señor Cirilo Alejandro C. tiene la edad de 34 años, habita en el barrio San Caralampio ubicado en la concepción  - Masaya , el es soltero habita con sus padres , los planes hacia un futuro es poder construir una casa ya que la que tiene actualmente es de madera con plástico y en las madrugadas hace mucho fríos , él desde hace cinco años trabaja como agricultor , con la ayuda de sus papá , los planes hacia un futuro para sus cultivos es poder diversificarlo , el financiamiento lo quiere para la comprar de fertilizantes e insumos para que la cosecha se en buenas condiciones y poder vender a buen precio en el mercado.
texts.en:
Cirilo Alejandro C., 34, lives in the San Caralampio neighborhood located in La Concepción, Masaya. He is single and lives with his parents. His plans for the future are to be able to build a house. The one he has now is made of wood and plastic. In the morning it is very cold. Since he was five years old, with the help of his parents, he has worked as a farmer. The future plans for his crops are to diversify them. He wants the loan to be able to buy fertilizer and supplies. Then his harvest will be in good condition, and he will be able to sell it for a good price at the market.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for his farm

loans.name: Mujeres Con Proposito Group

texts.en:
Yesenia N. M. is a bank coordinator for the bank of Mujeres con Propositos. She is 33 years old and lives with her 36-year-old husband. They have three children: 12, 8 and 6 years old. Fifteen women from the bank are now looking for their second loan.

Yesenia has a business selling candy to students at a school in her neighborhood. The school has about 120 students and she visits it twice per day. Before her first loan she had sales of about 500 pesos per month, but after receiving a loan from Esperanza, her sales have increased to over 2000 pesos per month. With a new loan, she hopes to increase her business even more.

Yesenia is herself a student. She has been studying at a university in the evenings for the past four years to become a teacher. She will finish her education in a year and will be able to work as a teacher then. She wants to continue selling candy, but hopes it will be possible for her to have her own colmado (small shop) one day.

In her spare time Yesenia likes to read and mentioned Juan Bosch as her favorite author. She hopes that she will be able to help her children so that they too will have an opportunity to study at the university.

On behalf of Yesenia N. M., Mujeres con Propositos, and all of us here at Esperanza International: thank you for your support!

loans.use: buy more supplies to sell in business

loans.name: Evarista

texts.en:
Evarista M. A. is 57 years old and lives with her common-law husband; they have seven children. Evarista sells clothing in Urubamba’s main market, a business she has been in for quite some time now. She works all day, six days per week. She is requesting a loan of 2000 nuevos soles to buy a variety of clothing for men, women, and children.

Evarista is a member of the Sayhua 2 Village Bank, an experienced group that has been taking out loans from Asociación Arariwa for years. Two of her adult daughters are also members of the Sayhua 2 Village Bank, though each has her own business and works independently. Evarista has pledged to repay her Kiva loan in full and on time. Her goal for the future is to open up more branches of her business.

loans.use: Buy clothing for men, women, and children

loans.name: Unidas Venceremos 3 Group

texts.en:
The women from group 3 of the Unidos Venceremos Bank of Hope are requesting their 7th loan through Esperanza International. They live in Samana, a peninsuL. located in northeast Dominican Republic. Samana is relatively an isolated and unexploited area of the country. Hence employment opportunities are scarce. The group members have worked very hard to establish their business through their previous micro loans and want to increase their sales volumes by buying new supplies with this loan. 

Maribel A. is the group coordinator. She runs a small grocery store where she sells basic food supplies for daily cooking. She will use this loan to purchase rice, sugar and malted drinks, which are the items she sells the most. She's been sick recently for an extended period of time, which has led to a decrease in her sales. She hopes to recover soon and attend to her business without having to ask for help (she still doesn't make enough profits to hire staff). She also wants to make some improvements in the space where her store is located. She will work hard to continue paying her loans successfully, as she has done so far.

Please help us support these entrepreneurs through this Kiva loan. Thank you!

loans.use: to purchase rice, sugar and malted drinks

loans.name: German

texts.en:
German is a member of the Sayhua 2 Village Bank, an experienced group that has been taking loans from Asociacion Arariwa for many years. He has been a member of the group for the past three years. He is 64 years old and is married with seven children, all of whom are now adults. German sells basic grocery items like rice, sugar, oil and flour at a stall in the market in Urubamba as well as from a store in his home. On most days, he tends one location while his wife tends the other. The couple works seven days a week. 

German is requesting a loan of 3,000 soles (US $950) to buy more grocery items. He doesn’t know specifically what products he will buy with the loan, since he has yet to do a thorough inventory of his stock. He has pledged to repay his Kiva loan in full and on time. 

German is considering changing his business some time in the future, in hopes of finding a more profitable activity, but he hasn’t made any decisions yet, and doesn’t know what kind of business he might like to open. 

German is pictured above with his wife.

loans.use: Buy basic grocery items to restock store

loans.name: Nuevo Progreso 4 Group

texts.en:
The members of the Nuevo Progreso (New Progress) Bank of Hope are requesting their 6th loan through Esperanza International. They've reached a level of stability in their sales and have also built a faithful clientele that keeps their businesses sustained.

Pura C., the group representative, sells clothes. She will use this loan to buy a "paca", which is a bundle of clothing that contains a number of items. The paca can have used or new clothes. Sometimes it has only one type of clothes (for example, clothes meant for children) and sometimes mixed. Pura has two children, aged 8 and 11, and she hopes to keep providing for them as she has always done. She dreams of setting up her own store, where she can sell clothing for women, men and children.

Please help us to continue supporting these entrepreneurs. Thank you!

loans.use: purchasing one bundle of clothes to sell

loans.name: Unidas Venceremos 4 Group

texts.en:
The members of Group 4 from the Unidas Venceremos Bank of Hope have been clients of Esperanza International for the last three years. They have paid their previous loans on time and have remained together as a group all this time. They think being together in a Bank of Hope has helped them be closer as neighbors and to contribute to their community. 

Ruth J. is the group coordinator, which means she is responsible for watching out for the well being of the rest of the group members, collecting payments, and being in permanent communication with their loan officer Nelly. She sells clothing and has built a large, faithful clientele. With this loan, she plans to add shoes to her sales, in order to offer this option to her clients who have asked that she start selling shoes. 

Ruth's health is not very strong. She gets sick rather easily and this keeps her away from her clients for extended periods of time. She hopes that during the time she is healthy, she can sell enough to attend her sickness with proper medical attention. Her dream is to travel to the United States someday as a tourist.
 
Please help us support the hopes and dreams of these entrepreneurs. Thank you!

loans.use: To buy shoes to add to her clothing sales.

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
Martha tiene una tienda donde vende refrescos, pan, dulces, abarrotes y otros; es  la única fuente de ingresos que tiene ya que todos sus hijos son independientes.
Vive en la zona de de llojeta de la Ciudad de La Paz, en casa propia.
El crédito será destinado para capital de trabajo (compra de aceite, refrescos, azucar, fideo, arroz, dulces y galletas) y tener productos en su tienda.
Es la séptima vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, su historial la califica como cliente bueno en el pago de sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Martha owns a shop where she sells soft drinks, bread, snacks and other groceries. It's her only source of income now that her children are independent. She lives in her own house in the Ilojeta neighborhood of La Paz. The loan will be used for working capital (to buy cooking oil, soft drinks, sugar, pasta, rice, candy and snacks) and for products to resell in her shop. This is her seventh Impro loan and her track record for repaying past loans qualifies her as a good customer.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products for resale.

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.es:
Reynaldo trabaja en una empresa de entrega de cartas, encomiendas, etc.,, es soltero e independiente y el único que genera ingresos para su subsistencia.
Vive en la zona de Villa Salomé de la Ciudad de La Paz, en casa de sus padres.
El crédito será destinado para tomar una pieza en calidad de anticrético ( es una forma legal de alquilar una habitación,departamento o casa, mediante un pago total anticipado por un periodo especifico de un año o dos,al cabo del cual el inqui,inquilino se compromete a desalojar la habitación y el dueño de casa a devolver el dinero original) y poder independizarse.
Es la segunda vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, su historial lo califica como cliente bueno en el pago de sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Reynaldo works for a package delivery company. He's single and independent and only has to make enough to pay his own way. He lives in his parents' house in the Villa Salome neighborhood of La Paz. The loan will be used to get a room by paying what's called a "calidad de anticretico" (a legal term in Bolivia for a payment to a lessor for a room, apartment or house whereby the renter pays the total expected amount for a fixed period of a year or two, at the end of which the renter promises to leave the room and the landlord to return the original money) and become independent. This is his second Impro loan and his track record for repaying the past loan qualifies him as a good client.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Deposit on leased room.

loans.name: Nuevo Progreso 6 Group

texts.en:
The Nuevo Progreso Bank of Hope has been a part of Esperanza International for three years. This group within the bank is requesting their sixth loan. Many of this group's members sell clothing and accessories. They've been able to develop a faithful clientele who purchase enough to enable the group members to pay their loans and make some profits.

Reina P. is the group coordinator and she runs a small grocery store. She will use this loan to buy three items with a large demand: rice, beans, and sugar. Rice and beans are essential to the Dominican diet because they are the main ingredients of the typical Dominican lunch. Sugar also plays an important part in the Dominican diet as it is used to make several sweets (especially with coconut, which is very abundant in the Samana Peninsula) and to sweeten coffee, which Dominicans drink especially strong. Reina wants to see her grocery store become a "super colmado," complete with sitting area, cold cuts area, and everything a customer could possibly imagine.

Please help us support these strong-willed entrepreneurs through this micro loan. Thank you!

loans.use: To purchase rice, beans, and sugar for grocery sales.

loans.name: Nuevo Progreso 3 Group

texts.en:
The members of Group 3 from the Nuevo Progreso Bank of Hope are requesting their sixth loan with Esperanza International. This group formed in 2006. The businesses in this group are extremely varied: some sell clothes and accessories, some sell fried pastries, and Rodolfo, the only male member, is a fisherman.

Robertina T. is the group representative and her business is making and selling juices. Her specialty is orange juice, which is why she will use this loan to buy oranges to make her very refreshing juice. She is also going to purchase foam cups so her customers can get their juice "to go." When she has some spare time, Robertina likes to relax by watching TV. She has a 13 year old son, which is an advantage for her business because she doesn't need to be with him all the time. She would like to have a larger space for her business so she can set up a cafeteria, and maybe make some sandwiches to sell with her orange juice at breakfast time!

Please help us support Robertina and her group through this Kiva microloan. Thank you!

loans.use: To buy sugar, oranges, and foam cups for juices.

loans.name: Las Amigas Unidas 1 Group

texts.en:
The members of Group 1 of the Amigos Unidos (United Friends) Bank of Hope have already been clients of Esperanza International for a year. They have experienced success in their businesses and most of them are expanding the activities with which they first started. The group members have businesses in prepared food sales, breakfast sales, and water distribution.

Serge D. is the group representative and he owns a souvenir shop in San Pedro de Macoris. His souvenir shop mostly caters to tourists. He sells crafts made of materials like clay, thatch, and wood. With this loan, he will purchase some paintings (Haitian art has an especially high demand in souvenir shops in Dominican Republic), along with some beach apparel like towels, bathing suits, and sunscreen. He would like to see his shop become a reference for souvenir shops in San Pedro de Macoris, and to be a better Christian each day.

Please help us support these entrepreneurs through this Kiva loan. Thank you!

loans.use: To purchase beach apparel and paintings to expand his souvenir shop.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George A. is 38 years old. He is married with six children, who are are all currently in school. He is a commercial truck driver and his wife is a baker who sells her product through hawking. George is very popular in his area because of his hard work and his dedication to work. He has been driving a big truck for a very long time now and taking care of the family. He is hired by customers who need to get their goods to various destinations and he charges them a reasonable rate.

His vehicle has developed a fault that makes it very difficult to earn a living. He requests a loan to buy car parts to maintain his car. Notwithstanding that, he also wants to get a bigger truck. He believes this would help him achieve his dream. With the loan he wants to change the engine, his diesel tank, and weld other parts that are wearing out. He will be grateful for your assistance, he said.

George belongs to a group called Awake. He hopes to receive GH¢1000 to make progress in his business by restocking his inventory. This would enable him to save more to support his wife in taking care of the children's educational needs.

loans.use: To maintain his truck van and purchase a new car.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is sixty years old. She is divorced due to a misunderstanding that ensued between her and her husband, and she has remained a single parent ever since. Mary is a mother of three children, all of whom are adults and living independently. Currently, she lives with some of her grandchildren in an old family house in a fishing community called Elmina, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Mary runs a provision store. She procures products such as sugar, tins of milk, milo, bread, etc. from Cape Coast, the regional capital. She has been in this business since her youthful days. Mary also owns a vegetable milling machine in her community, apart from the provision shop. She wants a loan to procure more goods.

loans.use: To procure provisions

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort B. is a 43 year old trader. She is married with five children - three are in the community school, while the rest are working. She lives in her husband's family house. Her husband is a teacher at the community school. She believes in hard work and that dedication is the primary antidote to minimizing poverty and for that matter, she is very serious about her business. She trades in cereals like maize. She started the business ten years ago and has a strong customer base that she supplies with food stuffs. She takes direct deliveries to the farmers at Tachiman in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana and this has helped her do away with middlemen. The business has enabled Comfort to provide for her family. She wants to use the loan to buy a larger supply of maize to serve her customers throughout the season, especially in the face of increasing prices due to the current food crisis in the country. She believes that with a loan of GH¢1000 she can buy more bags of maize grains, thereby making her business progress by restocking its inventory. This would enable her to save more to support her husband who is taking care of the children's educational needs. Comfort belongs to a group called ‘Gina Pin Tin’ which means 'stand firm'.

loans.use: To buy a larger supply of maize.

loans.name: Amigos Unidos 2 Group

texts.en: The members of Group 2 from the Amigos Unidos Bank of Hope have successfully paid off two loans they've had with Esperanza International and are now requesting a third. Many of them started their businesses with the first loan they had, and the loans have helped them establish themselves as micro entrepreneurs in their area. Their activities range from running cafeterias and small grocery stores, to candy making. Louis K. is the group coordinator and he sells prepaid phone cards. Mobile communications are relatively affordable in the Dominican Republic, and a lot of people own prepaid phones. Phone cards range in price from 50 to 500 pesos (between $1.50 and $12 approximately), and for some people, their mobile phones are their only source of communication (most people in rural areas and urban outskirts cannot afford a landline). However, this is a business which is best served as a street vendor, and Louis would like to move to another business activity soon. His life goal is to own his own home. Please help us support these entrepreneurs with this Kiva loan. Thank you!

loans.use: To purchase prepaid phone cards and other goods for resale.

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
Christiana N. is 41 years old. She is married with three children, all of whom are still in school. Some are in the senior high school, while others are still in the junior high school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Elmina in the Central Region of Ghana. Elmina is not only a fishing community but also one of the tourist attractions in the region.

Christiana works in order to support her husband financially. She is a hair dresser by profession. She owns a shop in her community where many women come to have their hair fixed. Christiana says she has a number of clients due to her skill, experience and good customer relations. She has been in business for over 25 years and has trained about 50 professionals. Currently, she is training four apprentices. She wants a loan to procure goods such as shampoo, lotion, artificial hair, etc. to expand her services and product offerings.

loans.use: To buy shampoo, cream, artificial hair, etc

loans.name: Kate May Carolina

texts.es:
La microempresaria Kate May Carolina N. Martínez tiene 60 años de edad, es casada con 3 hijos todos mayores de edad y con 6 nietos los que conviven con ella y su marido. Doña Kate se dedica al negocio de venta de ropas y calzados desde hace mas de 15 años, su negocio esta ubicado en el centro comercial Bluefields ubicado en una zona de comercio de esta localidad.

Con este negocio doña Kate ha podido sacar adelante a su familia a quienes les ha brindado educación, alimentación y protección como madre de familia. Este es el segundo crédito con Kiva, el primero fue cancelado en tiempo y forma. Hay que señalar que esta microempresaria ha sido cliente de ADEPHCA desde hace más de 10 años y siempre ha pagado sus cuotas a tiempo.

En esta ocasión  ella esta solicitando se le financie para comprar:

10 Unidades de Trajes de mujer los cuales compra a US 17 cada traje, 12 unidades de Short azulón los cuales compra a US 10 cada short, 12 unidades de  pantalón jeans los cuales compra a US 10 cada pantalón, 12 unidades de trajes de baño los cuales compra a US 8 cada traje de baño y  24 unidades de camisetas los cuales compra a US 6 cada camiseta.
texts.en:
The micro-entrepeneur, Kate May Carolina N. M., is 60 years old. She is married and has 3 children, all grown, and 6 grandchildren, all of whom live with her and her husband. Dona Kate has earned a living selling clothing and footwear for more than 15 years. Her business is located in a commercial district of the city of Bluefields.

The business has given Dona Kate the means to pull her family up and provide them with schooling and other needs. This is her second Kiva loan. The first was repaid on time and in accordance with the loan terms. It should be noted that this micro-entrepeneur has been an ADEPHCA client for more than 10 years and has always paid her loans on time.

Now she's applying for a loan to buy:

10 women's suits, each of which costs US$17; 12 pairs of blue shorts, each of which costs US$10; 12 pairs of jeans, each of which costs US$10; 12 bathing suits, each of which costs US$8; and 24 t-shirts, each of which costs US$6.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing for resale.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica M. is 46 years old. She is married with five children, all of whom are still in school (ranging from primary to senior high school). She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Elmina in the Central Region of Ghana. Elmina is not only a fishing community but also one of the region's tourist attractions.

Veronica works as a trader to support her husband financially and to provide for her family. She sells ice cream in the local market square and also treks to other towns. Veronica also runs a mother care crèche in her community. She has been in business for seven years and wants a loan to procure ice cream in bulk. Her dream is to give her children the best possible education.

loans.use: To procure ice cream in bulk for resale.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah E. is 45 years old and is married. She is the mother of four children, two of whom are in school and the others are working. She lives in Eguase in the central region of Ghana. Her husband is a crop farmer and has been very supportive of her. Life, she says, has not been as easy for her as she had expected, but she hopes and trusts in God that her dream of becoming well to do will come to pass. Hannah is very hardworking and dedicated to the upbringing of her children. She sells sweet potatoes and lemons, and it is from the proceeds of her business that she has managed to support her family. Hannah has mounted a stand by the major road side of Cape Coast where she sells her products. She takes delivery of stock from the surrounding farming communities and has been in business for twenty years now. She needs a loan to buy more sweet potatoes and lemons so that she can meet the demand from her customers. She would be grateful for your assistance. She hopes to receive GHS800, which would help her grow her business by restocking its inventory. This would enable her to save more money so she can help her husband take care of their children's educational needs. Hannah belongs to a group called ‘Gina Pin Tin’ which means 'stand firm'.

loans.use: To buy bunches of potatoes and lemons.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary D. is 52 years old. She is married with four children, all of whom have completed school. Some are working while others are learning trades. She lives with some of her children and husband in a family house in a fishing community called Elmina, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Mary is a trader. She sells vegetables such as peppers, tomatoes, onions, etc. on a table top in the market square. She procures the vegetables from farmers in nearby small communities at effective prices. She says she supplies the greatest percentage of the vegetables to food vendors. Mary has been in this business for three years. She wants a loan to procure more goods.

loans.use: Procure vegetables.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah K. is 46 years old. She is married with four kids. Two are schooling while the others work. She lives with her family at Eguase, in the central region of Ghana.

For the past ten years, Sarah has baked bread and pastries to take care of her household. She bakes sugar bread, wheat bread, cakes, meat pies, etc. and retails them to her customers. She books their order in advance, before they come, so it will be ready. She also retails to individuals for their morning breakfasts. And she sometimes sells by hawking herself. She says the price of commodities are increasing which makes it difficult to buy raw materials from the market. The daily demand for bread is high. She says she bakes at most 250 loaves a day. Sarah needs the loan to buy more bags of flour, sugar, margarine, milk and firewood etc. Her husband is a mason.

She says your assistance would be much welcome. Sarah belongs to a group called ‘Gina Pin Tin’ which means Stand Firm. She also hope to receive GH¢800 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: Buy baking materials.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther Q. is 46 years old. She is married with three children, all of whom are currently in school. One is in senior high school while others are in the junior high school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Elmina, near Cape Coast, in the Central Region of Ghana.

She works to support her husband financially. Esther is a trader. She deals in the palm oil production business. She procures palm nuts from nearby communities where palm fruits are readily available and cost effective. She says she supplies the greater percentage of the oil she produces to retailers who come from the big cities. She also sells to food vendors. Esther has been in the palm oil production business for five years. She wants a loan to procure palm nuts in bulk.

loans.use: Procure palm nuts.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary E.'s goal is to work hard and be productive. Through dedication and commitment she is living up to that. She sells cooked eggs with pepper and assorted biscuits by a road in Cape Coast, Ghana called Moore Junction.

Mary says she enjoys selling them and has done so for 10 years and is now in taking care of the home. Mary E. is 31 years old, married and the mother of a child who is currently in school.

She arranges the eggs on a tray and mostly sells to travelers. Mary treks to the poultry farmers in Ashanti and the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana to purchase the eggs. She does not have sufficient capital to buy more. She is requesting a loan to realize her dream of taking care of the family.

With the loan she wants to buy more from farmers to avoid frequent traveling which she believes is retarding her sales. Mary will be grateful for your loan support. Mary belongs to a group called ‘Gina Pin Tin’ which means Stand Firm.

loans.use: Buy eggs to sell.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia T. is 46 years old. She is married with four children, two of whom are currently in school. One is in senior high school while the other is in junior high school. Two are working at the moment. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Elmina, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Cecilia works to support her husband financially. She is a trader and also runs a cold store. She procures fresh fish and meat from nearby big cold stores to stock her shop. Cecilia’s shop is located at the market square. She says she supplies the greatest percentage of her goods to food vendors. She also sells to retailers and other consumers. Cecilia has been in business for five years. She wants a loan to procure goods in bulk.

loans.use: Procure food in bulk.

loans.name: La Union De Los Vecinos 2 Group

texts.en:
The members of the La Union de los Vecinos 2 (The Neighbors' Union) Bank of Hope are starting their entrepreneurship endeavor with Esperanza International with this first loan. They hope this micro loan will help them inject some capital in their businesses to make them more stable, or to expand into complimentary activities. 

Miriam R. is the group representative. She is a single mom with a seven year old child. As her primary activity she sells clothing, but she also runs a small cafeteria in her home. Her loan will be used equally in both her businesses; she plans to buy some clothing items that her customers have specially requested, and also expand her cafeteria. 
Miriam finds one of her biggest challenges is to keep her savings in storage and not spend them frivolously. She knows that savings are important in order to become financially independent, which is her ultimate goal. 
Please help us support this new group of entrepreneurs. Thank you!

loans.use: To purchase clothing and food to sell.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace K. is 54 years old, and she is divorced and a mother of four children. She has been married for almost thirty years now. She has been supporting herself and her children too. Currently two of her children are in school, while the rest are fully independent. She has a mini shop where she sells items like bags of rice, sugar, flour etc. She also bakes bread to supply the area where she lives. Others also come to her house to buy them.

With the slow pace of the business, she has opened a grocery shop just in front of her house and sells items like milk, sugar, tinned tomatoes, flour etc; but, the unfortunate thing is that she has insufficient working capital to run the business. With the loan, she wants to inject more working capital into the business to scale up business progress. She believes the loan will enable her to purchase good quality and a large quantity to upgrade her inventory. She says she would be grateful for that assistance. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Yesu Abusua Kuo’ which means 'God’s family'. She also hopes to receive GH¢1000 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase clothing materials, lace materials, slippers, sugar, flour and tinned tomatoes.

loans.name: Yeadze

texts.en: Yeadze M. is 28 years old. She is married with one child, who is currently in the basic school. She lives with her child and husband in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Elmina, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana. Yeadze works as a trader to support her husband financially. She trades in jewelry, such as ear rings, necklaces, wrist watches, etc., which she procures from Cape Coast, the regional capital. She hawks to sell her goods in her community. Yeadze also treks to other markets to sell the jewelry on their respective market days. She has been in business for three years and wants a loan to procure varieties of jewels in bulk. She is hoping with the proceeds of her business she will be able to help her husband build their own store so that they can improve their family’s life.

loans.use: To procure jewelry for resale.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes O. is fifty three years old and is married with three children. One child is currently in senior high school, one is in junior high and one is in primary school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Elmina, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Agnes works to support her husband financially. She owns a lavatory for public patronage. Customers, mostly passers by and travelers, check in to wash down and attend to natures call. She charges a fee (a token) to the customers for using the place. Agnes says she needs a loan to expand and maintain the facility. She has been running this business for six years.

She is hopeful to help her husband build their own home so that they can improve upon their life and give their children the best education.

loans.use: To maintain and expand business

loans.name: Zenovia

texts.en:
Zenovia is a member of the Sayhua 2 Village Bank, an experienced group that has been taking out loans from Asociacion Arariwa for years. She is 38 years old and is married with three children, who are 14, 10 and 4 years old. Zenovia sells meat in the market in Urubamba, a town in the Sacred Valley, located about one hour from the city of Cusco. She sometimes buys her meat from farmers themselves, and sometimes buys it from intermediaries. In a good week, she can sell three cows’ worth of beef, while in a slow week she sells just one. She has had her market stall since 1997, and works there seven days a week. Her husband works in transportation.

Zenovia is requesting a loan of 2,000 Nuevos Soles to buy beef and chicken. She has pledged to repay her Kiva loan in full and on time.

Zenovia’s goal for the future is to save up so that she can take care of herself in her old age. She would like to buy a car and a plot of land for herself.

loans.use: Buy chicken and beef

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah F. is 32 years old, divorced and has given birth to three children. Currently all her children (2 girls, 1 boy) are in school in the community where they live. She ended her marriage because of religious differences. She is a Christian while her ex-husband is a Muslim. He asked her several times to deny her religion and be part of his. For several years this did not happen so there was a need for separation.

Sarah sells maize porridge in her neighborhood. Maize porridge is one of the local foods enjoyed popularly as breakfast by almost all Ghanaians. It is prepared from milled maize boiled and taken with sugar, milk and bread. Sarah also sells assorted biscuits by the road side. With a large customer base, Sarah wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, sugar and milk to increase production. She also wants to upgrade her biscuit sales. Sarah hopes to increase income to support her children in school. She treks to buy her raw materials from the market. With the loan she believes she can buy more from the farmers which will prevent her from having to use middlemen. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Yesu Abusua Kuo’ which means God’s family.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, biscuits, sugar, milk etc.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia G. is forty years old. She is divorced due to a misunderstanding that ensued between her and the husband and she has remained a single parent ever since. She is a mother of three children. Two of her children are in the senior high school while the first born is in the Polytechnic. Currently, Cecilia lives with her children in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Elmina, near Cape Coast in the central region of Ghana. 
Cecilia is a restaurant operator. She cooks and serves foods such as rice and stew, yam slices, etc. in her restaurant. She procures the food items from the wholesalers from her community. She has been in this business for eight years. She wants a loan to procure food items and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Eva

texts.en: Eva D. is thirty two years old, married and the mother of two children. Fortunately all her children are currently in school. She is really dedicated to her work and supportive to her children. By her own effort and hard work, Eva has been able to enroll her children  in private school. She sells cosmetic products in the local community of Eguase where she lives. She believes she can make her business grow bigger with loan support. She wants to use the loan to buy more assorted cosmetics to increase her stock of goods. She believes this would help her save towards the children's education. Eva has been selling through hawking, ie house to house selling, for ten years. She is planning to rent a store to reduce the frequent hawking. With the loan she is sure that all her dreams will be achieved. Eva will be grateful for your assistance. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Yesu Abusua Kuo’ which literally means God’s family.

loans.use: To use the loan to buy more assorted cosmetics

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary B. is fifty six years old. She is married with three children, two of whom are currently in senior high school. The other is out of school and working. She lives with her children and husband in a family house in a fishing community called Elmina, near Cape Coast in the central region of Ghana. 

Mary works to support her husband financially. She is a trader in cosmetics. She procures cosmetics such as body sprays, powder, creams, etc. She hawks to sell her products in her community. Mary also treks to other markets to sell on the market days. She has been in business for six years and wants a loan to procure varieties of cosmetics in bulk. Mary is hopeful that she can help her husband give their children the best education.

loans.use: To procure cosmetics

loans.name: La Union De Los Vecinos 1 Group

texts.en:
The Bank of Hope, whose name is translated as The Neighbor's Union, is a new Bank recently formed in San Pedro de Macoris (southeast Dominican Republic). This will be their first micro loan in what they hope to be a successful endeavor to bring prosperity to their business activities. 
Bernabela B., the group coordinator, sells clothes. The items that have better sales are women's clothing, especially blouses and jeans. Bernabela has 6 children; three of them still live with her. They are 11, 16, and 14. She envisions her future as one where she will own her home and will run a successful boutique.
Most of the other group members also sell clothing. However, they don't feel like there's competition between them because they all have different clients. 
Please help us support this new group of entrepreneurs with this Kiva loan. Thank you!

loans.use: purchase clothing items for resale.

loans.name: Vida

texts.en:
Vida O., 37, is the mother of three children, one in senior high school, another in junior high and another in primary school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in the fishing community of Elmina, one of the tourist attraction centres near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana. 

To support her husband financially, Vida works as a trader, selling a variety of footwear including shoes, slippers, sandals, and prim soles in the community market, procuring her products from wholesale dealers in the regional capital, Cape Coast. As well, she sometimes hawks her wares and treks to other markets to sell on the market days. She has been in business for eight years and is requesting a loan to procure more footwear.

loans.use: To buy footwear.

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emelia O., 36, is the mother of five children, four in school and her youngest an infant. Emelia lives in Eguase, located in the central region of Ghana, with her husband, who works as a steel bender. Emelia is a direct woman who does not joke about her work. Her only friends are her husband and children because she believes having too many friends is not conducive to a productive life. 
	
Emelia has worked with flour for five years now, preparing and selling products including cakes, meat pies, chips, etc. She distributes her goods through mini shops where drinks are sold and sells her surpluses through hawking. Currently, inadequate funds are retarding business growth and profit margins, so Emelia is requesting a loan to buy bags of flour, margarine, sugar, vegetable oil, etc. With the loan she believes she will be in a better position to help her children in school. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Yesu Abusua Kuo,’ which means God’s family.

loans.use: To buy bags of flour, margarine, sugar, vegetable oil, etc.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice E. is the 40-year-old divorced mother of four children, two currently in senior high school, one in junior high and one in primary school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in the fishing community of Elmina, one of the country’s tourist attraction centres, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana. 

For the past ten years, Beatrice has worked hard as a trader to earn some income to support the family.  She deals in all kinds of drinks – malt, fan milk, fan ice, etc., procuring them from wholesale dealers in the regional capital, Cape Coast, and selling in the community market. Beatrice also distributes to other retailers in her community and nearby communities. She is now requesting a loan to procure the products in bulk.

loans.use: To procure drinks for her business.

loans.name: Ishaitu

texts.en:
Ishaitu I. is a 40-year-old woman. She is married and has five children. All her kids are in school. She lives with her husband in her matrimonial home in Eguase, a suburb of Moore in the central region of Ghana. She is an achiever and a resourceful young woman. She loves selling goods, a business through which she makes a living.

Ishaitu trades bananas and plantains, which she sells through hawking. She has been in this business for eight years. She treks to surrounding villages in the Central part of Ghana to purchase bulk stocks of bananas and plantains from the farmers and then retails them to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to pick up enough stock to make enough profit to support her family. She wants to use part of the profit to support her kids’ education.

With the loan, she wants to purchase a bulk supply of bananas and plantains, which will allow her to scale up her sales. She believes the loan would enable her to save more income to support her business growth. Ishaitu belongs to a village bank called ‘Yesu Abusua Kuo’ which means God’s family. She also hopes to receive GH¢1000 to make her business progress by restocking her inventory. This will help her save more to support her husband in taking care of their home.

loans.use: To buy food products like bananas and plantains.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria is a 52-year-old divorced mother of five children. She is a local manufacturer of palm kernel oil. Palm kernel oil is produced from palm kernel, which is a by-product of palm oil. The palm kernel is processed through various stages to obtain the palm kernel oil which is used to prepare many local dishes like fried fish and pastries. Victoria produces and supplies palm kernel oil to local food vendors. She also sells Fanti kenkey and homemade loaves of bread. She has been in this business for five years now.  Her production is low because she does not have the capital to buy a processing machine and does everything manually.  She wants to use the loan to buy seventy bags of palm kernel and an electric milling machine to help produce her oil in larger quantities. She believes the loan will enable her to save more money toward her children's educations. She belongs to a village bank called ‘Yesu Abusua Kuo’ which means God’s family.

loans.use: To buy seventy bags of palm kernel and an electric milling machine.

loans.name: Ana

texts.es: Ana tiene 38 años, es una dulce madre de dos pequeños hijos, quienes son su mayor tesoro; y junto a su pareja tratan de brindarles las mejores condiciones de vida, por ello compraron la casa  que les costó mucho construir. Desde muy joven tuvo que trabajar para ayudar a su familia, y dentro de sus actividades económicas que realizó encontró su verdadera vocación en los bordados, empezó a realizar diversos tejidos, ya que su creatividad la hicieron reconocida dentro de las diversas fábricas en las que trabajó. Más ahora adquirió una máquina especial para tejidos y bordados, la cual la ayuda a seguir trabajando, pero en su domicilio, pues le llevan grandes cantidades de prendas para que realice los tejidos o diversos adornos que sólo Ana, con su gran creatividad, puede realizar. Desde entonces se siente más tranquila, ya que dejó de lado las horas de ausencia de su hogar y tiene la posibilidad de trabajar y cuidar a su familia. Ahora tiene el anhelo de mejorar sus servicios con maquinaria más especializada o con instrumentos que le faciliten el arduo trabajo, pues algunos días tiene que terminar de bordar o tejer desde 100 a 300 prendas. Ana tiene una gran simpatía con su equipo de trabajo, pues dentro del grupo viene trabajando más de 5 años en MFP, le grada sentirse útil para realizar algunas tareas administrativas, las que le han ido ayudando en el trascurso de su permanencia. Más ahora este es su primer préstamo individual, fuera de su grupo, pues requiere mayor capital de trabajo. Con la finalidad de adquirir algunas herramientas o telares para sus trabajos, Ana optó por solicitar un préstamo de 3000 soles que serán invertidos en la compra de sus materiales de trabajo.
texts.en:
Ana, 38, is a doting mother of two small children, her treasures, and she and her husband try to give them the best. For that, they bought a house that cost a lot of build. From the time she was a girl, she's had to work hard to help her family and, among the jobs that she's done to earn money, she found that her true vocation is embroidery. She started by making different fabrics because her creativity had led her to be recognized for that skill at the factories where she worked. Later, she acquired a special machine for knitting and embroidery which allowed her to continue working--at home now--on clothing brought to her because only she, with her great creativity, could provide the level of decoration required. Since then, she's been happier because she no longer has to be away from home. She now has the chance to both work and care for her family. Next she wants to improve the level of services that she provides with a more specialized machine and instruments that will ease her difficult work, work that on some days requires her to complete 100 to 300 clothing pieces. Ana likes her working group, a group that's been working with MFP for more than 5 years, and she's grateful for the help they've provided with certain administrative tasks, something that's been very valuable during her time there. This will be her first individual loan, outside of the group, because she needs a larger amount of working capital. With the goal of buying some tools or cloth, Ana is applying for a 3000-soles loan that she will use to buy supplies for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for embroidery business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: La Union De Los Vecinos 3 Group

texts.en:
The members of Group 3 on the "Union de los Vecinos" (The Neighbors' Union) are requesting their first loan with Esperanza International. They hope this loan will help them establish their businesses and generate better profits to improve their living conditions.  In San Pedro de Macoris, the employment opportunities are not abundant due to the sugar cane industry collapse and the town's proximity to the capital. (For some industries it's not profitable to establish operations in San Pedro de Macoris, and some people cannot commute to Santo Domingo to work every day due to transportation costs).  

Ramon C. is the group coordinator. He is an electrician and decided to start making power inverters. This generates good profits because power outages are common in the Dominican Republic. Inverters are charged with batteries (the same kind you use in cars), and allow you to run some appliances for a reasonable amount of time. He will use this loan to buy wires and generator parts that are necessary to make inverters. Right now, he works out of his home but his hope is that profits from his sales will allow him to set up his own workshop, and eventually, build a new house of his own.   

Please help support these new entrepreneurs' initiatives with a Kiva loan. Thank you!

loans.use: To purchase electrical parts to assemble power inverters.

loans.name: Herminia

texts.es: A sus 59 años, Herminia sigue siendo una mujer con grandes fortalezas; gracias a sus hijos, quienes la ayudaron en su negocio, pueD. tener tranquilidad en D. su hogar donD. vive muy a gusto. Gracias a las oportunidades que supo aprovechar en el trascurso D. su vida pudo educar a sus hijos, quienes instalaron para su madre una tienda para que pudiera trabajar y no sentirse sola y mucho menos inactiva, que es lo que a la mayoría D. personas deprime. Es así, que desD. hace 4 años trabaja atendiendo su bodega todos los días, desD. las siete D. la mañana hasta las nueve D. la noche, pero los días que venD. comida cierra, pues hay mucha demanda en las tardes y cocinar es una D. las labores que le gusta realizar. Herminia tiene el deseo D. seguir trabajando para tener la posibilidad D. seguir cubriendo sus necesidades, pues “no lo agrada recibir, sino adquirir”; este pensamiento la motiva a luchar por incrementar su negocio e instalar un espacio para una librería y así surtir su mercadería. Trabajar con el grupo D. compañeras la llevaron a relacionarse con las personas y ayudarla en su negocio, pues las reuniones D. pago y los diversos eventos que celebran son motivos por las que sigue perteneciendo a PRISMA; pero este es su primer crédito individual, pues requiere D. capital para mejorar su negocio. Herminia comprará con los 3000 soles que solicita, grandes cantidades D. mercadería, como útiles escolares y productos D. belleza para tener una tienda muy bien surtida.
texts.en:
At 59, Herminia is still a woman of great fortituD.. Thanks to her children who help her with the business, she's able to live happily at home. Thanks to the opportunities that she's been smart enough to take advantage of over the course of her life, Herminia has been able to educate her children who, in turn, established a shop for their mother so that she would be able to work and not feel isolated, something that depresses most people. That's how, for 4 years, she's worked tending her grocery, each day, from seven in the morning until nine at night except those days when she closes to sell food. There's a lot of demand for her meals some evenings and cooking is one of the jobs that she most enjoys. Herminia would like to continue working in order to cover her everyday needs since "no lo agrada recibir, sino adquirir" [you're not grateful for what you receive, only what you buy]; this idea has led her to strive to grow her business and set up a space for bookshop. Working with a group has opened the way to friendships and help for her business and the payment meetings and other events are reasons for continuing to belong to PRISMA, but this will be Herminia's first individual loan. She will use the 3000-soles loan to buy large quantities of merchandise, things for students and beauty product, for example, to stock her shop.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supply general store.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy J. is a 30-year-old married woman with two children. Both of her children are in school. She lives with her husband in her matrimonial home at Eguase, a suburb of Moore in the central region of Ghana. She is an achiever and a resourceful young woman. She loves selling goods, which is how she makes a living. Lucy trades in cassava and plantains and has been selling in the community market for three years now. She treks to surrounding villages in the Central part of Ghana to purchase bulk stock from the farmers and then sell at retail to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to purchase enough stock to make enough profit to support her family. She wants a loan to purchase a bulk supply of cassava and plantain to enable her to generate more sales. She believes the loan will help her earn more income to support her business growth and also wants to use part of the profit to support her children’s educations. She also hopes to receive GHS1000 to help restock her inventory, which would enable her to save more money and support her husband to take care of the home. Lucy belongs to a village bank called ‘Kronkronye’ which means Holiness.

loans.use: To buy more bulk stock of cassava and plantains to sell at the market.

loans.name: La Bendicion 5 Group

texts.en:
The members of La Bendicion 5 Group have been clients of Esperanza International for 3 years, and are starting their 6th loan cycle. Many of the five members of this group sell clothes. They have made enough sales to successfully pay back five loans and have made profits that helped them to improve their quality of life. Each member sells in a different place and they refer customers to one another if a customer is looking for a specific item someone else in the group has for sale.

Ana R. is the group representative. She is a mother of 5 children. Selling clothes allows her to have her own income without leaving her home for extended periods at a time. The loans she has taken out have enabled her to purchase merchandise in larger quantities and of better quality. This has resulted in a faithful clientele that has grown thanks to her customers' referrals. Ana believes her hard work will pay off and one day she will have her own boutique.

Please help us to continue supporting these entrepreneurs through Kiva loans. Thank you!

loans.use: To purchase new clothing items for resale.

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas 2 Group

texts.en:
Mujeres Unidas in Spanish means "united women," and unity has been key to the success of this group of five. They have successfully received and paid back seven loans with Esperanza International. This will be their 8th loan.

Magalis C. is the group representative. She has 3 young children ages 10, 8 and 3. She has a "fantasia," which is a small store where you can buy accessories, personal care products, and school supplies. Magalis plans to add undergarments to her inventory, and will purchase the new products with this loan. Two other members of the group own grocery stores, and the other two run a poultry stand and a fruit stand.

The business stability they've experienced after taking out loans is, in their words, "incomparable" to their situation beforehand. Despite a worse economy, they feel more at ease and are confident that their hard work will pay off and they will continue to proviD. faithfully for their families. Please help us to continue supporting these entrepreneurs. Thank you!

loans.use: To purchase new undergarments inventory to sell in store.

loans.name: Shalom 6 & 7 Group

texts.en:
Group numbers 6 and 7 from the Shalom Bank of Hope have successfully repaid 4 loans to Esperanza International and will start their 5th loan cycle with this Kiva loan. Many of them sell food items and clothing. For most of their group members, providing a good education for their children (and advancing their businesses) proves to be their biggest challenge, one they are especially motivated to overcome. They know that education will allow them to do better in their businesses and/or become formal employees. 

Teolinda L. is the group representative. She has 4 children, including a 6-month-old baby. She is just 24 years old. She knows that she is mainly responsible for her children’s well being, and therefore wants to have an income-generating activity that would allow her to stay at home and take care of them. She sells clothing from her home. Since a lot of her customers cannot afford new clothes, she will also start selling used clothing she can purchase by bundle (she will buy one with this loan) that are still in optimal condition. This will open her business to potential new clients, which will increase her profits. In the near future, she would like to expand her house to have wider space to exhibit her merchandise. 

On behalf of Esperanza International, thank you for helping us support these entrepreneurs!

loans.use: Purchasing new clothes and a bundle of used clothes for resale

loans.name: Catalino

texts.es:
El señor Catalino C.  tiene 52 años, está casado, y tiene 3 hijos. El es propietario de tres vacas lecheras con cria y se dedica a la venta de leche y a la produccion de queso. La misma esta ubicada en la Compañia Cerro Real de la ciudad de Caacupe a cinco kilometros de centro.
 
El cliente realiza sus ventas por los alrrededores y en sudomicilio ya que no cuenta con un medio de trasporte tambien comenta  que con los préstamos que le otorgó la Fundación Paraguaya pudo comprar dos vacas con cria . Esto hizo que su venta aumente  y asi pudo llegar a mas  clientes.

Su objetivo a muy corto plazo es comprar un medio de transporte para agilizar su venta y llegar a mas cantidad de potenciales clientes.
texts.en:
Mr. Catalino C. is 52 years old, married, and has 3 children. He owns three milk cows and works selling milk and making cheese. His business is located in the Cerro Real Company in the city of Caacupe, 5 kilometers from the downtown. He sells in the surrounding neighborhoods and also from his home, since he does not have a car. He shared that with previous loan from Fundación Paraguaya he was able to buy cows. This increased his sales and then he was able to reach more customers. His short term goal is to buy a means of transportation to speed up his sales and be able to reach a larger quantity of potential clients.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two milk cows

loans.name: Arnaldo

texts.es:
El señor Arnaldo O. tiene 33 años, está casado, y tiene 2 hijos. El es propietario de un vehiuculo Toyota y se dedica al servcio de taxi. La misma esta ubicada en Barrio San Miguel de la ciudad de Caacupe.  La parada donde el trabaja cuenta con cinco taxi y dueños diferentes.

El cliente comenta que el servicio que realiza es por todo cordillera pero en en la ciudad que mas presta servicio es Caacupe y Atyra. Tambien alega que con los préstamos que le otorgó la Fundación Paraguaya pudo pagar el servicio de reparacion por su vehiculo. Esto hizo que pudiera mantener su clientela ya formada y asi tambien llegar a mas  clientes.

Su objetivo a muy corto plazo es comprarce un vehiculo en mejores condiciones para asi darles mayor comodida a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mr. Arnaldo O. is 33 years old, married, and has two children. He owns a Toyota and works as a taxi driver in the San Miguel district of the city of Caacupe. The taxi stop where he works has five different taxis drivers. He shares that he works over the whole range of land, but in the city he mainly works in Caacupe and Atyra. He claims that with the previous loans from Fundación Paraguaya he was able to pay for repairs on his vehicle, allowing him to maintain his client base he had already formed and also obtain more customers. His short term goal is to buy himself a car in better condition to provide greater comfort for his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To repair his car

loans.name: Con Esfuerzo Triunfaremos 4 Group

texts.en:
The members of this group, belonging to the Bank of Hope "Con Esfuerzo Triunfaremos" (We Will Succeed with Effort), are requesting their second loan since they've been clients of Esperanza International. This group of entrepreneurs lives in Consuelo, an area of San Pedro de Macoris known for being the hometown of baseball stars like Sammy Sosa. Consuelo was established around a sugar cane factory that is no longer operating. This has brought serious unemployment and left many acres of State-property land that are not being used right now because no one is planting on them after the sugar cane industry collapse. This has forced many people to become self-employed and set up their own businesses.

Roxana O. is the group representative and has a miscellaneous store. She sells all kinds of items, and will restock her inventory using the loan she has requested. She hopes to expand it to a large department store one day, so that people in Consuelo won't have to travel to San Pedro de Macoris (about 40 minutes away) to do their shopping.

Please help us support these microentrepreneurship initiatives through this Kiva loan. Thank you!

loans.use: Restock inventory in miscellaneous store

loans.name: Kuña Activa De Cabañas Group

texts.es:
El presente Comité  denominado Kuña activa de la compañía Cabañas de la ciudad de Caacupé, la misma integran 15 mujeres, todas ellas mayores de edad, y residentes en el mismo barrio.

En la actualidad el comité opera en su 10mo. ciclo recibiendo un promedio de guaranies 540.000 por cada integrante. Las mismas beneficiadas destinan sus prestamos en actividades comerciales detalladas mas abajo, que como se observa en la gran mayoria consiste en vender productos variados en forma ambulante que requiere de mayor esfuerzo para demandar los productos.

Es bueno mensionar que,  a la par que éstas mujeres reciben una asistencia financiera, asi tambien se benefician de servicios no financieros que comprenden la capacitación por cada ciclo, en las que las mismas aprenden como mantener la integridad del comité en donde pertenecen, aprenden a ahorrar, y a realizar presupuestos personales y familiares. Todo esto engloba los beneficios que reciben del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras que promueve la fundación Paraguaya de Cooperación  y Desarrollo.

La  integración toda del detallado Comité , agradece a la fundaciòn Parguaya por brindarles este tipo de oportunidades que promueve la creación de pequeños negocios y por ende generar recursos económicos a sectores desfavorecidos por este tipo de beneficios.

1.	Francisca C.        Vivero                             
2.	Elvira V.                   Vivero                            
3.	Inocencia A.          Despensa                      
4.	Marta B.                Venta de ropa             
5.	Felipa Q.            Peluqueria                     
6.	Maria C.                Despensa                       
7.	Elva D.                  Kiosko                            
8.	Juliana V.                   Venta de carbón             
9.	Lidia M.                   Vivero                             
10.	Clementina V.            Venta de ropa                  
11.	Hilaria G.             Venta de chipa                 
12.	Pablina V.         Vivero                              
13.	Maria M.               Despensa                        
14.	Liduvina C.            Despensa                         
15.	Carmen B.             Venta de cosmeticos
texts.en:
The present committee is named Kuña Activa in the Cabañas group from the city of Caacupé. Its membership includes 15 women, all of them adults and residents of the same neighborhood.

Right now the committee works in 10-month cycles, receiving an average of 540,000 for each member. These recipients use their loans for the economic activities detailed below, of which you will see the majority are street vendors that sell various products.

It should be mentioned that as well as the financial assistance that these women receive, they also benefit from non-financial services such as training each cycle, in which they learn to maintain the integrity of the committee, to save and to carry out their personal and family budgets. This encapsulates all the benefits that they receive from the program Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras (Enterprising Women’s Committee) that promotes the foundation Paraguaya de Cooperación y Desarollo (Cooperation and Development of Paraguay).

The members of the Committee thank the foundation Paraguaya for bringing them these types of opportunities that promote the creation of small businesses and generate economic resources for sectors that are not favored for this type of benefits.

1. Francisca C. Nursery 2. Elvira V. Nursery 3. Inocencia A. Small store 4. Marta B. Clothing Sales 5. Felipa Q. Hair Salon 6. Maria C. Small store 7. Elva D. Kiosk 8. Juliana V. Coal sales 9. Lidia M. Nursey 10. Clementina V. Clothing sales 11. Hilaria G. Chipa (bread) sales 12. Pablina V. Nursery 13. Maria M. Small store 14. Liduvina C. Small store 15. Carmen B. Sale of cosmetics

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of merchandise: fruits, vegetables, meats, cosmetics, hardware, bread-making materials, coal, fertilized seeds, plants and others

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: Maria es una mujer muy trabajadora, comprometida con el desarrollo y bienestar D. sus hijos, a quienes pudo educar y hacer profesionales. Más ahora vive solo con su esposo y su última hija, con quienes comparte sus mejores momentos dentro D. su casa, la cual está llena D. recuerdos. Estar pendiente del bienestar D. sus hijos la motivaron en trabajar desD. muy joven, pues los gastos para la educación D. sus hijos fueron muy costosos, pero satisfactorios. Gracias a su esfuerzo hoy sus hijos son profesionales, e instalaron una tienda en su domicilio para que Maria pudiera dejar D. trabajar fuera D. casa y dedicarse a su hogar. Es así que desD. hace 10 años viene atendiendo su tienda D. abarrotes y dulces, que gracias a la ubicación tiene grandes ingresos todos los días, sobre todo en las mañanas hasta el medio día, pues las madres D. familia y los escolares son los que mayormente la visitan. A pesar D. tener gran acogida, requiere D. más productos para incrementar sus ingresos, los que le ayudarán a ahorrar y tener un soporte económico en su vejez y la D. su pareja, quien también es muy trabajador, pues tiene una cerrajería y juntos proveen lo necesario para su futuro. Con su grupo D. trabajo ha conseguido tener muchas amistades y le agrada realizar actividades con sus compañeras, pero lo incomodo es tener que ser drástica cuando algunas no cumplen su responsabilidad con los pagos asignados, es por ello que inició su primer crédito individual dentro D. MFP y así tener mayor posibilidad D. crecer como negociante. La prioridad para María y en lo que invertirá el dinero que solicita es para surtirse D. productos y adquirir mayor cantidad D. mercadería para que sus clientes se sientan contentos al encontrar lo necesario para su hogar.
texts.en:
Maria is a hard-working woman, dedicated to the development and wellbeing of her children, whom she has educated to be professionals. Now she lives alone with her husband and her youngest daughter, with whom she shares her best moments in a home that is full of memories. The wellbeing of her children motivated her to start work very young. The costs of her children’s education were high but worth it. Thanks to her efforts today her children are professionals and have established a store in her home so that Maria could stop working away from home and dedicate herself to her household. For 10 years she has attended her store selling groceries and candies. Thanks to the location, she has good profits everyday, above all in the mornings until noon when most of the mothers and students visit her. Despite her good standing, she requires more products to increase her profits and help her to save and have an economic support for her old age and her husband’s, who is also a hard-worker. He has a locksmith’s shop, and together they proviD. for their future. With her work group she has founded many friendships and she likes doing things with her friends. The uncomfortable part is when it’s necessary to be severe with those that don’t fulfill their responsibilities with assigned payments. For this reason, she solicited her first individual loan from MFP, and in this way has more possibilities to grow as a businesswoman. Maria’s priority for this money is to stock up her store so that her customers can find what they need for their homes.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her merchandise

loans.name: Tempora

texts.es: Tempora tiene 45 años, hace 20 años se casó y formó una bonita familia, la cual la llena de mucha dicha por sus dos hijas, pero también la llenó de responsabilidades. Para dar seguridad a sus seres queridos tuvo que trabajar muchos años a lado su esposo y juntos adquirieron una casa en donde habitan armoniosamente. Sostener un hogar es una carga muy pesada, pero compartir esta carga con su pareja hace el peso liviano, pues juntos se dedican a prestar servicios a las fábricas que solicitan diseños su publicidad, así como trabajos para logotipos enmarcados en prendas o diversa papelería. Este trabajo hubiera sido difícil de manejar si su esposo no hubiera estudiado este oficio, pero a pesar de que la demanda es buena, siempre se requiere de nueva tecnología que resalte el acabado del trabajo, y debido a su economía no tiene la posibilidad adquirir la maquinaria necesaria para mejorar la calidad de los servicios y aumentar la productividad de su taller, el cual también falta implementar, pues está instalado en el patio de su casa y requiere de ambientación adecuada para su trabajo. El tiempo que Tempora lleva con PRISMA es de 5 años y junto a su equipo de trabajo viene desempeñándose con responsabilidad, pues el grupo siempre está tratando de mejorar y eso le agrada porque demuestran la calidad de personas con las que interactúa. Su préstamo de 1500 soles es básicamente para invertirlo en materiales de trabajo, tales como pinturas, diseños y moldes de impresiones.
texts.en:
Tempora is 45-years old; twenty years ago she got married and started a beautiful family. Her two daughters bring so much to her life but also come with a lot of responsibilities. In order to provide a good home for their precious children, Tempora and her husband have had to work for many years, and together they bought a house where their family lives happily. Supporting the household is very difficult, but sharing this responsibility with her husband makes the burden lighter. Together they offer their services to manufacturers seeking graphic designers for marketing. Typical projects include designing logos to be printed on garments or a variety of stationary. This work would have been difficult if her husband hadn't studied graphic design. But despite good demand for their work, new technology is required to makes the finished work stand out, and due to their limited resources they can't acquire the machinery necessary to improve their product quality and productivity. Their workshop is set up in the patio of the house and inadequate for the work. Tempora has been with PRISMA for five years and, together with her team, fulfills her obligations responsibly. The group is always trying to improve, which shows the quality of the group's members. Tempora's loan of 1,500 PEN will be invested in work materials, such as paint, and print designs and patterns.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of printing materials

loans.name: Amor Y Esperanza 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
The Amor y Esperanza (Love and Hope) Bank of Hope group is ready to start its entrepreneurial endeavor with Esperanza International. The members of this group are very excited about receiving their loans and bringing new life to their businesses. They feel very thankful to be given the opportunity to receive a loan and improve their lives through their own work. 

Yolanda P. V. is the group coordinator. She has four children who are all grown up (the youngest is 26 years old). However, they all still live with her and she supports them financially. Her business consists of selling clothing from her house. She purchases clothes in bundles, then sells the clothes, and this activity is what her first loan will be used for. If sales are good, she can sell them all in a month. This bundle will be entirely of children’s clothing, not necessarily because it sells better, but, in Yolanda’s words, “Because these are the clothes I like to sell.” She thinks the fact that she dedicates her business to only the clothes she likes to sell will make her business progress.  She hopes in the future to buy and sell bundles with bedding (sheets and towels) as well as clothes for adults. 

Matelo C. is the group two coordinator. He has six children who are all living with him. He sells vegetables in a stand at a local market. He buys his vegetables from a large supplier in the same market and sells them in his small stand.  The vegetables he sells the most are carrots and eggplant. Eggplant is a popular food in Dominican Republic because it doesn’t cost much, making it affordable when meat is too expensive.  Also, it serves as a good siD. dish with rice and beans, which is the traditional Dominican meal. Matelo thinks it’s important for a stand in a market to look attractive so that customers are drawn to it. He also thinks a seller must be aware of his customers’ demands because demands vary from person to person. He hopes this first loan with Esperanza International will help him increase his sales and help him set up a larger stand in the market.

Please help these new micro entrepreneurs launch their initiatives to generate income and improve their quality of life. On behalf of Esperanza International, thank you for your support!

loans.use: Buy bundles of clothing to restock her inventory

loans.name: Comité La Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El Comité Caacupé la nueva Esperanza esta integrada actualmente por 18 señoras trabajdoras del barrio Sagrado Corazón de Jesús de la cuidad de Caacupé.  Actualmente estan operando el 7mo. ciclo del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya de Cooperación y Desarrollo, que consiste en beneficiarle a las miembros con asistencia crediticia y servicios no financieros que incluye capacitación formal para capitalizar ahorros, charlas para el mantenimiento íntegro del Comité, capacitaciones sobre presupuesto personal, familiar, y otros mas.

Las integrantes  del Comité administran el uso comercial de sus créditos en un promedio de 466.000 guaranies por cada  integrante. Dicho monto lo invierten en las actividades detalladas mas abajo.

Las mienbros del comité dan las gracias a la Fundación Paraguaya por tener la misión y visión de formar emprendedoras como ellas, capacitarles y brindarles servicios financieros viables para la realidad social que enfrentan estas mujeres  de escasos recursos.

1.	Francisca F.                    Copetin             
2.	Silma G.                     Despensa         
3.	Fautina A.                   Modista             
4.	Victoria F.                      Modista            
5.	Sonia P.                        Kiosko              
6.	Elsa A.                         Despensa          
7.	Lucia A.                     Venta de ropa    
8.	Olimpia S.                  Despensa          
9.	Rosa P.                        Venta de ropa    
10.	Dionicia A.                  Kiosko               
11.	Mariana F.                   Modista               
12.	Patricia V.                   Kisoko                
13.	Celia S.                          Kiosko                 
14.	Francisca G.            Despensa           
15.	Deysi N.                    Kiosko                
16.	Maria Teresa S.           Venta de ropa     
17.	Noelia G.                  Despensa           
18.	Antonia V.                   Kisoko
texts.en:
The Comité Caacupé la Nueva Esperanza (Caacupé Committee of New Hope) is currently composed of 18 women workers from the neighborhood of Sagrado Corazón de Jesús in the city of Caacupé. Right now they are executing the seven-month program of Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya de Cooperación y Desarrollo (Committee of Entrepreneurial Women of the Paraguayan Foundation of Cooperation and Development), which assists the members with credit assistance as well as non-financial services including formal training on capitalizing savings, talks on the maintenance of the integrity of the Committee, trainings on personal budgets, family, and more.

The members of the Committee administer the commercial use of their credit with an average of 466,000 PYG for each member. This amount is invested in the activities detailed in the loan use section.

The members of the Committee give their thanks to the Fundación Paraguaya for having the mission and the vision to form entrepreneurs such as themselves, and for training and providing viable financial services for the social reality that faces these ladies of scarce resources.

Translated from Spanish by William Gray, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of: much needed merchandise for the pantry such as rice, soda, milk, sugar, herbs, and meat; other purchases such as fabric, thread, new and used clothes, etc.

loans.name: Mujeres De Gloria 4 Group

texts.en: This group belonging to the Mujeres en Gloria (Women in Glory) Bank of Hope is ready for their second loan through Esperanza International. They are very proud of themselves for fully paying their first loan and feel good about the fact that Esperanza International has rewarded their good payments with a second loan.
