Yanilsa V. is the group coordinator. She has two children and lives with her husband. Her children are nine and four years old. The oldest goes to school and the youngest will start in the next school year. She is a home-to-home seller of clothing and shoes. Her mother owns a convenience store so she will use the money from her second loan to set up a display in her mother’s store, which will allow her to offer her products to a wider clientele. Even though right now she sells clothing, Yanilsa is a college student. She plans to major in Education, concentrating in Elementary Education. She hopes to finish her college education in order to accomplish her dream of setting up an elementary school to teach children. Yanilsa is one of the many examples of Esperanza clients who intend to use their businesses to get to a point in their future where they can give back to their communities. Yanilsa believes education can help a person have a better quality of life, which is why she wants to eventually commit her time to teaching children. On behalf of Esperanza International and the Mujeres de Gloria Bank of Hope, thank you for your support!

loans.use: To set up a shoe display in her mother's convenience store

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas 1 & 2 Group

texts.en: Groups 1 and 2 from the Mujeres Unidas Bank of Hope are ready to start their second loan cycle through Esperanza International. The group members all live in Villa Mella, which is located in the northern outskirts of Santo Domingo, which is Dominican Republic’s capital city. Evelyn R. and Josue A. are the group coordinators. Evelyn has five children. The youngest is 12 years old. All her children still live with her. She sells shoes, which she purchases in Dajabon (a city in the northwest of the Dominican Republic, which is about a 5 ½ hour ride from Santo Domingo) as well as in the capital. With this loan, she will buy mostly tennis shoes and sandals. She explains that depending on the time of year, sales increase on a certain kind of shoe (for example, loafers during back-to-school time). Evelyn hopes her profits from selling shoes will allow her to buy a house of her own. This would let her have a more peaceful life. Josue has four children of ages 10, 8, 6 and 3. His current business is selling clothes. He finds greater demand for women’s clothing. Lately, however, he has noticed that people are not buying as much as usual. He will use this second loan to purchase new clothes to sell. During his interview, he commented that he likes the fact that because all the members of his group paid their first loan on time, Esperanza International approved higher loan amounts for them in this second loan cycle. He hopes to continue that trend so he can invest larger amounts in his business and create sustainable growth. Thank you for supporting these entrepreneurs!

loans.use: purchasing tennis shoes and sandals

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas 3 And 4 Group

texts.en:
These 10 entrepreneurs are the new members of the Mujeres Unidas Bank of Hope from VilL. MelL.. They live in the farthest northern neighborhood of Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic.  Ornise M. is the Group 3 Coordinator. She doesn’t speak much Spanish so her fellow group members helped with her interview and also described some of their own businesses and why they decided to get together on a microloan. 
Ornise sells clothing which she buys in bundles. She travels from Santo Domingo all the way to Dajabon, a city on the border with Haiti with a large commercial market. It is about a 5½ hour riD.. Another member of the group is involved with the same business. The other businesses incluD. a butcher shop and a fried food stand. Two of the members own colmados (convenience stores). 
Carine D. L. C. is the Group 4 Coordinator. This group was interviewed during a visit to Esperanza International’s DR headquarters in Santo Domingo. Carine also sells clothing. She would like to increase her business profits to build a reputation in her area. In general, the group members indicate that loans help them to keep their businesses stocked and allow them to have merchandise available for longer periods of time. They are very excited to be receiving their first microloan through Esperanza International. Please help us to support their business initiatives. Thank you!

loans.use: To purchase bundles of clothing for resale

loans.name: Creciendo Hacia El Futuro 3 Group

texts.en:
The members of this Bank of Hope have successfully paid back 6 loans to Esperanza International. These previous loans have allowed the entrepreneurs to expand their business activities, their inventory volume and their profit margins. They want to see their children have a better life quality, provide them schooling and a college education, and hopefully see them break the vicious circle of poverty.

Petronila M. is the group representative. She has two children, ages 17 and 9. She has a small store in her home where she offers an array of items for sale: from personal care products to school supplies. She would like to see her store grow to become a department store (maybe a chain of them!) that will provide items at more accessible prices for the community.

All the group members have similar businesses, but they do not compete against each other. Usually, the items available in one are not available in the other, and they live far enough apart for there to be enough clientele for everybody.

Please help us to continue supporting these entrepreneurs through this Kiva micro loan. Thank you!

loans.use: purchasing miscellaneous items for store

loans.name: De Lunion Group

texts.en:
The “De Lunion” or “Unity” Group is made up of 10 male and female entrepreneurs, half of whom will be taking out a loan this time. These 5 women are looking forward to continued success and growth in their businesses with their 2nd loan. Though small, the group has a wide range of businesses from cosmetics to clothing, and from wood to food.

Ruth J. is the representative of the group. Ruth mostly sells used clothing and shoes which she buys in the big city to sell in her community. She says that the 1st loan was beneficial to her business because she was able to buy in larger quantities and increase her profit margin. She hopes to continually grow her business, increase her savings so she may finish school, go to college, and eventually get married. On behalf of Ruth, "De Lunion", and Esperanza, we thank you for your support.

loans.use: used clothing, sandals, shoes, jewlery for re-sale

loans.name: Barrio Maria Auxiliadora Group

texts.es:
El presente Comité denominado Barrio Maria Auxiliadora integran 19 mujeres, todas ellas mayores de edad, residentes en de la compañía Cabañas de la ciudad de Caacupé.

En la actualidad el comité opera en su 10mo. ciclo recibiendo  un promedio de guaranies 578.000 por cada integrante y las mismas la invirtieron en la compra de productos tales como arroz, leche, carne, fideo, gaseosas, semillas para plantas, ropas nuevas y usadas, algunas de las integrantes venden estos productos en forma ambulante lo cual implica un esfuerzo mucho mayor para comercializar estos productos.

Una de las caracteristica de este comité es de que son muy unidas y cada fín de semana realizan actividades para aumentar y capitalizar el ahorro interno del grupo.

Todas las integrantes agracedecen a la Fundación Paraguaya por el apoyo que están recibiendo no solo por los préstamos que recibierón sino también por las capacitaciones permanente que recibe especialmente cuando van renovar el préstamo y también por brindarle la oportunidades  de que promuevan la creación de pequeños negocios y por ende generar recursos económicos y empleos para familiares.

1.	Maria C.             Venta de pollo               
2.	Victoria B.                Kiosko                            
3.	Guillermina E.        Despensa                       
4.	Rosa B.                Venta de ropas               
5.	Maria B.               Despensa

texts.en:
The group Barrio Maria Auxiliadora is made up of 19 adult women. They live in La Compañía Cabañas in the city of Caacupé. The group is in their tenth cycle of receiving an average of 578,000 PYG ($113) per member. They bought products such as rice, milk, meat, noodles, soft drinks, seeds for planting, and new and used clothes. It requires a lot more effort to market these products in the streets as some of the members do. This group is very united. Every week end they carry out activities to increase and capitalize upon the group’s savings. All of the group members are grateful to the Fundación Paraguaya for the support they are receiving. They are grateful not only for the loans they have received, but also for the good advice. They appreciate the opportunities offered to create small businesses that generate economic resources and employment for family members. 1. Maria C. Sells Chicken 2. Victoria B. Kiosk 3. Guillermina E. Grocery Store 4. Rosa B. Sells Clothes 5. Maria B. Grocery Store 6. Mirian F. Grocery Store 7. Herminia B. Sells “Chipa” (A typical bread in Paraguay) 8. Rosa L. Sells “Chipa” (A typical bread in Paraguay) 9. Ana B. Grocery Store 10. Sebastiana V. Sells Clothes 11. Herminia O. Sells “Chipa” (A typical bread in Paraguay) 12. Maria B. Grocery Store 13. Mirta G. Grocery Store 14. Eliodora O. Sells Plants 15. Ruth C. Grocery Store 16. Maria D. Sells Soft Drinks 17. Silvia B. Grocery Store 18. Carmen Colmán Grocery Store 19. Rosa E. Sells Plants

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise such as:  fruit, vegetables meat,cosmetics,raw materials for chipa (bread),coal,soft drinks,noodles,rice, milk eggs, and others

loans.name: Vy`a Raity Group

texts.es:
El comité está integrado por 18 señoras de la compañía Potrero de la cuidad de Tobati.  Actualmente el comité se encuentra en el octavo ciclo consecutivo de su crédito.

Las 18 señoras manejan un crédito promedio de guaranies 480.000 por cada integrante, a travez del apoyo educativo y financiero que les brinda el programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya de Cooperación y Desarrollo. 

Los miembros del Comité Vy`a Raity agradecen a la Fundación Parguaya por el apoyo constante que se les brinda a travez del mencionado programa y esperan como siempre cumplir bien sus responzabilidades y seguir trabajando con la Institución para combatir la pobreza.

1.	Maria Griselda S.       Artesania en madera      
2.	Maria Aida L.            Venta de ropa

texts.en:
The group is made up of 18 women from the Portrero Company in the city of Tobati. The group is in its eighth loan cycle. The 18 woman manage a loan of an average of 480,000 PYG ($93) per member. They have this loan by means of the educational and financial support offered by the Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya de Cooperación y Desarrollo. The members of the group Comité Vy`a Raity are grateful to the Fundación Parguaya for the constant support offered to them from this program. They hope, as always, to meet their responsibilities and to keep working with the Institución to fight poverty. 1. Maria Griselda S. Wood Crafts 2. Maria Aida L. Sells Clothes 3. Nelly L. Wood Crafts 4. Lilian Mabel S. Wood Crafts 5. Saturnina S. Wood Crafts 6. Rosalina S. Wood Crafts 7. Elvia Mariela S. Wood Crafts 8. Alicia S. Vargas Wood Crafts 9. Liz Maria R. Wood Crafts 10. Juana M. Gomez Wood Crafts 11. Ursulina S. Rubber Crafts 12. Silvia S. Rubber Crafts 13. Claudia N. Rubber Crafts 14. Waldina C. Wood Crafts 15. Gloria Mabel N. Domestic Employee 16. Liliana F. Seamstress 17. Carmen B. N. Haberdashery 18. Laura Maribel R. Wood Crafts

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy nails, wood, glue, blades, saw, rubber, and to buy material for sewing

loans.name: Los Fuertes 1, 2 And 3 Group

texts.en:
This Kiva loan will be for a full Bank of Hope with a total of 15 members. This will be their first loan with Esperanza International. They are all looking forward to starting or reinforcing their business activities. Expanding their businesses represents a challenge for them; in their own words, "the economy is not good and not proper for most businesses". However, they remain optimistic and are willing to work hard.

The coordinators for the three groups of five are Ligne L., Emilia M., and Wilson F.. The three of them are in sales but each sells a different item: Ligne sells vegetables, Emilia sells hair extensions and weaves, and Wilson sells clothes. Emilia and Wilson are parents. Emilia has an 8-year-old child and Wilson's child is 9 years old. They all have a common dream: own a house one day.

Please help us support this new group of entrepreneurs. Thank you!

loans.use: stock or re-stock their business inventory

loans.name: Ramon

texts.es:
Ramon tiene 30 años, es soltero, y tiene 1 hijo.  Su negocio tiene una antiguedad de 5 años y vende maiz (en granel y tambien molida), queso, frutas y verduras. La inversión del préstamo, lo destinó a la compra de maiz, ya que en esta época es lo que presenta mayor demanda en su negocio. Los ingresos que le genera este negocio, le permite cubrir los gastos propios de su familia además de los gastos del colegio de su hijo.

Al inicio comenta que fue muy duro y difícil iniciar este negocio ya que no contaba con capital y  las primeras inversiones realizadas fueron gracias a sus ahorros y con la ayuda de sus padres quienes les facilito un pequeño capital.

En este emprendimiento Ramon tiene tambien cuenta con el apoyo de su madre que en horas de llevarle a su hijo a la escuela es la encargada del negocio y que lo hace con gran responsabilidad.
texts.en:
Ramon is 30, single, and has one son. He has had his business for 5 years. He sells corn (in bulk and also ground), cheese, fruit, and vegetables. He will use the loan to buy corn because it is now in the greatest demand in his business. The income generated by his business allows him to cover the family expenses as well as the school expenses for his son. In the beginning it was very hard and difficult to start his business. He did not have resources. The first investments made were thanks to his savings and help from his parents who gave a little money. In this endeavor Ramon also counts on his mother’s support. When Ramon takes his son to school, his mother is in charge of the business. She does this in a very responsible manner.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn

loans.name: El Mamey 1 Group

texts.en:
The El Mamey Bank of Hope is a new group of micro-entrepreneurs joining Esperanza International for a loan. They live near VilL. MelL., which is a large district on the northern outskirts of Santo Domingo. There, employment opportunities are scarce and life conditions are difficult. Most people have turned to self-employment to support their families.

This group’s coordinator is Lario P.. Lario is 28 years old. He is married and has 3 children. Despite having some college education, Lario has not been able to find a good job placement. He has taken advantage of the numerous construction sites around VilL. MelL. to sell breakfast and lunch to the construction workers. He sells good portions of traditional items like rice and beans for a very low price. He plans on using this loan to buy more food items in order to be able to cook more portions to sell, since he is finding a larger demand for his meals.

Lario hopes the profits from his business will help him establish a food business where people can come and buy from him, instead of his having to go and sell on site.

On behalf of the El Mamey Bank of Hope members and Esperanza International, thank you for your support!

loans.use: buy rice, beans and poultry for lunches

loans.name: Evelin Brigida

texts.es: La Sra. Evelin es madre soltera tiene un hijo en edad escolar,  atiende un  Restaurante de comida; su especialidad es la comida chuquisaqueña, departamento de Bolivia, con muchos años de trayectoria es muy conocida en la Zona, con la ayuda de la mama y la hermana, viven en una pequeña casa que comparte con sus mama  es con el único ingreso con que cuentan para solventar todos  sus gastos familiares, y de estudios de su hijo, es cumplida con sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Evelin is a single mother. She has a school-age son. She works at a restaurant. Her specialty is chuquisaqueña (local) cuisine from Bolivia. With many years in this career and the help of her mother and sister, she is well known in the area. She lives in a small house that she shares with her mother. She pays all the family costs, including the education of her son, with her income.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of dishes, pots and a food processor

loans.name: Ramona

texts.es:
La sra. Ramona tiene 51 años, esta casada, y tiene 6(seis) hijos.  Su negocio tiene una antiguedad de 15 años y en su negocio vende todo tipo de mercaderias de consumo. La inversión del préstamo, lo destinó a la compra de todo tipo de mercaderias para la canasta fliar, lo que hizo su negocio este bién surtido. Los ingresos que le genera este negocio le permite cubrir los gastos propios de su familia además de los gastos del colegio de sus hijos.

Al inicio comenta que fue muy duro y difícil iniciar este negocio ya que no contaba con capital, y  las primeras inversiones realizadas fueron gracias a sus ahorros y con la ayuda de su marido que le facilito un pequeño capital.

En este emprendimiento Ramona tiene el apoyo y acompañamiento de sus dos hijos mayores quienes la ayudan en atender su negocio los dias que ella sale a hacer las compras y que muestran gran responsabilidad en la hora de hacerlo.
texts.en:
Ramona is 51-years old, married, and has six children. In her business, which is 15-years old, she sells all types of consumables. The loan will be used to buy all kinds of merchandise for the typical buyer, keeping her store well-stocked. The income from her business allows her to cover her family's household expenses as well as education costs. At first it was difficult to start her business, as she didn't have much starting capital and her initial investments were thanks to her savings and the help of her husband, who was able to obtain some money. In this enterprise Ramona has the support and company of her two older children, who help her to attend to the store on the days when she has to leave to make purchases and are very responsible in their work.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise for consumption

loans.name: El Mamey 2 Group

texts.en:
The El Mamey Bank of Hope is a new group of micro-entrepreneurs joining Esperanza International for a loan. They live near Villa Mella, which is a large district on the northern outskirts of Santo Domingo. There, employment opportunities are scarce and life conditions are difficult. Most people have turned to self-employment to support their families. All the members of this group are Haitian immigrants.

Roselene F. is the group coordinator. She is married and has 3 children. She has a small stand where she sells fruits and vegetables, and she will use her loan to buy more items to sell. Her biggest challenge at the time is communicating. She hardly speaks any Spanish and has a hard time speaking and trying to understand her Dominican customers. She was not able to go to school either, so cannot read or write. This is a powerful reason for Roselene to work very hard to provide her children with an education that will help them embrace a future with more opportunities.

On behalf of the El Mamey Bank of Hope members and Esperanza International, thank you for your support!

loans.use: purchase friuts and vegetables in season for re-sale

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth J. S. is 29 years old was widowed 4 years ago. She now lives with her mother in a small village called Paraxquin, which is about 32 km from Tecpan Guatemala. Since she was very young, Janeth has worked with her mother helping to manage their crops and raising their cow in the best way possible. Working together like this has been their way of life for over 20 years. They recently started making and selling bread and plan to invest part of their loan to purchase flour in order to make more bread, which they will sell in their village. During the months leading up to Easter, bread sales increase significantly and the women think it would be a good idea to take advantage of this for their business. Ms. J. says that she must make the most of the strength that she has now at a younger age so that when she gets older she can sustain herself and live with dignity. Her efforts today she is always thinking about the future.

*********************************************************************************
Translated from Spanish by Andrea Bouch, Kiva Fellow.
*********************************************************************************

La señorita Janeth J. S., de 29 años de edad viven con su Madre viuda desde hace cuatro años, ellas viven en la Aldea Paraxquin; desde pequeña trabaja con su mamá, administrando sus cultivos, tienen una vaca, trabajan juntas en su crianza, buscando la mejor manera para cuidarla, la aldea queda a 32 kilometros de distancia del municipio de Tecpán Guatemala, desde hace 20 años trabajan de esta manera unidas para su forma de vida, y hace poco de dedican a la elaboración de pan quieren invertir, una parte en compra de Harina, para hornear, y distribuir en su aldea pan que en esta época es una tradición en Guatemala el consumo de pan, por lo que piensan que es un buen comienzo iniciar este negocio, la señorita J. que por ser joven es un momento para aprovechar su fuerza, para cuando sea de edad avanzada, pueda sostenerse con dignidad y con su esfuerzo ella piensa en su futuro.

loans.use: Materials for making bread and helping to grow crops and animals

loans.name: Sagrado Corazon De Jesus Group

texts.es:
El Comité Sagrado Corazón de Jesús que recide en la compañía Cabañas de la cuidad de Caacupé esta compuesta por 18 integrantes, todas de la misma zona, y actualmente estan en el décimo ciclo, participando del programa comité de mujeres emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya.

Se benefician de las capacitaciones por ciclo que comprenden témas de integración del Comité, autoestima, ahorros, y presupuestos, asi mismo la institucion tambien les beneficia de un capital operativo que hoy por hoy asciende en un promedio de guaranies 6.033.000  por cada integrante.
El capital desembolsado de la Fundación directamente va acompañar el crecimiento de cada negocio mensionados anteriormente.

Todas las integrantes agradecen a la Fundación por este apoyo tan importante y esperan como siempre cumplir los reglamentos propuestos por la instituciòn para que sigan teniendo tan importante programa de apoyo  brindado por la Fudación Parguaya de Cooperación de Desarrollo.

1.	Salvadora Monzón              Tambo                          
2.	Ascención Monzón             Vivero de plantas            
3.	Simeona C.                 Tambo                          
4.	Ana Isabel G.           Vivero de plantas          
5.	Florencia O.             Realiza juegos de azar  
6.	Esperanza D.        Venta de dulce              
7.	Isabel L.                        Venta de dulce              
8.	Josefina S.                     Despensa                      
9.	Celina  M.                       Vivero de plantas           
10.	Claudelina E.             Despensa                      
11.	Maria Vidalia M.               Vivero de plantas          
12.	Gloria Monzón                      Empleada                      
13.	Maria Eulasia A.           Despensa                      
14.	Maria del Carmen G.  Venta de plantas           
15.	Cristina Mozón                     Venta de leche               
16.	Rosalina C.                   Venta de huevo              
17.	Maria Leticia C.         Venta de ropa                
18.	Hilda Daisy B.               Peluquera
texts.en:
The Sagrado Corazón de Jesús ('Sacred Heart of Jesus') committee, which meets in the Cabañas company of Caacupé city, is composed of 18 members who all live in the same zone, are in their tenth loan cycle, and participate in the Fundación Paraguaya's committee of women entrepreneurs. They benefit from the training in each loan cycle that cover topics such as committee integration, self-esteem, savings, and budgeting. They also benefit from the institution's working capital that grows day by day, averaging 6,033,000 PYG per member. The funds disbursed by the foundation go directly to aid growth in each of the businesses mentioned. All the members appreciate the foundation for its important support and expect to always follow the rules set by the institution, so that they can continue to have the important support program provided by Fudación Parguaya, of the Cooperación de Desarrollo. 1. Salvadora Monzón (Vendor) 2. Ascención Monzón (Plant nursery) 3. Simeona C. (Vendor) 4. Ana Isabel G. (Plant nursery) 5. Florencia O. (Makes gambling games) 6. Esperanza D. (Sells sweets) 7. Isabel L. (Sells sweets) 8. Josefina S. (Store) 9. Celina M. (Plant nursery) 10. Claudelina E. (Store) 11. Maria Vidalia M. (Plant nursery) 12. Gloria Monzón (Domestic worker) 13. Maria Eulasia A. (Store) 14. Maria del Carmen G. (Sells of plants) 15. Cristina Mozón (Sells milk) 16. Rosalina C. (Sells eggs) 17. Maria Leticia C. (Sells clothes) 18. Hilda Daisy B. (Hairstylist)

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of essential merchandise for stores, ingredients to make sweets, clothes, hair salon products, enriched animal feed, etc..

loans.name: Felicia

texts.es:
La Sra. Felicia Escurra tiene 51 años de edad, es separada, y estuvo casado por 14 años. El matrimonio tuvo cuatro hijos que actualmente están todos casados y viven en forma independiente.

La Sra. Felicia se inicio en este negocio de ventas de joyas hace cuatro años con la ayuda de uno de sus hijos que le dio el capital inicial y a partir de ahi ella empezo a aumentar sus mercaderias gracias a que cada dia aumenta su clientela y por ende aumenta su ingreso mensual.

El cliente solicita el préstamo para la compra de aro, argolla, medallitas, anillos, cadenas, pulseras y otras joyas de plata y de esta forma cumplir con todos los pedidos de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mrs. Felicia Escurra is 51 years old, separated, and was married for 14 years. The couple had four children who today are married and live on their own. Felicia began this business selling jewelry 4 years ago with the help of one of her children who gave her the initial capital and from there she began to increase her merchandise as thankfully every day her clientele grew as a result increasing her monthly income. The client seeks a loan to buy earrings, rings, medals, necklaces, chains and other silver jewelry and in this way meet her customer’s orders.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy earrings, rings, medals, necklaces, bracelets and other silver jewelry

loans.name: Marìa Guadalupe

texts.en:
María Guadalupe O. J. is a married woman who lives in Villa Lobos, a rapidly growing urban community outside of Guatemala City. She has 3 grown children. María says that she owns her house and she also lends rooms to the local church as a charity so that they have a proper meeting place.

For about a year, María Guadalupe has been selling clothes. She sells women's, men's, and children's clothes in all sizes and prices. She would like to expand her business a little bit by buying more clothes and perfume to sell. Her goal is to grow the business and to help her family become more financially stable with the aid of this loan. Her husband works but he doesn’t earn enough the support the family.

María prays to God that everything will turn out well for her family and believes that this loan will be a good investment for the betterment of the lives of her family members.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Bouch, Kiva Fellow

María Guadalupe Jiménez O. es una señora casada vive en Villa Lobos Guatemala tiene 3 hijos mayores de edad, la casa en donde vive es propia y presta un local para reuniones de la iglesia es una obra de caridad de doña María Guadalupe. María Guadalupe tiene 1 año de vender ropa de damas, caballeros y niños diferentes tallas y precios solo que ella desea ampliar un poco mas su negocio comprando ropa y algunos perfumes para vender. Su meta es crecer en su negocio de la venta de ropa con la ayuda del crédito que se le dará ella podrá crecer como comerciante y estará mejor económicamente su familia ya que su esposo trabaja pero no alcanza para sustentar a su familia, María espera en Dios que todo le salga bien y que este crédito sea para un buen beneficio en la vida de su familia.

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Hugo

texts.es:
El Sr. Hugo S. tiene 28 años de edad y es soltero.
 
Don Hugo tiene un negocio de investigacion.  El investiga todos temas de Paraguay y vende la informacion a varias empresas.  Comenzó con este negocio como estudiante, aproximadamente en el año 2005; desde ese momento el fue comprando poco a poco para sus comodidades ya sea escritorio, estante para sus libros, y en la actualidad el esta trabajando con varias universidades privadas ofreciendo sus servicios de investigación.

El Sr. Hugo  invertiría este crédito para comprar máquinas (computadoras), para que asi pueda ofrecer un servivio completo a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mr. Hugo S. is 28 years old and single. Hugo has a business as a researcher. He researches all kinds of Paraguayan topics and sells the information to various businesses. He began this business as a student, approximately in 2005; since then he has little by little been buying the things he needs such as a desk, bookshelf, and today he is working with several private universities offering his research services. Hugo will invest this loan in buying computers so that he can offer a full range of services to his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy computers

loans.name: Mariela

texts.es:
La Sra. Mariela P. 34 años de edad y esta casada con el Sr. Leonardo Mareco de 52 años de edad. Ellos tienen 1 hijo de 4 años.

Doña Mariela comenzó con este negocio con el capital adquirido por la venta de un automovil, aproximadamente en el año 2003. Ella se compro varias máquinas de coser y telas con la que desidió emprender su propio taller de costuras, en la actualidad tiene varias personas que trabaja con ella y una gran clientela ya formada.

La Sra. Mariela invertiría este crédito para comprar más mercaderías, y asi poder satisfacer las demandas de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mariela Portillos is 34 years old and married to 52 year old Mr. Leonardo Mareco. They have one 4 year old son. Mariela began this business with the capital she acquired by selling a car back in 2003. She bought various sewing machines and fabric with which she decided to open her own seamstress shop. Today she has various people that work with her and a well established clientele. Mariela will invest this loan in buying more merchandise and in this way be able to meet the demands of her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabric

loans.name: Lumiere Celeste Group

texts.en:
The “Lumiere Celeste” or “Heavenly Light” Group is a made of twenty-five male and female entrepreneurs. After successfully repaying their 1st and 2nd loans, they are looking forward to continued success and growth in their businesses with this loan.

Their businesses are very diverse. They range from selling and repairing motorcycles to a bakery and many others in between.

J. J. is the representative of the group. This hard-working young man sells motorcycles. He buys the motorcycles in the Dominican Republic to re-sell in Haiti. He sells in various locations depending on the customer and has an ever-growing client base in multiple cities across northern Haiti. He has one person who works with him who repairs motorcycles as well.

J. is grateful for the increased profits from his business because they have allowed him to purchase chickens and goats, and help family members when they’re ill. He dreams of expanding the business to employ multiple people and earn enough to build a house and eventually get married.

On behalf of J., Lumiere Celeste, and Esperanza we thank you for your support!

loans.use: Motorcycle parts, tools, appropriate oils

loans.name: Alejandrina

texts.es: Alejandrina tiene 58 años, vive en su casa propia con sus 2 hijos y 2 nietos. Se dedica al tejido a mano D. prendas, utiliza los palitos a crochet y también los comunes, actividad que realiza en su misma casa con la ayuda D. uno D. sus hijos. Su afición a los tejidos comenzó hace 25 años, cuando empezó a laborar en una fábrica D. chompas, que fue como una escuela D. aprendizaje. DesD. entonces, empezó a tejer D. manera independiente, aplicando bellos puntos en sus tejidos, tiene un catalogo D. modelos que siempre muestra a sus clientes que le garantizan un retorno seguro. También produce en cantidades necesarias para vender a comerciantes D. su confianza y por la velocidad que ha adquirido, pueD. llegar a producir hasta 10 chompas por mes. Es la segunda vez que Alejandrina viene solicitando un préstamo a MFP, está muy animada D. continuar un trabajo solidario en su banco comunal, ya que es D. su agrado y renueva una vez más su compromiso D. seguir demostrando puntualidad. El dinero requerido es para la reparación D. su máquina D. tejer y la compra D. lana al por mayor, en grandes cantidades.
texts.en:
Alejandrina is 58 years old, lives in her own home with her two children and two grand-children. She, with the help of one of her children, knits clothing using traditional knitting needles an activity she undertakes at home. Her love of knitting began 25 years ago when she began work in a sweater factory which was like an apprenticeship for her. Since then, she began to knit independently, applying beautiful touches to her work. She has a catalogue of her designs which she always shows to prospective customers thereby guaranteeing a sure return. She also sells to retailers she has gotten to know and, because she has become a fast knitter, can complete up to 10 sweaters per month. This is the second time that Alejandrina has asked for a loan from MFP. She is very eager to continue working with her communal bank since it pleases her and renews her commitment to punctual repayments. Her loan will be used to repair her knitting machine and to buy wool at wholesale.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To repair her knitting machine.

loans.name: Brenda Janeth

texts.es: La señora Brenda Janeth V. es madre soltera y tiene bajo su responsabilidad a dos pequeños hijo y ambos viven en una casa rentada. El costo de la renta se ha incrementado y cada vez mas y es difícil para ella cubrir ese gasto. Por tal  motivo está tramitando un préstamo para obtener su propia casa mediante un crédito Gubernamental. Sin embargo el valor de la vivienda es mayor que el crédito que puede recibir ya que su sueldo es bajo. Por ello está solicitando un préstamo para completar el valor de la vivienda y obtener así la casa que necesitan ella y sus hijos para un patrimonio seguro.
texts.en:
Mrs. Brenda Janeth V. is a single mother, responsible for two small children, who rents her home. Rent continues to increase making it progressively more difficult to pay. She is negotiating a government loan to buy her own home but the value of the home is higher than the maximum loan she qualifies for due to her low salary. She is, therefore, asking for a loan to pay the difference so that she and her children can begin to build their own equity.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay the difference between a government loan and the price of her own house.

loans.name: Francisco José

texts.es:
El señor Francisco José R. es padre de familia y quiere lo mejor para sus hijos. 
A la vivienda de don Francisco le está haciendo falta un cuarto más pero no cuenta con el dinero necesario para llevar acabo está mejor. 
Portal motivo solicita un préstamo para poder realizar la construcción del cuarto que quiere para sus hijos que ya son adolescentes y quieren su propio espacio en la casa.
texts.en:
Mr. Francisco Jose R. is a head of household who wants the best for his children. His home currently lacks an additional bedroom but he needs funds to build it. He is asking for a loan to build this needed room so that his sons, who are now teenagers, can have their own space in the house.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To add a room to the front of his house.

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.es: La señora Magdalena R. es madre soltera y  es una mujer emprendedora ya que actual mente tiene un negocio de papelería y renta de computadoras esté es el ingreso de su familia. Actual mente es nuevo negocio le hace falta mas equipo y mercancía  es por eso que esta solicitando nueva mente su cooperación para poder llevar acabo está inversión.
texts.en:
Mrs. Magdalena Rodriguez is an enterprising single mother who supports her family with a stationer's store where she also rents computers. Her business needs more equipment and inventory so she is again asking for help in order to increase her investment.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase computer equipment.

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en:
Benedicta M. manages a small rice farm. She is 55 years old and has 8 children who are still attending school. She is married to a farmer named Maximo M.. Her life is in the farm and she believes that they have a bright future in growing rice. Like other wives, Benedicta helps her husband on the farm. She also started running a new sari-sari store business to supplement their income.

She now wants a loan of Php 12,000 from CEVI. She will use a loan to buy fertilizers and herbicides. The loan will help her family achieve a bigger yield. The loan will also help her get started in the new business.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people, especially the poor, to start and have their own business. They provide not only credit but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and herbicides

loans.name: Epifanio

texts.es: A la vivienda del señor Epifanio M. le está haciendo falta las protecciones en ventanas y puertas pero en esté momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para llevar acabo la mejora. Esta solicitando un préstamo para poder pagarle a la persona que se encargara de realizar y colocar las protecciones en la vivienda. Y así estará mas segura cuando el estén en su trabajo.
texts.en:
Mr. Epifanio Martinez's home lacks safety devices on its windows and doors but he is currently in need of financial help in order to install them. He is asking for a loan to pay the person who will install such devices on his home thereby keeping it safe while he is at work.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To install safety devices on his home.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
" Ever since I was just a 10-year-old kid, I already knew the proper way to farm rice," says Luzviminda C.. "My parents are farmers, they taught me everything about planting rice, removing weeds and harvesting a lot in our farm," she added. Luzviminda is 44 years old and has 8 children. Some of her children quit school to help them in managing their farm. Her husband, Eduardo C., is not happy about that, that is why they work harder now, to support their children, especially the ones in schools.

Luzviminda is asking for a loan of Php 12,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer, herbicide and pesticide for her farm. The loan will truly help her grow her harvest to support her family better.

CEVI is a non-profit organization and a partner of WorldVision Philippines. CEVI helps people, especially the poor, to start and run their own business. CEVI reaches out to more people so that they can have their own livelihood. CEVI provides not only credit but training and insurance coverage to all their clients.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda is residing in the peaceful yet rocky village of San Lorenzo, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 46 years old and married to Orlando, a farmer. The couple is blessed with three children: Danny Boy, the eldest is 24 years old and a graduating college student with a course in Agriculture; Rommel, 21 years old, a college undergraduate, and Lailanie, 18 years old, a graduating high school student. Rosalinda shares that her family perseveres together to have a progressive life.

Rosalinda has been managing a piggery business for seven years already. The business is quite good and really of great help to her family. Thus, to further improve her business, Rosalinda is hoping to access a loan amounting to PHP 6,000 that will serve as additional business capital. She plans to use her loan to buy additional piglets. She also aims to have an increase in income so she can help her husband in providing the daily needs of her family and pay for the education of their youngest child. She hopes that the lenders will assist them in the business.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou has been a vendor of snacks and vegetables in their village for one year. But aside from vending, she is also engaged in hog-raising to assist her husband in providing for the needs of their family. She is now requesting a loan of PHP 6,000 that she will use to expand her snack-vending of barbecue and other easy-to-prepare snacks. She is hoping that someday she can become successful in her chosen enterprise and continue to send her children to school. She hopes that someday her children will finish their studies through their sacrifices.

Marilou is 49 years old and married to Orlando who manages their small farm. They are blessed with five children: the eldest is Vanessa, 22 years old, a high school graduate. Second is Krislene, 18 years old, a high school student; Kristle, 16 years old, second-year high school; Jeristy, 14 years old, an elementary student, and the youngest is Algie, 3 years old. Three of their children pursue their education despite their age. They believe age does not matter if you want a better life.

loans.use: Business Expansion

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel is married to Macario R.. He works as a rice and corn classifier for a buyer. She is forty-two years old and engaged in the hog-raising business. She wants to take out a loan of $125 to maintain her business. She will utilize the loan to buy a bag of feed for her hogs. She hopes that somehow she will able to expand into other businesses such as vending in order to generate more income to support her family.

The couple has four children: Nowee - twenty-three years old; Michael - twenty years old; Maricris - seventeen years old, now in his fourth year of high school, and their youngest, Macario - twelve years old, a mentally disabled child. Maribel's family lives in a harmonious relationship in their rural area of Minanga Proper in Angadanan, Isablea.

loans.use: Feed for her hogs

loans.name: Hermie

texts.en:
“There is a positive side to every situation if we simply make the choice to find it," says Hermie, who is twenty-five years old, single and a man with simple dreams.  He is still living with his parents and his two siblings are also working.

Hermie is getting married soon.  This is the reason why he is working hard to make sure that he can provide a stable life for his future family.  He owns a community-based variety store in their village and at the same time works as a tricycle operator.  

His loan request of $175 will be used to buy more stock for his store and for the maintenance of his tricycle, so they will have a stable source of income.

loans.use: To buy more stock and tricycle maintenance

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita is the mother of three children and the wife of Benjamin A..  They are both farmers and work hard for the welfare of their family.  Her family lives simply in the village of Barangay San Lorenzo, Ilagan, Isabela. Her children are Geraldin, twenty-four years old, a college graduate and presently working in DSWD (Department of Social Welfare and Development), Gerlyn, twenty-one years old, also a college graduate, and the youngest is Harron, 19 years old and a high school student.  Pacita is thankful that through their hard work and patience, they are able to eat three times a day and send their children to school.  She prays that their youngest will also finish his college education.  

Pacita manages a small store beside their house.  She has been in this business for ten years and it really helps her family a lot.  She wants her business to become more progressive and with this, she would like to take out a loan of $75 that she needs to purchase different grocery items for her store.  Her goal is to expand her business so she can generate more income, because her income of $7.50 a week is not enough to meet the needs of her family.  Pacita is hoping that her loan will be granted for the development of her business.

loans.use: To purchase different commodities

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta D. is fifty-one years old and vending was her chosen business.  This has been the main source of income for the family.  Since her income is not enough to provide all the needs of her children, there came a time when she needed to look for financial assistance to support the education of her children.  

She was glad when she learned about the Kiva lenders and she gained hope that she can borrow additional capital for her business.   She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $125 that she will use for her vending business.  Violeta is also planning to start in the hog raising business if she ever has extra money.  She dreams that her younger children will finish their studies and have a better job in the future.  

She has seven children: Rosemarie, thirty-one years old and a high school graduate; Rodel, twenty-nine years old and a high school undergraduate; Romalyn, twenty-three years old and in college; Rosel, twenty-one years old and a nursing student; Roby-Ann, eighteen years old and a high school graduate; Jenny Mae, seventeen years old and a high school student; and Richelle, the youngest, is twelve years old and presently in elementary school.  Most of her children were not able to pursue their studies further due to their poor living situation.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Mylene

texts.en:
Mylene chose hog raising as her business.  She is thirty-four years old and married to Marlon, who works as a farmer in their simple village at Barangay San Lorenzo, Isabela. They have two children: Aicytel, twelve years old and a high school student, and Archie Jay, five years old.  Mylene is thankful to God because they are able to maintain their good bonding and a harmonious relationship. 

Her need of financial support leads her to request a loan of $100 that will serve as additional capital for her business.  She plans to use the loan to purchase a feed supply and a piglet that she will sell after three to four months.  She dreams that through their sacrifices, their children can finish their studies in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a feed supply and a piglet

loans.name: Ni Nyoman Dewi

texts.id: Setelah dua kali mengikuti program pinjaman ternak babi di Dinari, Ni nyoman Dewi ingin mengikuti kembali program ini untuk tahap yang ketiga. Di periode kedua yang sudah berlalu,  Nyoman Dewi memelihara 3 ekor penggemukan. Walaupun kandangnya hanya terbuat dari bambu, tidak mematahkan semangat Nyoman Dewi untuk memelihara babi. Karena dari 3 ekor babi itu, Ni Nyoman Dewi akan mendapatkan keuntungan sebesar Rp. 1.200.000.- / 6 bulan atau Rp. 200.000.- / bulan. Di pinjaman tahap ketiga ini, Ni Nyoman Dewi merencanakan untuk menambah babi peliharaannya. Agar nantinya keuntungan yang diperoleh semakin besar.
texts.en:
Ni Nyoman Dewi participated in Dinari pig farming loan program twice in the past. Now she is planning to participate for the 3rd terms.

In her last 2nd term, she raised 3 piglets. She can earn a net profit of USD 110 for a 6 month period. In this 3rd term, she wants to raise more pigs so she can get higher profit.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy piglets

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
“Stronger belief means weaker worries,” was the inspirational quotation that Teresita used to recall in times of difficulty and trouble in life.  She and her family live in the simple rural village of Minanga Proper, Angadanan, Isabela. She is 46 years old and married to Domingo, a farmer. They are blessed with five children: Joy, 26; Joel, 22; Jacinto, 17; Jaces, 13 and in his first year of high school; and Hannah, 10, in the fourth grade.

Teresita has been a vegetable vendor for almost ten years. She and her husband are working hard for the education of their two younger children.  In a week, Teresita earns an average net income of PHP 1,000, which she budgets for their basic needs and for their children.

Due to lack of business capital, Teresita is requesting a PHP 6,000.00 loan from the lenders. She will use it to buy different vegetables that she can sell. She believes that having a strong faith in God will lead her to a more fruitful life and a better future for her children.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables

loans.name: Florida

texts.en:
Florida is 39 years old and married to Jorge, a farmer.  They live in Barangay San Lorenzo in Ilagan, Isabela.  The couple is blessed with two children: Jaylord, an 11-year-old fifth-grader, and Jorge Jr., a 7-year-old elementary school student.  Florida says that her family enjoys their modest but happy living conditions and she is glad that they have a good relationship with each other.
 
Florida is a hog farmer.  She would like to borrow a loan amount of PHP 6,000.00 from lenders to develop her business.  She plans to use most of her loan to buy feed.  She believes that her business will continue to grow by being diligent and never losing hope.  She is hoping that her income will increase enough to save money so she can continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: To buy feed for her hogs

loans.name: Maxima

texts.en:
Maxima A. is a 50-year-old widow.  She lives in the simple village of Barangay Minanga Proper in Angadanan, Isabela.  She has two children: Judith, 31, and Raffy, 28. Her children are both married.  She lives with her youngest child.

Maxima has been a snack and vegetable vendor for almost 25 years. She strives to work hard to help her son in supporting their daily basic needs.  She is applying for a loan amounting to PHP 8,000.00, which she will use as capital for her vending business. Maxima hopes that through the financial support of the lenders, her business will improve to support her family.

loans.use: Business capital to improve her vending business

loans.name: Baby Irene

texts.en:
Baby Irene is 21 years old and married. Her husband Joey is a farmer and they are blessed with a ten month old son named Tee-Jay.

Baby Irene has been exposed to the vending business since she was young and this experience has led her to open her own store. She is proud that she is able to maintain her village store. She is hoping to become a successful entrepreneur someday. In order to do this, she would like to request a loan of PHP20,000 to expand her business.  This would be of great help for the welfare of her son and future children. Baby Irene always believes that “in life, what matters is not what you get, but what you shared”.

loans.use: Business Expansion

loans.name: Edmundo

texts.en:
"I started my business with a small farm. I till 1 hectare of land which I use to feed and clothe my family. Farming is very interesting work. It's really fulfilling when you see all your children able to attend classes in school because you can easily provide for their needs because you have a farm", says Edmundo M., a father of 9 children from Bunawan, Agusan del Sur.

Now, he is requesting a loan of PHP12,000 from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy fertilizers and other farming products for his farm. The loan will help him protect his rice from insects and achieve the desired harvest from his farm.

CEVI is reaching out to more farmers, especially the poor, to sustain their livelihood. They help people start and maintain their own business too. CEVI gives their clients credit, training, and insurance coverage to help their small businesses grow.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, herbicides and other farming products.

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio B., 33 years old, is a good father and husband, and is happily married to Angelica. They have two children: Isaac - 6 years old, grade one; and Iamron - 4 years old. They live in the simple village of Minanga Proper, a rural area where farming is the common source of income for the residents. 

Rogelio is a village store owner. Aside from his store, he has also been engaged in the business of raising hogs for almost a year, for extra income. His weekly income from his store is not enough to support the needs of his family and the education of his son. With this in mind, he is requesting a loan amount of PHP11,000 as additional capital.  This amount will be of great help in improving his business. He dreams that someday he can sustain all the needs of his family.

loans.use: Additional business capital

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa D. is engaged in the business of raising hogs. She is thankful that her husband is helping her in maintaining her business aside from managing their farm, which is also a source of income. Her need of additional capital leads her to request a loan of PHP4,000 that she will use to purchase a piglet. She promises to be more diligent and be more patient to make her business grow. Through her enterprise, Marissa is hoping that she can support the education of her children in school and hopefully finish college degrees. When this happens, she will be the proudest mother, says Marissa. 

Marissa is married to Warlito, who works as a farmer. She is 34 years old and lives peacefully and happily in the village of San Lorenzo, Ilagan, Isabela.  They have three children: Ana Mae - 14 years old, second year high school student; Warren - 12 years old, grade six; and Kaycee – 10 years old, grade five.

loans.use: To purchase a piglet

loans.name: Ni Ketut Sinten

texts.id: Setelah dua kali mengikuti program pinjaman ternak babi di Dinari, Ni Ketut Sinten kini melanjutkan pinjamannya ke tahap yang ketiga. Dari induk babi yang dipeliharanya saat ini, sudah melahirkan 8 ekor anak. Jika dijual dengan Harga Rp. 325.000.- / ekor Ni Ketut Sinten bisa memperoleh keuntungan bersih setelah di potong biaya pakan dan obat sebesar Rp. 800.000.- Keuntungan ini di pergunakan untuk biaya keperluan pendidikan anaknya dan biaya hidup sehari – hari. Ni Ketut Sinten berharap Kiva melalui Dinari dapat terus membantunya dalam hal permodalan. Sehingga usahanya dapat terus berjalan dan semakin meningkat.
texts.en:
Ni Ketut Sinten participated in Dinari pig farming loan program twice in the past. She is now participating for her 3rd term. The breeding pig that she has now has produced 8 piglets which can be sold for USD 29/ piglet. From this she can earn a net profit of USD 72 (after all deduction for pig feed and raising cost). She uses this money to fund her children eduction and their daily living cost.

She is hoping for Dinari to be able to assist her with further loan so she can expand her business.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy feeds

loans.name: Joylin

texts.en:
Joylin D. grows rice. She is 30 years old and has 2 children. School is quite expensive now. She started to worry about how she would be able to stretch their limited income. Her husband, Henry D., is also a farmer. They manage their small rice farm business together, to support their children's growing needs.

She is asking for a loan of PHP12,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy more fertilizers and pesticides for her farm. The loan will make her farm have a better yield. In that way, she believes, she has more support to give to her own family.

CEVI is reaching out to more farmers, especially the poor, to sustain their livelihood. CEVI gives their clients credit, training, and insurance coverage to help their small businesses grow.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers.

loans.name: Ni Putu Wartini

texts.id: Ni Putu Wartini sudah lama menekuni usaha ternak babi. Kini usahanya sudah semakin maju dan berkembang. Walaupun kandang babi yang dimilikinya terbuat dari bambu hanya alasnya saja yang disemen, Ni Putu Wartini tidak mengeluh. Dari 2 ekor  induk babi yang dipeliharanya, Ni Putu Wartini mendapatkan keuntungan dalam enam bulan mencapai Rp 1.500.000.- Keuntungan ini  didapat dari penjualan bibit babi. Dalam setiap bulannya Ni Putu Wartini harus menyisihkan uang untuk biaya pemberian pakan ternaknya sekitar Rp.150.000,- Dari penghasilan induk babi ini, dirasa kurang mencukupi untuk biaya hidupnya. Karena itu, dalam pinjman ketiga ini Wartini akan menggunakan uang pinjaman tersebut untuk membeli bibit babi dan pakan ternak untuk babi peliharaannya.
texts.en:
Ni Putu Wartini has been in the business of pig farming for quite a while. Her business is keep on growing even though she only raising her pigs inside a bamboo hut. From her 2 breeding pigs, she can earn a net profit of USD 135. She has to set aside USD 13.5/ month for the cost of pig feed.

Even so, she feels that her income is still not enough to secure her family's economy. Therefore she is hoping by participating for the 3rd time in Dinari pig farming loan program, she will be able to grow her business more.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy feeds

loans.name: Jeanilyn

texts.en:
Jeanilyn S. is managing a small parcel of land. She grows rice to feed and clothe her family. She is 32 years old and has 3 small children. She is looking for possible ways to help her husband, Ronilo S., sustain their farm business. Farming is their only source of income. They want to make their farm prosper to meet the needs of their family.

Jeanilyn is requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides. Fertilizers will help enrich the soil while the pesticides will prevent harmful insects from inflicting damage and disease on her rice. The loan will definitely help her achieve a better harvest for her whole family.

CEVI is a non-profit organization and a partner of WorldVision Philippines. CEVI helps people, especially the poor, to start up and own their own businesses. CEVI is reaching out to more farmers like Jeanilyn to help sustain their livelihood. They provide not only credit assistance, but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Ni Komang Ayu Sumber Astiti

texts.id: Di pinjaman periode ke dua,  Komang Ayu Sumber Astiti memelihara 4 ekor babi penggemukan. 2 ekor babi jenis crossing dan 2 ekor lagi jenis babi lokal Bali. Biaya per hari yang diperlukan untuk pakan adalah Rp.15.000.- Pemeliharaan, pembersihan kandang dan pemberian pakan dilakukan dua kali dalam sehari. Dari hasil usaha ini Komang Ayu mendapatkan keuntungan Rp. 1.000.000.- dalam tiga bulan. Dengan keuntungan yang diperoleh tersebut, Komang Ayu bisa  membantu suaminya, I Made Sugita,  untuk menghidupi 3 orang anaknya yang masih sekolah. Mereka tinggal bersama dirumah yang mereka bangun sendiri, walaupun sangat sederhana.
texts.en:
In her 2nd loan term, Komang Ayu Sumber Astiti raises 4 piglets, 2 crossing type piglets and 2 Balinese local piglets. She spends USD 1.35/ day for the pig feed. She cleans the hut and gives the pig feed twice a day.

From this business she can earn a net profit of USD 90 for a 3 month period. WIth this she can help her husband and also to send their 3 children to school.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy piglets

loans.name: Solina

texts.en: Solina N., a 66-year-old mother of four, resides in the beautiful town of Hamtic, the first town of the province of Antique, Philippines.  Her husband is a farmer and a carpenter. The family has experienced different forms of poverty; however, they've always tried their best to survive. Mrs. N. has been able to send one of her children to college, who is now employed and helps support the family. She joined Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.(ASHI) last year to obtain capital for raising pigs.Mrs. N. has applied for this loan to buy clothing for a retail business to be managed by her daughter-in-law and to buy another pig and goat for her to maintain her previous business. She plans to save money in order to rent a stall in the market. She hopes that in the future she and her daughter-in-law can expand their businesses.

loans.use: To replenish livestock and buy clothing for retail.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa R. is engaged in rice farming. She is forty years old and has six children. When she is not busy on her farm, she sells food. This is how she supplements their income while waiting for their next harvest to come. She is married to a farmer, Abner Rodeco, and they started tilling their land in 1987. Farming is their life and they hope that someday it will be more profitable.

She is requesting a loan of $250 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides. Fertilizers will aid the fertility of the soil, and the pesticides will protect her plants from damaging insects and pests.The loan will truly help them have a bigger harvest.

CEVI is reaching out to more farmers to sustain their livelihood. CEVI helps people start up and maintain their own business. They also provide credit, training and insurance coverage to all their clients.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Norma

texts.en: Norma B. is forty-three, married, and the mother of three.  She lives in Hamtic, at the south end of beautiful Antique Province, where farming and fishing are the backbone of the economy.  Two of her children are in primary school, and one is in high school.  Her husband is a fisherman.  Norma plans to use the money from this loan to buy new nets, rope, and line for her husband's fishing boat, and will use the remaining balance as working capital for her business of buying and selling fish.  One day, Norma hopes she and her husband can buy a long line fishing boat so they will be able to earn more money. She wants to be able to send all of her children to college.

loans.use: To buy nets, rope and line for fishing, and for capital to buy and sell fish.

loans.name: Loimata

texts.en: Loimata I. is twenty-eight years old and married with three children.  She has five years of experience in building thatched roof beach houses (Samoan beach fale). She sells to the public and tourists seven days a week. She has five previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be $73.  SPBD loans are Loimata’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: To buy building materials and pay school fees.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en: Jean V. lives in San Jose, the capital of beautiful Antique Province on the island of Panay.  She is married and has a four-year-old daughter.  Her husband, Roland, is a seaman.  Jean has been running a sari-sari store for about five years.   "Sari-sari" is Tagalog for "various kinds" and the shops sell an array of basic foodstuffs, beverages, and everyday commodities.  The stores are usually operated out of the owner's home, and retail items in small units -- selling single cigarettes, for example.  Sari sari shops fill an important economic and social niche in Filipino life, especially in poor or rural areas.  Jean plans to use the money from this loan to buy beverages, food, and other items for resale in her store.  She hopes to be able to grow her business and enlarge her store, and dreams of being able to send her daughter to college one day.

loans.use: To buy inventory for a small grocery store.

loans.name: Sina

texts.en: Sina K. is forty-five years old and married with five children.  She has two years of experience in a popcorn and ice cake business. She sells to the villagers seven days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be about $75.  SPBD loans are Sina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Part of her loan will be used for home improvement

loans.use: To purchase supplies for her business and materials for home improvement.

loans.name: Foloi

texts.en: Foloi M., 44, is married with 4 children.  She has 6 years of experience in the retail business. She sells to the general public and villagers, 7 days per week.  She has  no previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 229 Tala (~ $75 US).  SPBD loans are Foloi’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase boxes of mutton flaps, sausages, chicken, boxes of chicken noodles, sacks of sugar, rice, flour, salt, beverages, Vailima beer, herrings, laundry soap, toilet paper, Mortein bug spray, candles, spaghetti, and snacks such as bongos, lollies, twisties, cookies, Chinese lollies, and chocolates, etc.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en: Nenita S. is a 54-year-old mother of four. She lives in a beautiful village in the town of Hamtic, Antique, Philippines, where most people earn their livelihood through fishing and farming. Nenita is new in town, because she lived in her own city before she decided to permanently settle here in Hamtic. She started her variety store to serve her neighbors with an initial capital of Php 3,000. The income earned from her business was used to finance her children's education. She applied for this loan to buy food and beverages to maintain her variety store. She hopes that in the future, she could establish a bigger grocery, and she hopes to send her other children to a university.

loans.use: To buy food and beverages for variety store.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria T., 31, is married with 4 children. She has 5 years of experience in the fishing and plantation businesses. She sells to the general public 5 days per week. She has had 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 187 Tala. SPBD loans are Vitoria’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase a new fishing net, spears, goggles, a new boat, gromozones, weedkiller, and bushknives.

loans.name: Alaifue

texts.en: Alaifue I. is thirty-six years old and married with five children.  She has four years of experience in a taxi service business. She serves the general public seven days a week. She has three previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be about $75.  SPBD loans are Alaifue’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase tires, taxi license registration fee, seat cover, air freshener, vacuum and carpet freshener.

loans.name: Ravshan

texts.ru: Равшан Жалилов 1975 года рождения женат имеет 2 детей. Он закончил школу и сразу пошел работать мастером ремонтных работ. Он помогал дяде ремонтировать квартиры и дома. Но работа оказалась немного тяжелой и он также начал заниматься откормом скота. Он получает кредит для покупки скота. Его жена ухаживает за скотом, полученное молоко продает, от этого и есть маленький доход. Равшан и его жена планируют расширить коровник и  прикупить еще несколько коров . Они откормят и продадут быстрее, если дадут высокую плату.
texts.en:
Ravshan J. was born in 1975, he is married and has two children. He finished school and started working as a repairman. He was helping his uncle to repair apartments and houses. But this job turned out to be a little too hard and he then started a business raising cattle. He takes out a loan to buy cattle. His wife watches after the livestock and sells the milk from which she makes small income. Rashvan and his wife plan to expand the cow house and buy a few more cows. They will feed them and sell faster if the get a higher price.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Balbina

texts.en: Balbina A. is a sixty-nine-year-old mother of four. Her husband is a farmer and a fisherman. The family resides in a beautiful village in front of Cuyo East Pass facing the South China Sea, on the island of Panay, Philippines. She buys and resells fish and vegetables to support the needs of the family. She applied for this loan to buy farm supplies such as seed, fertilizer, and insecticides, and to get additional capital for fish vending. Balbina wants to purchase these items in advance so as to get a lower price, because when she buys during planting season the cost is much higher. She hopes that in the future she can save their harvest for their own consumption rather than sell the harvest to finance their next crop.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and insecticides for farm, and for capital for fish vending business.

loans.name: Agripina

texts.en: Agripina J. is seventy-two years old and a widowed mother of six.  Agripina plans to use the money from this loan to buy inventory for her sari-sari shop.  "Sari-sari" is Tagalog for "various kinds" and the shops sell an assortment of basic foodstuffs, beverages, and everyday commodities.  The shops are usually operated out of the owner's home, and retail in small units -- selling single cigarettes, for example.  Sari-sari shops fill an important economic and social niche in Filipino life, often functioning as neighborhood watering holes, especially in poor or rural areas.  Besides her sari-sari store, Agripina also earns income by fattening hogs and receives a small monthly sum from her husband's pension.  She hopes to make enough extra money from her two ventures to help pay for her grandchildren's education.

loans.use: To buy inventory for a small grocery store.

loans.name: Umedajon

texts.ru: Умедажон 1983 года рождения, она замужем имеет 2 детей. Она торгует в магазине 5 лет. Торгует она продуктом питания. В основном она продает консервы: соленые огурцы, зеленый горошек, майонезы и кофе разных сортов. Перед новым годом был хороший сбыт товара, потому что все готовились к новому году и к зимовке. Сейчас кроме тех товаров она будет продавать напитки, для этого она и получает кредит. В ее бизнесе помогают дети. Товар привозят поставщики и если есть лишние деньги заказывает своим соседям по магазину. Она благодарна КИВА за поддержку, благодаря которым  расширяет свой бизнес.
texts.en:
Umedajon was born in 1983, she is married and has two children. She has own store where she sells food products for five years. She mostly sells canned foods such as pickles, sweet peas, mayonnaise and different varieties coffee. Before the new year the sales were good and she sold a lot of inventory because everyone was preparing for the new year and the winter ahead. Right now besides those items she will also start selling soft drinks and she needs a loan for this. Her children are also helping with the business. The products are brought in by the suppliers and if she has extra money she also orders for the store neighbors. Umedajon is grateful to Kiva for the support thanks to which she is expanding her business.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy products to stock his business

loans.name: Ketwarrin

texts.en:
Ketwarrin L. manages a pig farm. He has 5 pigs and a sow. He wants to grow his business to help his parents and wife. He is 28 years old and does not have any children yet. His wife, Disel, is helping him in their pig business to save a little for their future children. He started his business using his own money of Php 6,000. His pig farm is situated 4 meters away from their house. He loves pigs because they remind him of his parents who are pig growers, themselves.

He is asking a loan of Php 7,000 with CEVI. He will use the loan to buy feed for the pigs. The loan will help him expand his pig farm and earn a bigger income.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people, especially the poor, to start and maintain their own business. CEVI is reaching out to entrepreneurs like Ketwarrin to help sustain their livelihood. CEVI provides credit assistance, training and insurance coverage to all their clients.

loans.use: To purchase feed for the pigs

loans.name: Samalaulu

texts.en: Samalaulu Falono is forty-three years old and married with six children.  She has five years of experience in the banana plantation business. She sells to the general public four days per week. She has two previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be about $50.  SPBD loans are Samalaulu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy pesticides, herbicides, fertilizer, a weedeater, plant sprayer and bushknives.

loans.name: Ana Ruth

texts.es: Ana Ruth H. D. V.  vive en el municipio D. Comasagua departamento La Libertad, con su familia que está compuesta por 3 hijos y su esposo. Ana Ruth posee un negocio en su casa, es una librería donD. venD. lapiceros, cuadernos, papel y también hace trabajo D. sacar copias, Ana cuenta con la ayuda D. sus hijos que después del colegio colaboran en el negocio D. su madre, Ana solicita un crédito para comprar mercadería.
texts.en:
Ana Ruth H. D. V. lives in the Comasagua municipality of La Libertad department, with her family who consists of 3 children and her husband. Ana Ruth has a business in her home, and her business is a bookstore where she sells pencil cases, notebooks, paper and also makes photocopies. Ana says that after school her own children help her with the business. Ana is seeking a loan to buy merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise for her store

loans.name: Viclar

texts.en:
Viclar T. owns a small variety store. She sells food and other commodities to earn an income for her family. She is thirty-two years old and has two children. She wants to earn money in order to pay tuition and other school fees. Her husband, Christopher T., is helping her in their small business. Viclar admitted that her store is the only thing that sustains their family now. She started her business from her small savings of $75 for their livelihood.

She needs additional capital in her business. She is requesting a loan of $100 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise to sell.

CEVI is reaching out to more entrepreneurs like Viclar to sustain their business. They not only provide credit, but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To buy inventory for her store

loans.name: Selesa

texts.en:
Selesa E. is a 37-year-old married woman with 5 children. She has 4 years of experience in the elei printing business. And she sells her goods to the public 5 days per week.

She has received one prior loan through SPBD, which she successfully repaid. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 187 Tala. Notably, SPBD loans are Selesa’s only access to capital because she is unable to qualify for loans from traditional banks. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional materials (e.g., fabric paints, brushes, elei printing boards, needles, and threads).

loans.name: Ana Mirian

texts.es: Ana Mirian L. D. A.. vive en San Salvador, su grupo familiar está compuesto por su esposo y dos hijos uno D. ellos aun es menor D. edad, tan solo tiene 10 años y estudia tercer grado, Ana se dedica a su negocio que lo tiene ubicado en el mercado D. San Jacinto, donD. venD. pollo. Ana es una mujer muy responsable ya ha obtenido anteriormente dos créditos con Integral con los cuales ha sido muy puntual en sus pagos y ahora solicita un nuevo crédito para compra D. mas pollo para su negocio para aumentará su margen D. ganancia.
texts.en:
Ana Mirian L. D. A. lives in San Salvador. Her family consists of her husband and two children, one of whom is a minor age 10 and in third graD.. Ana has a business located in the San Jacinto market where she sells chicken. Ana is a very responsible woman as she has had 2 previous loans with Integral which were repaid very punctually and now she seeks a new loan to buy more chickens for her business to increase her profit margin.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business

loans.name: Leonel Edgardo

texts.es: Leonel Edgardo C. vive en la Colonia santísima trinidad departamento San Salvador, Leonel tiene  30 años de edad, está acompañado  y tiene dos hijos, uno de ellos tiene  10 años y otro 5 años, ambos niños van a la escuela;  Leonel se dedica a su negocio que una venta de tortas, ubicado en un pequeño puesto que está rodeado por muchas oficinas donde los empleados salen a la hora del almuerzo y compran de sus tortas, Leonel cuenta con el apoyo de su compañera de vida que le ayuda en el negocio todos los días, Leonel solicita un crédito para la compra de materia prima como carnes, jamones, pan. De esta manera podrá incrementar sus ventas y por consiguientes sus ganancias, las cuales son el único ingreso con el que cuenta esta familia
texts.en:
Leonel Edgardo C. lives in the Santisima Trinidad neighborhood of San Salvador department. He is 30 years old, has a life partner and two children aged 10 and 5, both of whom go to school. Leonel sells tortas from a small stand which is in a business district where many employees come out at lunch time to buy tortas from him. His life companion helps him with this endeavor every day. Leonel is asking for a loan to buy raw materials such as meats, ham and bread so that he can increase his sales and therby his profits which are the sole source of income for the family.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase raw materials.

loans.name: Fuefue

texts.en:
Fuefue S. is a 27-year-old married woman with one child. She has 3 years of experience in the restaurant (barbecue) business. She explains that she operates her business six days per week.

She has received one previous loan from SPBD, which she successfully repaid. On average, her weekly net cash flow is approximately 145 Tala. SPBD loans are in fact Fuefue’s only access to capital because she cannot qualify for loans from traditional banks. She is now requesting a loan in order to purchase various ingredients and supplies (e.g., mutton, chicken, sausage, soy sauce, tomato sauce, onions, spoons, folks, knives, foil, and napkins). She thanks you for your support.
