loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional raw materials and supplies

loans.name: Taesali

texts.en:
Taesali E. is a 44-year-old married woman with four children. She has five years of experience in the agricultural industry. She sells her crops to the general public five days per week.

Notably, she has received three previous loans from SPBD, all of which she successfully repaid. On average, her weekly net cash flow is approximately 270 Tala. SPBD loans are Taesali’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for loans from traditional banks. She is seeking this particular loan to purchase various materials for her business, and a portion of the loan will be used to improve her family's home. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To expand her business and to improve her home by purchasing materials (e.g., barded wire, fertilizers, weed-eater, spades, and a wheelbarrow for the business, and timber, kitchen zinc and cement for the home).

loans.name: Ma. Theresa

texts.en:
Ma. Theresa S. is a 44 year old mother of five.  She wants to use some of her loan to buy a pig to raise.  She hopes that in the future, she can save money to send all of her children to a university.

Her five year membership in ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.) has impacted her life and her family. Her income from her previous loans was used to finance the education of her children; two in elementary, two in secondary and one in college.  She applied for this loan to buy a brand new rickshaw and some spare parts for the maintenance of her older rickshaw, handled by her son Walter.  

Her husband is a rickshaw driver and a carpenter.  Her husband and son, Walter, are very supportive of her business.

loans.use: Buy a pig, new rickshaw and rickshaw parts.

loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.es: Rodolfo S. P. vive en la comunidad Buena Vista ubicado en el departamento de La Libertad tiene 49 años de edad, su grupo familiar lo compone su esposa , una hija y la mamá de su esposa que también vive junto con ellos , Rodolfo se dedica a su negocio que está ubicado dentro de su casa y  es un taller de fabricación de cortinas, esta pareja de esposos trabajan en conjunto mientras Rodolfo fabrica las cortinas, la esposa se va al mercado central de San Salvador a venderlas, Rodolfo solicita un crédito para la compra de materia en este caso tela, para poder ampliar su variedad en colores y diseños.
texts.en:
Rodolfo Sanchez Presentacion lives in the Buena Vista neighborhood in La Libertad department. He is 49 years old and his family consists of his wife, his daughter and his mother-in-law who lives with them. Rodolfo manufactures curtains, a commercial activity which he carries out from his own home. This couple work together in this enterprise: Rodolfo manufactures the curtains, his wife takes them to the San Salvador central market to sell them. Rodolfo is asking for a loan to buy fabric so that he can diversify and increase colors and designs of his products.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fabrics.

loans.name: Kambarali

texts.ru: Камбарали Ёкубов 1969 года рождения имеет 3 детей. Он закончил всего лишь 10 классов , в университет поступать денег не хватило. Он разводит дома коров. Разведением скота занимается около 15 лет. В бизнесе помогают жена и дети. Он хочет купить коров для откорма и продажи. На рынке скот держится очень дешево он хочет успеть купить , поэтому и получает кредит для покупки скота. Узнав о Микроинвесте и поддержки КИВА сразу же обратился к нам. Благодарен за поддержку и помощь другим.
texts.en:
Kambarali Y. was born in 1969 and has three children. He has completed only 10 years of school and he did not have enough money to go to a university. He keeps and raises cows. He has been in the animal husbandry business for fifteen years. His wife and children help him with the business. He wants to buy cows for feeding and resale. The cattle is cheap right now on the market so he wants to buy it on time and this is why he plans to get a loan. He found out about MicroInvest and Kiva's support and came here right away. He is very grateful for the support and help to others.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma V. owns a small sari-sari store business. She is 47 years old and has two loving children. Her husband, Alberto V. is a fisherman. They work very hard to pay for their children's educational needs. They want them to achieve the highest educational attainment, so when they get old they won't be like them and could find better jobs.

She is requesting a loan of Php 21,000 from CEVI. Emma will use the loan to buy additional merchandise in her store. Some of the loan will also be used to repair their small boat. In that way, her husband could continue catching fish for their family's needs.

CEVI is helps its clients sustain and grow their businesses. They also provided credit assistance, training and insurance coverage to support their businesses.

loans.use: Purchase additional stock.

loans.name: Siupolu

texts.en: Siupolu C., 36, is married with six children.  She has  three years of experience in the sewing business.  Siupolu sells to the public and members of her family six days per week.  She has no previous loans with SPBD.   Siupolu expects her weekly net cash flow to be 125 Tala.  SPBD loans are Siupolu’s only access to capital because she was not able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase sewing machine and supplies.

loans.name: Rosa Lidia

texts.es: Rosa Lidia M. P. vive en  Soyapango departamento San Salvador, vive junto a su esposo que es empleado en un taller de mecánica automotriz  e hijos de 6 y 7 años de edad que estudian. Rosa se dedica a la  producción de jugos y licuados, que son muy conocidos y preferidos en zona por sus precios muy bajos y de excelente calidad, Rosa solicita un crédito para compra de materiales para su negocio.
texts.en:
Rosa Lidia Martinez Panameno lives in Soyapango department San Salvador with her husband, who works at an auto repair shop, and their children, ages 6 and 7, who are students. Rosa sells fresh fruit juices and blended fruit drinks which are well-known and liked in her area due to their high quality and low price. Rosa is asking for a loan to purchase materials for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials for her business.

loans.name: Melea

texts.en: Melea P., 25, is married with one child.  She has two years of experience in the elei and printing businesses.  She sells to villagers and the general public five days per week.  She has one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 145 Tala.  SPBD loans are Melea’s only access to capital because she was not able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase materials, zippers, threads, needles, fabric paints, elei board for printing.

loans.name: Kosimjon

texts.ru: Косимжон  1952 года рождения женат имеет 3 детей. Образование среднее. Он торгует луком 10 лет. До зимы у него был хороший спрос, теперь с начало весны опять опять спрос повысился на лук.  осенью все люди запасались луком и другими  продуктами. Он был доволен прошлым сбытом своего товара. До сегодняшнего времени покупка была не важной. По его прогнозу скоро будет хороший спрос.В  прошлом году он получил свой первый кредит. И благодарен что существуют такие организации как КИВА и Микроинвест.
texts.en:
Kosimjon was born in 1952, he is married and has three children. He has secondary education. He has been selling onions for ten years. Before the winter the demand for his product was high and now with the beginning of the spring and demand has grown again. In the fall everyone has stocked up on the onions and other produce. Kosimjon was satisfied with the sold inventory. Right until this point the sales were not so good. According to his prognosis the demand will grow again. Last year he has received his very first loan. He is very grateful that organizations such as Kiva and MicroInvest exist.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To develop business

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia G. is a 51 year-old mother of three.  Her husband is a warehouse man in Manila, the capital of the Philippines.  Cecilia manages her business and her husband is far from the family.  She raised her three children; one in college, two have graduated, but only one is employed.  

Cecilia has been an active member of ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.) for eleven years.  Cecilia is also the treasurer of their village; Lapaz, Hamtic, Antique, island of Panay.   Her husband's income, plus her income from her job as treasurer is not enough to sustain the needs of the family.  

She applied for this loan to buy one unit of cellphones and pre-paid phone credits in order to save extra money to provide for the educational needs of her child.  She hopes that in the future, her children will land jobs and have a better living.

loans.use: Buy cellphone and pre-paid phone credit.

loans.name: Santiago

texts.es: Santiago H. vive en Soyapango departamento San Salvador, Santiago vive junto a su esposa, ambos se dedican al negocio que tienen montado dentro de su misma casa; el cual es una tienda, con diversos productos de consumo, Santiago ya ha tenido otros créditos en los cuales ha sido muy puntual en sus pagos, ahora solita un nuevo crédito para invertir en su tienda, en la compra de mas productos para ofrecer a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Santiago H. lives in Soyapango department San Salvador. He lives with his wife. Both of them tend to their general store which operates from their home. Santiago has had previous loans which he has repayed punctually. He now requests a new loan to invest in more inventory that he can offer his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase inventory for his store.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en: Teresa V. is a 57-year-old mother of eleven who lives in San Jose, the capital of beautiful Antique Province.  Her youngest child is still in primary school. Another child is in high school and one is attending college. The rest of her children are finished with school.  She and her husband farm rice.  Teresa plans to use the money from this loan to buy fertilizer for her rice crop and to purchase a water buffalo (called  "caribou" in the Philippines) to use as a work animal in the fields.  Teresa would like to be able to buy more farmland someday and hopes to be able to provide for the rest of her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and one water buffalo for use in farming rice.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en: Pauline A. F., 63, is married with 4 children.  She has 4 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public 7 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 83 Tala.  SPBD loans are Pauline’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Agricultural supplies

loans.name: Suitaitaifono

texts.en: Suitaitaifono F., 30, is married with 2 children.  She has 5 years of experience in the laundry business. She sells to the general public 7 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 208 Tala.  SPBD loans are Suitaitaifono’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To improve her laundry business

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam S., 42, is a villager from Pursat province, where he cultivates rice to earn a living. He puts in two rice crops per year on farmland inherited from his grandparents. Besides his farming business, he also has a job as a requirement worker. His wife works with him in the field as well as raising animals for sale. The family lives with one teenage child who is a student in the local public school.

Because farming is the family's most important source of income, they are looking for a loan in order to buy 3 water buffalo. This will help with the hard physical labor of plowing the fields and they can make additional income by hiring out to other farmers.

loans.use: To buy 3 water buffalo

loans.name: Rhodora

texts.en:
Rhodora G. is 49-year-old single mother of two.  She joined Kiva field partner ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.) eleven years ago to get capital to help fund her business selling fish.  She began selling fish about twenty years ago, at the time when she gave birth to her eldest child, a son.
Now Rhodora has second business venture, a sari-sari store.  "Sari-sari" is Tagalog for "various kinds" and the shops sell just that: an assortment of basic foodstuffs, beverages, and everyday commodities.
Rhodora applied for this loan to buy assorted goods as inventory for her shop.
As Rhodora has been an ASHI member for a long time, she got previous loans to help pay for her son's education.  He is now a Criminology course college graduate, and hopes to land a job in Manila so he can save money to pay for his board examination.  Rhodora wants to save more money for the education of her daughter, who is in secondary school. She hopes that in the future, her family will lift itself out of poverty.

loans.use: To buy assorted food for her variety store.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en: Marilyn F. G., 39, is married with four children. She has six years of experience in the housing rental business, which she works at seven days per week.  She is requesting her first loan from SPBD to purchase fixtures, paint supplies, lighting, tiles, new doors, etc. for her business. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala ($88 USD). An SPBD loan is Marilyn’s only access to capital because she is unable to qualify for a loan through traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase fixtures, paint, brushes, lighting, tiles, new doors for rental business

loans.name: Iokapeta

texts.en:
Iokapeta S., 34, is married with one child. She has been growing and selling vegetables for two years. She sells to the general public seven days per week. She is seeking a loan to purchase a wheelbarrow, vegetable seeds such as cabbage, tomato, cucumber, etc., fertilizer, weed eater, and gloves for weeding.

This is her first loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 125 Tala ($44 USD). An SPBD loan is Iokapeta’s only access to capital because she is unable to qualify for a loan through traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase a wheelbarrow, vegetable seeds, fertilizer, weed eater, and gloves for weeding.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Pen K. is 52 years old and a resident of Pursat Province. She currently sells Khmer cakes and raises a few pigs out of her home to make a daily revenue. Her husband Thean is 50; he helps with the responsibility of the family's expenses by making and selling charcoal. The old couple has five children; four of them are single and the other is married and lives independently. Pen K. is asking for a loan to buy a pair of buffalo to be used as transportation for her husband's business.

loans.use: To buy a pair of buffalo

loans.name: Edna

texts.en: Edna T., 41, is married with four children.  She has six years of experience in the retail business. She sells to the general public seven days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 187 Tala (~ USD).  SPBD loans are Edna’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase cigarettes, beverages, sacks of rice, flour, salt, sugar, milk, onions, toilet paper, twisties, lollies, ice cream etc.

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.en: Eufemia V. is a 52-year-old widowed mother of seven. Three of her children are still in primary school, two are in high school, one attends college, and one is a university graduate.  Eufemia lives in San Jose, the capital of beautiful Antique Province.  Much of the economy in Antique Province revolves around fishing and farming.  Eufemia sells fish from a stall at a public market, a business she inherited from her parents. She plans to use the proceeds of this loan as rolling capital for her fish-selling business.  Eufemia hopes that someday she'll be able to buy her own vehicle to transport fish back and forth. Her goal is to earn enough income to be able to put all her children through college.

loans.use: To buy fish for resale.

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en: Naomi L., 34, is married with two children.  She has three years of experience in the pancake and ice cake business. She sells to the villagers and general public for seven days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 125 Tala (~ USD).  SPBD loans are Naomi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase cordial, milk, sugar, flour, yeast, plastic cups and cooking oil.

loans.name: Aotoa

texts.en: Aotoa M., 50, is married with nine children.  She has seven years of experience in the Chinese cookies and pancake baking business. She sells to the public and villagers five days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 145 Tala (~ USD).  SPBD loans are Aotoa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase flour, sugar, cooking oil and a frying pan

loans.name: Dionesio

texts.en:
Dionesio R. is managing an RTW business. RTW or ready-to-wear business is common in their place. He is 38 years old and looks after the needs of his only child. His wife, Marcela R., is helping him in their business. He started his RTW store in 2000 and since then he was able to sustain his business. He wished to make it grow. 

He is asking for a loan of Php 18,000 from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy additional merchandise. He believes that displaying more items will attract more customers and definitely sales and income.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people, especially the poor, to start and have their own business. CEVI reached out to more people to have their own livelihood. CEVI gives not only credit to their clients but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Mafoe Sunana

texts.en: Mafoe Sunana S., 24, is married with four children.  She has two years of experience in the ice cake and piggery farm business. She sells to the villagers seven days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 62 Tala (~ USD).  SPBD loans are Mafoe Sunana’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase wire for fence, cement, sugar, cordial and foam cups.

loans.name: Chan Nary

texts.en:
Chan Nary U. lives in Pram Bey Mum village, in Takeo province.  She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice.  Aside from this plantation, she is a grocer who owns a small store.  Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. 

Thus, Chan Nary decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery products to expand her business.  She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan.  She is a 42 years old widow with three children, two of whom repair cars while the other attends the local school.

loans.use: Buy more grocery products to expand her business.

loans.name: Avatea

texts.en: Avatea F., 38, is married with one child.  She has three years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public three days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 145 Tala (~ USD).  SPBD loans are Avatea’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase weed killer, pesticides, bushknives, gromozones, plant sprayer and bard wire.

loans.name: Koeun

texts.en: Koeun S. is 39 years old and she lives in Trapaing Rompak village, in Takeo province.  She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice.  Her husband, Neang Oeun, is a construction worker.  They have five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others attend the local school.  Koeun is requesting a loan to purchase ten piglets to start a pig breeding business.  She will use the rest of money to buy pig food. Her husband is presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: Purchase ten piglets and pig food to start a breeding business.

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en: Dolores D. is 59 years old and lives in San Jose, the capital of beautiful Antique Province.  She is single, but is helping to support a nephew and niece. To earn money, Dolores runs a small "sari-sari" variety shop and raises pigs.  She operates both businesses out of her house -- the pigpen is at the back, and the store is at the front. "Sari-sari" is Tagalog for "various kinds" and the shops sell just that: an assortment of basic foodstuffs, beverages, and everyday commodities. The shops retail items in small units -- selling single cigarettes, for example.  Sari-sari shops fill an important economic and social niche in Filipino life, especially in poor or rural areas; they often have chairs or a bench out front and act as neighborhood watering holes.  Dolores plans to use the money from this loan to purchase beverages, food, and other items for her shop, and to buy five piglets to raise.  Dolores hopes to expand her variety shop in the future, and one day would like to have a "huge" piggery.  She wants to earn enough money to help pay for her niece and nephew's education, and dreams of being able to send them to college.

loans.use: To buy five piglets, and purchase inventory for a small "sari-sari" variety store.

loans.name: Tilomai

texts.en: Tilomai T., 42, is married with two children.  She has three years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public 5 days per week. She has successfully repaid a previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 145 Tala.  SPBD loans are Tilomai’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase  a water gallon for water storage, weed eater, plant sprayer, pesticides and gromozones.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria A. is managing a small sari-sari store in their place. She is 39 years old and has two children. She started her business from her small savings of Php 2,000. Until now, she was able to sustain her store and make a good profit for the whole family's needs. When she is not busy in her store, she sells fashion products like lipsticks, perfumes and shirts. She also knows how to do manicure and pedicure things and uses it as additional income.

She is asking for a loan of Php 20,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise and fashion items to sell. The loan will help her grow her business.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people start and have their own business. CEVI gives their clients not only credit but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise and fashion items to sell

loans.name: Chum

texts.en: A medium-size wooden house and a grocery store in Pursat Province belong to Mrs. Chum M.. She is 51, a widow, and currently lives with her one daughter who is a grocery seller. She also helps her daughter sell groceries and is the good grandmother who spends time caring for her two grandchildren; they are still young and enrolled in school. The whole family's expenses are met by M.'s daughter. M. has requested a loan of $800 for her daughter to buy more groceries to sell and to increase the size of the grocery store. (Mrs. M.'s daughter is pictured because she was not available.)

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Sophoan

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophoan T. is a farmer cultivating rice on a small piece of land that she owns in Thmor Keo Village in Takeo Province.  She is also a vegetable seller in the local market. Sophoan wants to expand her business since it is doing well, but she needs a reliable means by which to transport her vegetables to market. She is therefore requesting a loan to buy a motorbike for that purpose. 
	
Sophoan is a 29-year-old mother of two, both of whom are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport goods to market.

loans.name: Choy

texts.en:
Mr. Choy S., a 58-year-old farmer living in Ta Preas Village in Takeo Province, cultivates rice on a plot of land he owns. His wife, Mrs. Haum Phan, is a grocer.  Choy is requesting a loan to buy six piglets plus pig food and to build a piggery. He hopes to increase his income and improve his family’s living conditions with this loan. 

Choy is the father of four children, two of whom are employed while the others are attending the local school. His wife is presented in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy six piglets plus pig food and to  build a piggery.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 25-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa with his parents. Mohamad has owned a fish and trout shop for ten years. He requested a loan of 1500 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase food for his fish. This is the first time that Mohamad has requested a loan.

Mohamad is special in his work because he sells good quality fish. His clients are people from his region and tourists. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase food for his fish.

loans.name: Haidar

texts.en:
Haidar is a 24-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa with his parents. Haidar has owned a mini-market since 2001. He also sells fruits and vegetables. Haidar requested a loan of 1500 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop. This is the first time that Haidar has requested a loan.
Haidar is special in his work because he has a big variety of products. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his shop.

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en:
Thoeun U. lives in Ta Preas village, in Takeo province. She owns a small grocery business. Her husband, Kun Pouch, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. The couple also makes and sells rice wine.

Thoeun is applying for a loan to buy seven piglets and pig food for her breeding business. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions. Thoeun is 43 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are enrolled in the local school. The youngest one is too yoU. to work or study. Her husband is shown on the right of photo.

loans.use: Buy seven piglets and pig food for her breeding business.

loans.name: Aayda

texts.en:
Aayda is a 22-year-old woman who lives in the Bekaa with her parents. Aayda has been selling women's accessories since 2008. She also sells beauty products. Aayda requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise and beauty products. This is the first time that Aayda has requested a loan.
Aayda is speciA. in her work because she knows how to treat her clients and sells nice accessories. She decided on doing her business because she wanted to work. In the future, she plans on improving her business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and beauty products.

loans.name: Samir

texts.en: Samir is a 37-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa with his wife and their four children. Samir has been working as a van driver. He requested a loan of 700 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to do some maintenance work on his van. This is the first time that Samir has requested a loan. Samir decided on doing his business because he had to improve his family’s financiA. situation. In the future, he plans on improving his work.

loans.use: To do maintenance work on his van.

loans.name: Sakhorn

texts.en:
Sakhorn C. lives in Rolus village, in Takeo province. She is a duck breeder. Since her poultry business is going well, she wants to expand it but she does not have enough money. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase more ducks to add her poultry business. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan.

Her husband, Chan Eap, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Sakhorn is 39 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom stays at home to do housework while the others attend the local school. Her husband and a child are presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: Purchase more ducks to add her poultry business.

loans.name: Roula Group

texts.en:
The group name is Roula; it is made up of three ladies who are living in the region of the Bekaa, Lebanon. LayA. is a 27-year-old woman who has three children. LayA. has been working in chocolate design for five years. She requested a loan of 300 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase chocolate and designs. This is the first time that LayA. has requested a loan.
LayA. is speciA. in her work because she does it well. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she had difficulty working while taking care of her children. LayA. decided on doing her business because she wanted to work and supplement her family’s income, and she has experience in her work. In the future, she plans on improving her work. Doha is a 33-year-old woman. She has been working in chocolate design and she also sells flowers. Doha requested a loan of 300 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her businesses. This is the first time that Doha has requested a loan.
Doha is speciA. in her work because she likes what she does and she does it well. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she didn’t have the startup capitA.. Doha decided on doing her business because she has experience. In the future, she plans on expanding and improving her businesses. Roula is a 33-year-old married woman. She has been selling beauty products. Roula requested a loan of 300 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her work. This is the first time that Roula has requested a loan. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When Roula first started her business, she didn’t have the startup capitA.. She decided on doing her business because she wanted to have independent work. In the future, Roula plans on expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Rorn

texts.en:
Rorn M. lives in Trang village, in Takeo province.  She is a Bro Hok seller in the local market.  Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand.  She decided to request a loan to buy more Pro Hok to re-sell to earn more income to support her family. 

Her husband, Chan Young, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice.  Rorn is a 45 year old mother of three children who attend the local school.  Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: Buy more Pro Hok to re-sell.

loans.name: Al Hasnaa Group

texts.en:
The group name is A. Hasnaa; it is made up of three ladies who are living in the region of the Bekaa, Lebanon. 

EjmA. is a 34-year-old married woman. EjmA. has been working as a sewer for six years. She requested a loan of 300 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase thread for her work. This is the first time that EjmA. has requested a loan. EjmA. is speciA. in her work because she does it well. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she had financiA. issues. EjmA. decided on doing her business because she wanted to work and supplement her family’s income; also, she has experience in her work. In the future, she plans on improving her work. 

Houwayda is a 37-year-old woman who has three children. She has been selling clothes from her house. Houwayda requested a loan of 300 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her business. This is the first time that Houwayda has requested a loan. Houwayda is speciA. in her work because she likes what she does and she sells nice clothes. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she didn’t have the startup capitA.. Houwayda decided on doing her business because she has experience. In the future, she plans on improving her business. 

Iman is a 31-year-old married woman who has three children. She has been working as a hairdresser for five years. She also sells makeup. Iman requested a loan of 300 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her work. This is the first time that Iman has requested a loan. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When Iman first started her business, she didn’t have the startup capitA.. She decided on doing her business because of her experience. In the future, Iman plans on expanding her business. 


Please note that Houwayda couldn't be in the picture for personA. reasons.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Badegna Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Badegna (sont toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans ont en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles à Médine, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente   du bois de chauffe et des fruits et légumes.
Elles sont à leur cinquième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe) avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter 10  chargements de charrette en  bois de chauffe et  20 paniers de fruits et légumes.
Elles  s’approvisionnent à Sikasso ville et  dans ses localités environnantes généralement auprès des producteurs. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au marché et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes et d'hommes  au comptant. En détail et à crédit.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 17.000CFCA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Badegna group (all married) have an average age of 36 and on average 2 children. They live in traditional families in Médine, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They have various businesses, among others, selling firewood and fruit and vegetables. They are on their 5th solidarity loan (group loan) with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, so as to satisfy the needs of their clientele.

With this loan, they intend to buy 10 cartloads of firewood and 20 baskets of fruit and vegetables. They buy their merchandise in the town of Sikasso and its surroundings, generally from the producers. The merchandise is sold in the market and neighborhoods, to a clientele composed generally of women and men, for cash, retail, and for credit.

They each expect to make a profit of 17,000 F CFA per month, of which part will be used for family needs and the rest reinvested in the businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of firewood and fruit and vegetables for re-sale

loans.name: Ream

texts.en: Ream I. lives in Rolus village, in Takeo province.  She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice.  Her husband, Moeung Chan, is a duck seller in the district.  Since his business is doing well, he wants to expand it; thus, Ream decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks to transport to sell in the district.  She hopes to increase their income and improve their family's living conditions.  She is 30 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are attending the local school, while the youngest is too young to work or study.  Her husband is shown in the picture.

loans.use: Buy more ducks.

loans.name: Kamal

texts.en:
KamA. is a 44-year-old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with his wife and their three children. KamA. has owned a grocery store for a year. He requested a loan of 1500 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his store. This is the first time that KamA. has requested a loan.
KamA. is speciA. in his work because he knows how to treat his clients. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t have the startup capitA.. KamA. decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans on improving his store and starting a new business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Jamal

texts.en:
Jamal is a 31-year-old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Jamal has owned a butcher shop since 1994. He requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a refrigerator and a new machine for his shop. This is the first time that Jamal has requested a loan.
Jamal is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t have the startup capital. Jamal decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans on improving his shop and opening another butcher shop in a different region.

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator and a new machine for his shop.

loans.name: Jiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Jiguisseme (sont toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans, ont en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles à Médine un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région de la république du Mali).
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de tubercules et des fruits et légumes.
Elles sont à leur cinquième  prêt solidaire avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Tous les prêts précédents ont été remboursés sans difficulté.
 Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter, 8  chargements de charrettes en igname et  40 paniers de fruits et légumes. 
Elles   s’approvisionnent  auprès des producteurs à Sikasso ville et dans les villages environnants.  Les marchandises sont vendues au marché et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes et d'hommes  au comptant en détail et à crédit.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 17.000 FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Jiguisseme group (all married) have an average age of 36 and on average, 2 children. They live in traditional families in Médine, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They have various businesses, among others selling cocoyams and fruit and vegetables. They are on their 5th solidarity loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. All the preceding loans were reimbursed without difficulty.

With this loan they intend to buy 8 cartloads of cocoyams and 40 baskets of fruit and vegetables. They buy their produce from the farmers in the town of Sikasso and the surrounding villages. The merchandise is sold at the market and in various neighborhoods to a clientele composed generally of women and men, retail, for cash or credit.

They each expect to make a profit of 17,000 F CFA per month, of which part will be used for family needs and the rest reinvested into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fruit and vegetables and cocoyams

loans.name: Sarom

texts.en:
Sarom S. lives in Chi Chrab village, in Takeo province. She and her husband, Ouch Choek, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice and vegetables to earn a living. Ouch is a hard working man.

Although they try to work hard, they still earn less income than needed to support their family. Thus, Sarom decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to earn income. She is 30 years old and the mother of two children, one attends the local school while the other stays at home to do housework. Her husband is presented on the left of photo.

loans.use: Buy a cow for breeding to earn income.

loans.name: Ziad

texts.en:
Ziad is a 31-year-old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with his wife and their child. Ziad has owned an accessory shop since 1996. He requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop. This is the first time that Ziad has requested a loan.
Ziad is speciA. in his work because he knows how to treat his clients and sells beautiful accessories. His clients are his friends and neighbors. Ziad decided on doing his business because there isn’t any other accessory shop in his region. In the future, he plans on expanding his shop.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his shop.

loans.name: Khodor

texts.en:
Khodor is a 39-year-old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with his wife and their six children. Khodor has been working as a house painter since 1988. He requested a loan of 1500 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a car for his business. This is his second cycle and he has always paid on time.
Khodor is special in his work because he knows he does it well. His clients are people from his region. When he first started his business, he had difficulty building networking. Khodor decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans on improving and purchase a painting shop.

loans.use: To purchase a car for his business.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Toutes mariées, les  femmes du groupe Benkadi avec une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, ont en moyenne 2 enfants et  vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles à Sanoubougou I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative de la république du Mali). 
 Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente  de condiments alimentaires, des  vêtements pour enfants, des tissus, des pagnes wax et du sucre. 
Elles sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter 15 paquets de condiments alimentaires, 20  douzaines vêtements pour enfants, 20 pièces de pagnes  wax et 10 sacs de  50 kg de sucre. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de  Sikasso auprès des grossistes. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au comptant en détail et à crédit, au marché et dans les quartiers d’une façon ambulante à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 25.000CFCA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
All married, the women in the Benkadi group average 32 years of age and 2 children. They live in traditional families in Sanoubougou, one of the neighborhoods of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They run various businesses, such as selling food condiments, children clothing, fabrics, Wax pagnes (a brand of colorful African cloth), and sugar. They are seeking their first loan from Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso. They plan to use it to buy 15 packs of food condiments, 20 dozen children clothing, 20 pieces of Wax pagnes, and 10 sacks of 50 kg of sugar.

They get their supplies from wholesalers at the grand market in Sikasso. The women retail their goods for cash or on credit, at the market and as ambulant saleswomen in the area, to a clientele comprising mostly women. They foresee turning a monthly profit of XOF 25'000 (ca US$ 50 ) each, to be used in part to provide for their families. The remainder will be invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food condiments, children clothing, Wax pagnes, and sugar

loans.name: Maguie

texts.en:
Maguie is a 43-year-old woman who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with her husband and their three children. Maguie has been selling clothes for four years. Maguie requested a loan of 700 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise. This is the first time that Maguie has requested a loan.
Maguie is special in her work because she knows how to treat her clients. She decided on doing her business because she wanted to work. In the future, she plans on improving her business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Mona

texts.en:
Mona is a 56 year old woman who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with her husband and their eight children. Mona has been selling home accessories products for four years. She sells coffee cups, mugs, dishes and a lot of other products. Mona requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise. This is the first time that Mona has requested a loan. 
Mona is special in her work because she knows how to treat her clients. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. She decided on doing her business because she wanted to work and supplement her family’s income. In the future, she plans on improving by purchasing a shop.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Dembagnouman Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Dembagnouman (sont toutes mariées), avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies à Sanoubougou I   un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente  de  produits de beauté, de boissons, de fruits, de condiments etc.
Elles sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter 10 paquets de condiments alimentaires,  15 casiers de boissons et 10 cartons de produits de beauté.
Elles   s’approvisionnent  en générale au grand marché de Sikasso  auprès des grossistes et dans les villages environnants pour certains condiments auprès des paysans. Elles effectuent leurs ventes au marché et dans les quartiers d’une façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes , généralement  au comptant et en détail.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 15.000FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Dembagnouman group (all married), have an average age of 35 and on average, 3 children. They live in traditional extended families in Sanoubougou I, one of the neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).

They have various businesses, among others the sale of cosmetics, drinks, fruit, condiments, etc. They are on their first loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. With this loan, they intend to buy 10 packs of condiments, 15 crates of drinks, and 10 cartons of cosmetics.

They do their buying generally from wholesalers at the big market in Sikasso, and in the surrounding villages from the farmers, in so far as certain condiments are concerned. They sell at the market and in the neighborhoods, door-to-door, to a clientele composed of women and men, generally retail and for cash.

They each expect to make a profit of 15,000 F CFA per month, of which part will be used for needs of their families and the rest will be invested back into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Hala

texts.en:
Hala is a 46-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Hala owns an antiques shop. She requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her shop. This is the first time that Hala has requested a loan.
Hala is special in her work because she is the only shop in her region. She decided on doing her business because she wanted to open a shop and have independent work. In the future, she plans on improving her shop.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her shop.

loans.name: Yon

texts.en: Mr. Yon Y. is 48 years old and he lives in Rolus village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice and earn more income. His wife, Mrs. Chek Douch, is a duck breeder. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it but she does not have enough money. In order to solve this problem, Mr. Yon Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks for his wife’s business to earn more income to support his family. He has six children, three of whom stay at home to do housework and help the parents with their work while the others are attending the local school. His wife is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more ducks for his wife’s business to earn more income to support his family.

loans.name: Botros

texts.en:
Botros is a 42 year old man who lives in Beirut, the capitA. of Lebanon. Botros has owned a grocery store for two years. His clients are his friends and neighbors. He is requesting a loan of $1000 from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise, like ice cream, for his store.

This is his second cycle and he has always paid on time. His previous loan helped him diversify his merchandise and expand his stock. When Botros first started his business, he had financiA. issues. He decided on doing his business because he couldn’t find a job. In the future, he plans on improving his store.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Houayda

texts.en:
Houayda is a 41 year old woman who lives with her husband in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Houayda owns a clothing shop. She is requesting a loan of $1500 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a computer for her shop. This is the first time that Houayda has requested a loan.

Houayada is special in her work because she knows how to treat her clients and her shop is well positioned. Her clients are people from her region. In the future, she plans on expanding her shop by selling accessories.

loans.use: To purchase a computer for her shop.

loans.name: Samira

texts.en:
Samira is a 44 year old woman who lives with her husband and three children in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Samira owns a shoe shop. She is requesting a loan for $1000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for the summer. This is her second loan cycle and she has always paid on time.

Samira is special in her work because she knows how to treat her clients and has competitive prices. Her clients could be anyone. Samira decided to start this business because her husband has been working as a shoe repairer. In the future, she plans on expanding her shop.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for the summer.

loans.name: Bchara

texts.en:
Bchara is a 38-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the Lebanese capital, with his wife. He has been working in jewelry maintenance and cleaning for 25 years, and learned his business when he was a teenager. Bchara has a wide range of customers, and is successful in his work because of his experience and the high quality of his workmanship. He enjoys the challenge that his work presents.

Bchara requested a loan of $2000 USD from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase tools and a car for his work. This is the first time that Bchara has requested a loan.

loans.use: To purchase tools and a car for his work

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Sabali ont en moyenne  de 36 ans et 1 enfant. Toutes mariées, elles vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles à Sanoubougou un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles font essentiellement le commerce  de  condiments alimentaires, de fruits et de vêtements pour  enfants.. 
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur premier prêt de groupe.
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter, 4 paquets de condiments alimentaires,  10 chargements de charrette en fruits et 20 douzaines d’habits pour enfant.
Elles   s’approvisionnent à Sikasso ville et ses localités environnantes. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au marché et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 15.000FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour les besoins de la famille et  investir  dans les activités.
Les femmes du groupe sabali ambitionnent de pérenniser leur relation avec l’institution Soro Yiriwaso afin de pouvoir obtenir des montants importants.
texts.en:
The women of the Sabali group have an average age of 36 and on average, one child. They are all married and live in traditional families in Sanoubougou, one of the neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They essentially sell condiments, fruit, and clothing for children. So as to satisfy the needs of their clientele, they decided to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their first group loan.

With this loan, they expect to buy 4 packets of condiments, 10 wagonloads of fruit, and 20 dozen outfits for children. They do their buying in the town of Sikasso and surrounding locations. The merchandise is sold at the market and in the neighborhoods, to a clientele composed generally of women, and most sales are for cash.

They each expect to make a profit of 15,000 F CFA per month which will be used for the needs of the family and partially invested back into their businesses. The women of the Sabali group hope to continue their partnership with Soro Yiriwaso so as to take out loans for greater sums in future.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Zepure

texts.en:
Zepure is a 42-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, the Lebanese capital, with her husband and two children. She has owned a grocery store for six years. Zepure embarked on her grocery business because she wanted to supplement her family’s income. She was encouraged by her children, especially when she didn’t have start-up capital.

Zepure requested a loan of $2000 USD from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase merchandise for her store. This is her third loan cycle and she has always paid on time. Zepure's previous loans helped her to improve the store as well as her financial situation. In the future, Zepure plans on expanding her store.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her grocery store

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 35 years old and lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. He has owned a bakery for nine years, and went into this line of business as his father was a baker. Joseph makes 'saj' and 'mankoucheh' at the bakery. The saj bread is baked in a traditional Lebanese cooking dome/metal oven called a 'saj'. Mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza, and its most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat mankoucheh at any time of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning. Joseph is successful in his work because he is a good baker and is known for his excellent mankoucheh. His customers are his friends, neighbors and local people.

Joseph requested a loan of $2000 USD from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase merchandise for his bakery. This is his third loan cycle and he has always paid on time. In the future, he plans on expanding his bakery.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his bakery

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael O. Owuir is a soft-spoken married man and father of two children, both in school. His wife sells fish while Michael drives people around town on his motorbike, colloquially known as a piki-piki. They live in Yolanda slum.

Michael is asking for 10,000 K Sh. to help his wife expand her business so she can sell flour, sugar and salads. He said the challenges come when purchasing the goods, making sure food items have not already expired and making sure they are of high quality.

He would like to Kiva lenders to know that he himself was an orphan and that if profit allows, he will educate his children so they can lead a better life than they are living.

loans.use: To purchase food stock to sell

loans.name: Rosemary Onyango

texts.en:
Rosemary Onyango O. is a 31-year-old mother of four children, ages 14, 9, 4.5, and 4. All of her children are in school. She is married to an auto-mechanic and lives in Yolanda slum. She has owned her own motor-vehicle repair shop since 1998 and likes doing business in Kisumu because she was born here. Rosemary estimates that she sees around 15 drivers per day.  She is asking for 10,000 K Sh. to buy auto parts but is eager to pay off this loan and ask for a larger one. She will use most of the profits to pay for her children’s school fees. 

Rosemary recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: Auto Parts

loans.name: Saleh

texts.en:
Saleh, 51, lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Saleh has owned a faux bijoux shop for two years and is now requesting a loan of $1300 from A. Majmoua in order to purchase more merchandise for his shop. This is the first time that he has requested a loan.
	
His relationship with his clients, who are friends, neighbours and community members, and his regular diversification of merchandise make Saleh speciA. in his work. Having built up his customer base from very modest beginnings, in the future he plans to expand his shop by selling beauty products.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his shop.

loans.name: Yen

texts.en: Mr. Yen Y. lives in Rolus village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. His wife, Mrs. Soung Thorn, sells Pro Hok in the local market. She is also a duck breeder. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it, so Mr. Yen Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks to expand his wife’s business. He hopes to increase income and improve their living conditions with this loan. He is 55 years old and the father of four children, one of whom stays at home to do housework while the others are attending the local school. His wife is present in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy more ducks to expand his wife’s business.

loans.name: Fadi

texts.en:
Fadi, 36, resides in Tripoli, northern Lebanon with his wife and their four children. Fadi has worked as a car repairer for 28 years and is requesting a loan of $2500 from Al Majmoua to purchase merchandise, a generator, and car oil for his work. Fadi has been a microcredit client for eight years now and has always repaid on time.
 
His previous loans helped him improve his garage as well as his financial situation. Fadi is special in his work because of the relationship he has established with his clients since taking over his father’s work, and his clients know him well. He decided on this business because of his aptitude for it and his considerable experience in the field, having learned a great deal since beginning this work as a child. In the future, he plans to open a car oil-changing shop and expand his garage.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and equipment for his business.

loans.name: Haytham

texts.en:
Haytham, 25, lives with his parents in Tripoli, northern Lebanon where he has owned a CD and cassette shop for five years. He also rents out a sound music system for parties. Haytham is requesting a loan of $1000 from A. Majmoua  to purchase merchandise for his shop and a tool for his sound system. 

Haytham is speciA. in his work because he has a good relationship with his clients, who are his friends, neighbors and people from his region, and knows how to treat them.  Haytham decided upon this business because of his interest in music, and in the future plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his shop and a tool for his sound system.

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Soutoura, toutes mariées, ont une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans, 2 enfants et vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles à Sanoubougou un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région du Mali).  
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente  de  pagnes wax, de bazin teintés,  et des fruits et légumes.
Elles sont à leur premier prêt  solidaire avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter, 20 pièces de bazin blanc et 15 pièces de pagnes wax.  Les bazins seront amenés à la teinture pour recevoir différentes colories avant d’être revendus en pièces de trois, cinq et six mètres.
Elles  s’approvisionnent à Sikasso auprès des commerçants  grossistes spécialistes de la lingerie. Elles effectuent leurs ventes, en détail, la plupart au comptant, dans les différents marchés et dans les quartiers de la ville. Leur clientèle est composée généralement de femmes..
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 18.000FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Soutoura group, all married, have an average age of 37 and two children, on average, and live in traditional families in Sanoubougou, one of the neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).

They have various businesses, among others selling "wax pagnes" (bolts of high quality African print cloth), locally dyed damask cloth, and fruit and vegetables.

They are on their first solidarity loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. With this loan they expect to buy 20 bolts of damask and 15 lengths of "wax pagne". The damask will be taken for dyeing in different colors before being sold in lengths of 3, 5, or 6 meters. They do their buying in Sikasso from wholesalers specialized in cloth. They sell retail, mostly for cash, in the various markets and in the neighborhoods of the town. Their clientele is composed generally of women.

They each expect to make a profit of 18,000 F CFA per month of which part will be used for needs of their families and the rest reinvested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of damask and "wax pagnes"

loans.name: Mrs. Chantha Kea Village Bank Group

texts.en: Fourteen people living in Mkak village in Takeo province comprise this village bank loan and they will use the loan for various purpose. Mrs. Chantha K. is a 41 year old village bank president. She is a farmer wH. owns a 1 hectare field of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Thang Choeun, is a construction worker. Although they tR. to work hard they still earn less income than needed to support their family. They also do not have enough to build a lavatoR. to provide their family a clean life. In order to deal this problem, Mrs. Chantha K. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. She has four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factoR. while the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To build a lavatory to provide their family a clean life.

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Badenya, avec une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans ont en moyenne 2 enfants et vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles à Mancourani  l’un des quartiers central de la ville de Sikasso (3e région du Mali). 
Elles mènent diverses  activités telles  l’achat vente de poissons, de fruits et légumes, de l’encens etc. 
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur sixième  prêt de groupe. Tous les précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 5 sacs de 50 kg gousse   d’encens , 300kg de fruits,  500 kg de  légumes. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marche de Sikasso et dans les villages voisins avec les producteurs. 
Les marchandises sont vendues en détail, au  grand marché de Sikasso à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 12.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour les besoins de la famille et l’investissement dans les activités.
Les femmes du groupe Badenya ambitionnent être chacune une commerçante grossiste à Sikasso.
texts.en:
The women of the Badenya group, with an average age of 38 and on average 2 children, live in traditional families in Mancourani, one of the centrally located neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third region of Mali).

They have various businesses, such as selling fish, fruit and vegetables, incense, etc. So as to satisfy the demand of their clientele, they work together with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their 6th group loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

With this new loan, they expect to buy 5 50-kg sacks pods of incense, 300 kg of fruit, and 500 kg of vegetables. They do their buying at the big market of Sikasso and in neighboring villages from the farmers. The merchandise is sold retail, at the big market of Sikasso, to a clientele composed of men and women, mostly for cash.

They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 12,000 F CFA which will be used for the needs of their family and for reinvesting into their businesses.

Each of the women of the Badenya group hopes to be a wholesale merchant in Sikasso.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Soro Yiriwa Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Soro Yiriwa (sont toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles à Bougoula ville  l’un des quartiers central de la ville de Sikasso (3e région  administrative de la république du Mali) 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres  la vente de chaussures de poissons, de fruits et légumes etc.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur quatrième  prêt solidaire, tous les trois  prêts précédents  se sont bien dénoués. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter 3 sacs de 50 paires de chaussures , de 200kg de fruits,  50 kg de  légumes. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marche de Sikasso auprès des grossistes et dans les villages voisins auprès des producteurs et effectuent leurs ventes en détail, la plupart au comptant. au  grand marché de Sikasso à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes . 
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.000FCFA  par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Certaines femmes du groupe Soro Yiriwa ambitionnent être un jour une commerçante grossiste de fruits et légumes.
texts.en:
The women of the Soro Yiriwa group (all married), with an average age of 37 and on average 3 children, live in traditional families in Bougoula town, one of the centrally located neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They have various businesses, among others selling shoes, fish, fruit and vegetables, etc. So as to satisfy the demand of their clientele, they work together with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their 4th group loan. All three preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

With this new loan, they expect to buy 3 sacks of 50 pairs of shoes, 200 kg of fruit, and 50 kg of vegetables. They do their buying at the big market of Sikasso from wholesalers and in neighboring villages from the farmers, and they sell retail, at the big market of Sikasso, to a clientele composed of men and women, mostly for cash.

They each expect to make an average profit of 15,000 F CFA per month which will be used for the needs of their families and for reinvesting into their businesses. Certain women of the Soro Yiriwa group hope one day to become wholesale merchants selling fruits and vegetables.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Faida Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Faida, avec une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans ont en moyenne 1 enfant. Elles vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies à Médine un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région du Mali). 
Elles mènent généralement les  activités d’achat et vente de fruits, de condiments alimentaires et de poissons.
Dans le souci de mieux de satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle, le groupe Soro Yiriwa décida d’adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance avec qui il est  à leur troisième prêt solidaire. Tous les précédents prêts ont été remboursés sans difficulté.
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter, 20 paquets de condiments alimentaires,  200 kg de poisson de mer pour les revendre et 10 chargements de charrette en fruits. Elles   s’approvisionnent à Sikasso ville auprès des grossistes et dans les villages environnants auprès des propriétaires de vergers et des potagers. Elles vendent dans les différents marchés de la ville de Sikasso et dans les quartiers(d’une façon ambulante) à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes et d'homme  au comptant, en détail et à crédit.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 28.000FCFA par mois qui servira  essentiellement pour les besoins de la famille et le reste investi dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Faida group, with an average age of 28 and on average 1 child, live in traditional extended families in Médine, one of the neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third region of Mali).

They generally buy and sell fruit, condiments and fish. So as to satisfy the needs of their clientele, the Faida group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their 3rd group loan. Both the preceding loans have been reimbursed without difficulty.

With this loan, they expect to buy 20 packets of condiments, 200 kg of ocean fish for re-sale, and 10 wagonloads of fruit. They do their buying in the town of Sikasso from wholesalers and in neighboring villages from the owners of orchards and market gardens. They sell in the various markets and neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (going door-to-door), to a clientele generally composed of men and women, for cash or on credit.

They each expect to make a profit of 28,000 F CFA per month which will essentially be used for the needs of their families, investing the rest back into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Lafia Group

texts.fr:
Vivant  dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies à Médine un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative de la république du Mali), les femmes du groupe Lafia  (toutes mariées) ont en  moyenne  28 ans  et 1 enfant. 
Unies par des liens de voisinage et professionnel, ces femmes du groupe Lafia mènent  des  activités d’achat et de vente  de  produits de beauté, de boissons, de fruits, de condiments alimentaires etc.
 Elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, après avoir correctement remboursés les deux précédents prêts. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 10 paquets de condiments alimentaires,  20 casiers de boisson.
 Elles s’approvisionnent  essentiellement à Sikasso ville avec les grossistes et effectuent leur vente au marché et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes et d'homme  au comptant, en détail et à crédit.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 25.000FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
Living in traditional extended families in Médine, a residential neighborhood of the town of Sikasso, (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali), the women of the Lafia group (all married) have an average age of 28 and on average, one child.

United by bonds of neighborhood and by professional ties, these women of the Lafia group buy and re-sell cosmetics, drinks, fruit, and condiments, etc.

They are on their third solidarity loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, after having correctly reimbursed the two preceding loans.

With this new loan, they expect to buy 10 packets of condiments and 20 crates of drinks. They do their buying essentially in Sikasso town from wholesalers and sell in the market and the residential neighborhoods to a clientele composed generally of women and men, for cash, retail, and on credit.

They each expect to make a profit of 25,000 F CFA per month, of which part will be used for the needs of their families and the rest will be reinvested into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of drinks and condiments for re-sale

loans.name: Pauline

texts.fr:
D. Pauline est née le 28/12/1970 à Comè un village du département de MONO dont elle est originaire. Pauline est mère de cinq (5) enfants dont trois (3) garçons et deux (2) filles, tous scolarisés. Pauline est mariée à AGBOTON Paul, un photographe de profession. Pauline et sa famille vit en location à Kowegbo un quartier périphérique de Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Pauline vendait des habits pour enfants de façon ambulante dans la journée et de la nourriture les soirs devant son domicile. Mais depuis quatre (4) ans, Pauline a laissé cette activité au profit de la vente des divers (pâtes alimentaires, boîtes de lait, savons, biscuits, de l'huile d'arachide et de palme, de maïs, etc.)qui est plus rentable que les activités qu'elle menait avant. Pauline a ouvert une boutique dans son quartier non loin de son domicile où elle expose tous ses produits qui lui marchent à merveille. La demande de la clientèle de Pauline se fait de plus en plus pressante et Pauline n'arrive plus à la satisfaire. C'est pourquoi Pauline  sollicite un prêt afin d'accroître son capital et de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Pauline D. was born on December 28, 1970 in Comè, a village in the province of Mono, where her roots are. Pauline is the mother of 5 children, 3 boys and 2 girls, all in school. Pauline is married to Paul Agboton, a professional photographer. Pauline and her family rent a place in Kowegbo, an outlying neighborhood of Cotonou, economic capital of Benin.

Pauline used to sell children's clothing door-to-door in the daytime and cooked food evenings in front of her house. Four years ago, however, Pauline left off these businesses in favor of selling various items (pasta, tinned milk, soap, biscuits, peanut and palm oil, maize, etc.) which brings in more money than her former businesses.

Pauline opened a little shop in her neighborhood, not far from her home, where she displays her products and is having great success. Her customers' demand is becoming more insistant and Pauline is not able to satisfy it. This is why she is requesting a loan so as to increase her working capital and satisfy the demand of her clientele.

The significance of ALIDé in the local language of Benin, Fon, is "there is always a pathway for the poorest of the poor". Benin is a small country in West Africa next door to Nigeria, where the GNP is about $1,500 per year. ALIDé offers special loans at 0% interest to very vulnerable individuals and is part of a group which will soon begin a program of small scale health insurance for recipients of micro-credit.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various items (sugar, candy, sweet biscuits, detergent, etc.), peanut and palm oil and sacks of maize

loans.name: Djikiya Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Djikiya (sont toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans ont en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles à Médine un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région du Mali).
Elles mènentLes  femmes du groupe Djikiya (sont toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans ont en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles à Médine un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région du Mali).
Elles menent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente  de condiments alimentaires, de  tissus, de pagnes wax, de charbon de bois, des céréales,des  boissons gazeuses etc. 
Elles sont à leur premier prêt solidaire avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Ce prêt servira à acheter, 3 paquets de condiments alimentaires,  5 sacs de 100kg de riz, 10 paquets de boissons,  5  chargements de charrette en  charbon de bois et  10 pièces de pagne wax. Elles   s’approvisionnent à Sikasso ville et ses localités environnantes. 
Les marchandises sont vendues, en détail,  la plupart au comptant  et quelques fois à crédit au marché et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 16.000F CFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
 diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente  de condiments alimentaires, de  tissus, de pagnes wax, de charbon de bois, des céréales,des  boissons gazeuses etc. 
Elles sont à leur premier prêt solidaire avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Ce prêt servira à acheter, 3 paquets de condiments alimentaires,  5 sacs de 100kg de riz, 10 paquets de boissons,  5  chargements de charrette en  charbon de bois et  10 pièces de pagne wax. Elles   s’approvisionnent à Sikasso ville et ses localités environnantes. 
Les marchandises sont vendues, en détail,  la plupart au comptant  et quelques fois à crédit au marché et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 16.000F CFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Djikiya group (all are married), with an average age of 35 and on average, 2 children, live in traditional families in Médine, one of the residential neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (3re region of Mali).
