They have varied businesses, among others, selling condiments, cloth, "Wax pagnes" (high quality traditional African print cloth), charcoal, cereals, fizzy drinks, etc.

They are on their first solidarity loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. This loan will serve to buy 3 packets of condiments, 5 sacks of 100-kg of rice, 10 packs of drinks, 5 wagonloads of charcoal, and 10 lengths of "Wax pagne". They do their buying in Sikasso and its surrounding localities.

The merchandise is sold retail, mostly for cash and sometimes for credit, in the market and the residential neighborhoods, to a clientele composed generally of women.

They each expect to make a profit of 16,000 F CFA per month of which part will be used for family needs and the rest will be invested back into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Sindiya Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Sindiya, avec une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans ont en moyenne 2 enfants et vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles à Médine un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative de la république  du Mali). 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente  de condiments, de poissons, de boisson gazeuses, de  tissus, de  wax, de charbon de bois et   de céréales.
Elles sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter, 3 paquets de condiments alimentaires, 10 carton de poisson fumé , 5 sacs de 100kg de riz 10 paquet de boissons , 5  chargements de charrette en charbon de bois et  10 pièces de pagnes wax.
 Elles s’approvisionnent à Sikasso ville et dans les villages  environnants et effectuent leurs ventes au marché et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 20.000FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group Sindiya average 37 years of age and 2 children. They live in traditional families in Médine, a district in the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They do various kinds of work, including selling condiments, fish, fizzy drinks, fabrics, Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), charcoal, and grains.

The group members are on their first loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. With this loan, they plan to buy three packets of condiments, ten boxes of smoked fish, five 10-kg sacks of rice, ten packets of drinks, five cart-loads of charcoal, and ten bolts of Wax pagnes. Supplies of goods are gotten in Sikasso City and in surrounding villages. Sales are made at the marketplace and in the districts to customers composed generally of women.

The group members each envision realizing a profit of 20,000 francs CFA per month. A portion of the profits will be used to meet family needs, and the other portion will be invested in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Mireille

texts.fr:
O. Mireille est née le 16/01/1982 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique du BENIN. Mireille est originaire de TAKON dans le département de PLATEAU. Mireille est célibataire sans enfant. Mireille est titulaire du baccalauréat et vit chez sa maman à Agongbomey, un quartier de Cotonou.  Mireille est dans le commerce des cartes de recharge téléphonique.Mireille gère en plus de cela deux combines téléphoniques. L'activité de Mireille est très florissante et nécessite plus de moyens financiers qu'elle n'en a. En effet, Mireille envisage acheter d'autres appareils téléphoniques afin d'ouvrir des cabines téléphoniques dans d'autres quartiers de la ville de Cotonou. C'est pour cette raison que Mireille sollicite un quatrième crédit à ALIDé pour satisfaire sa clientèle.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Mireille O. was born on January 16, 1982 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Mireille's roots are in Takon, in the Plateau province. Mireille is single and has no children. She has her "bacc." (advanced high school diploma) and lives with her mother in Agongbomey, a district of Cotonou. Mireille sells rechargeable phone cards and she also manages two public telephones. Her business is flourishing and necessitates increased working capital that she doesn't have. In fact, Mireille is hoping to buy more telephones so as to have telephone booths in other sections of the city of Cotonou. For this reason, Mireille is requesting her fourth loan from ALIDé so as to satisfy her clientele. The significance of ALIDé in the local language of Benin, Fon, is "there is always a pathway for the poorest of the poor". Benin is a small country in West Africa next door to Nigeria, where the GNP is about $1,500 per year. ALIDé offers special loans at 0% interest to very vulnerable individuals and is part of a group which will soon begin a program of small scale health insurance for recipients of micro-credit.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of rechargeable telephone cards and two public telephones

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr:
Monsieur Adama D. est un homme marié de 38 ans et père de 2 enfants qui  vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans la  quartier Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu à fréquenter l’école pour des raisons sociales, Monsieur Adama D. s’essaya à plusieurs activités économiques notamment la vente d’habits , de chaussures, de tasses etc. Ces activités ne lui ont pas réussies, il opta finalement  pour l’ouverture une boutique d’articles divers. Il a appris cette activité auprès de grand frère.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, il fait recours à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son premier individuel.
Monsieur Adama D.  compte  acheter  une diversité d’articles pour  boutique à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). Sa clientèle est composée de toutes les catégories sociales de la population.
Avec ce prêt, Adama D. compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30 000 FCFA qui servira à agrandir sa boutique et à assurer les dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Adama D., 38, is married and the father of 2 children; he lives with his wife and children in the Hérémakono North district of the town of Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Having been unable to attend school for societal reasons, Mr. Adama D. tried out various businesses, notably selling clothing, shoes, basins, etc. None of these businesses was successful, so he finally decided to open a general store. He learned this business from his big brother.

As he searched for complementary financial resources, he turned to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom he is on his first individual loan. He intends to buy many varied items for his shop in Bamako (the capital of the Republic of Mali). His clientele is composed of all social strata.

With this loan Adama D. expects to make a monthly profit of 30,000 F CFA which will be used to expand his shop and support his family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont toutes mariées. Âgées de 23 à 35 ans avec en moyenne 2 enfants, elles vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier Torakabougou de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles sont unies par des liens de voisinage  et font le commerce d’articles divers (condiments, pâte d’arachide, charbon de bois).
Ces femmes viennent de commencer le partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur premier prêt solidaire. 
Le présent prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 9 sacs d’arachide avec les agriculteurs des villages environnants. Les graines d’arachide obtenues seront vendues au marché de Bougouni. La clientèle est composée exclusivement de femmes vendeuses de condiments alimentaires qui en font de la pâte d’arachide. 
Ce commerce permet aux membres du groupe de gagner en moyenne 20.000FCFA par mois. Cette marge bénéficiaire permet de rembourser l’échéance du prêt et de satisfaire également quelques dépenses de la famille (éducation des enfants, santé et habillement surtout).
texts.en:
The women of the Benkadi group are all married. They are 23-35 years old and on average, have 2 children. They live in extended traditional families in the Torakabougou neighborhood of the town of Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are united by being neighbors and sell diverse items (condiments, peanut butter, charcoal).

These women have just become partners of Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their first solidarity loan. This loan will be used to buy 9 sacks of peanuts from the farmers in the surrounding villages. The hulled peanuts will be sold in the market in Bougouni. The clientele is composed exclusively of women who sell condiments and use the peanuts to make peanut butter.

This business permits the members of the group to earn an average of 20,000 F CFA per month. This profit allows them to reimburse the loan and also to cover some family expenses (education of the children, health, and clothing above all).

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of peanuts for re-sale

loans.name: Tièssiri Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Tièssiri (3 mariées et une célibataire) sont  âgées de 18 à 45 ans avec en moyenne 3 enfants et vivant dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier Torakabougou de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes viennent de commencer le  partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur premier prêt de groupe  et sont unies par des liens de voisinage.
Le présent prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 30 kg de poudre de gombo. Les femmes s’approvisionnent avec les paysannes des villages environnants de Bougouni. Les achats sont faits  pendant les jours de foire. Cette poudre de gombo (qui est un condiment alimentaire entrant dans la préparation de beaucoup de sauces au Mali et même en Afrique de l’ouest) sera reconditionnée, mise dans des petits emballages et vendu à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali).
De ce commerce les femmes du groupe espèrent  gagner en moyenne 15.000FCFA par mois. Avec cette marge bénéficiaire elles  remboursent l’échéance du prêt et font face également à quelques dépenses de la famille (éducation des enfants, santé et habillement surtout).
texts.en:
The women of the Tièssiri group (3 married and one single) are between 18 and 45, with on average 3 children. They live in traditional extended families in the Torakabougou neighborhood of the town of Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

These women have just begun their partnership with Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their first group loan and are united through the fact that they are neighbors.

This loan will be used to buy 30 kg of powdered okra. The women buy their merchandise from the farm women in the villages surrounding Bougouni. They do their buying on market days. This powdered okra (which is a condiment used in the preparation of many sauces in Mali and indeed in all of West Africa) will be reconditioned, put into small packets, and sold in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali).

From this business, the women of this group hope to make on average 15,000 F CFA per month. With this profit, they will repay the loan and also cover some expenses for their families (education of their children, health, and clothing above all).

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of powdered okra

loans.name: Penda

texts.fr:
Madame Penda  D. est une femme divorcée de quarante trois  ans, mère de trois enfants, qui réside à Sanankoroba village situé à 20  kilomètres de Bamako (la capitale du Mali) où elle est assistante sociale au village d’enfants SOS (VSOS). Sanankoroba est situé dans la deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Penda fait le commerce de pagnes, de draps de lit, de tissus etc. Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, elle décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Elle est à son premier prêt individuel après avoir correctement remboursés ses trois prêts de groupe (prêt solidaire) et compte avoir avec ce nouveau prêt  pour acheter, 35 pagnes et 15 draps de lit.
 Elle s’approvisionne sur le marché de Bamako pour revendre à Sanankoroba au comptant et à crédit.
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 55. 000  F CFA pour pouvoir non seulement rembourser l’échéance du prêt mais aussi investir dans son commerce et contribuer aux dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Mrs. Penda D. is a divorcee aged 40, mother of three children, who lives in Sanankoroba, a village situated 20 km from Bamako (the capital of Mali) where she is a social worker in the SOS children's village. Sanankoroba is situated in the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali.

Penda sells "pagnes" (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth), bedsheets, fabrics, etc. In her search for complementary financial resources, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.

She is on her first individual loan after having correctly reimbursed three group loans (solidarity loans) and with this loan she intends to buy 35 "pagnes" and 15 sheets.

She does her buying at the market in Bamako, then sells for cash and credit in Sanankoroba. She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 55,000 F CFA so that she can not only reimburse the loan but also invest in her business and contribute to family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of "pagnes" and bedsheets for re-sale

loans.name: Assétou

texts.fr:
Madame  Assétou D.   est âgée de 41 ans,  veuve et mère de  8  enfants, elle vit chez son feu époux  avec ses  enfants au quartier Pelengana village  de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas été à l’école, elle a commencé le commerce auprès de son frère qui vendait de l’oignon, de l’ail et du gueni (racines parfumées se trouvant dans des zones humides utilisées dans la préparation de l’encens) pendant 15ans et finit par évoluer seule après avoir acquis suffisamment d’expériences. Elle jouit d’une grande réputation et d’une grande clientèle.
Madame Assétou D. a fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso pour renforcer son fonds de commerce. En relation avec cette dernière depuis 28 mois, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel  après avoir bien remboursé 3 prêts solidaires. 
Ce nouveau prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter 300 kg de riz, 300 kg de (gueni).Elle s’approvisionne à Dougabougou et Siribala. Elle vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle constituée  d’hommes et de femmes sur place à Ségou et à Bamako où elle a beaucoup de clients.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30.000 FCFA.qui lui permettra de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille (car elle est veuve) et payer les frais de scolarité de ses enfants qui sont à bas âge. 
Elle ambitionne  pérenniser son commerce de riz et de (gueni).
texts.en:
Mrs. Assétou D., 41, is a widowed mother of 8 children; she lives in the house of her late husband with her children in the Pelengana neighborhood of the village of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

She never attended school, so she began working in sales with her brother, who sold onions, garlic, and "gueni" (good smelling roots that grow in humid areas and are used in making incense). She worked with him for 15 years and finally began selling on her own account, when she had gained enough experience. She has an excellent reputation and an extensive clientele.

Mrs. Assétou D. turned to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to reinforce her working capital. She has been a member for 28 months and is now on her third individual loan, after having reimbursed 3 solidarity loans correctly. This new loan will be used to buy 300 kg of rice and 300 kg of "gueni". She does her buying in Dougabougou and Siribala. She sells for cash and credit to a clientele constituted of men and women right there in Ségou and in Bamako where she has a lot of customers.

She expects to make a monthly profit of 30,000 F CFA which will permit her to support her family (since she is a widow) and pay the school fees for her younger children. She hopes to be able to keep up her sales of rice and "gueni".

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy rice and "gueni" (sweet-smelling roots)

loans.name: Koumba

texts.fr:
Madame  Koumba C. est âgée de 45 ans,  mariée et mère de 3 enfants, elle vit chez son   époux  avec ses  enfants au quartier Pelengana Sud  de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Aide soignante de profession, elle s’est initiée au  commerce par l’entremise d’un commerçant de la place pour qui elle vendait en détail et en ambulant des habits et ventilateurs  pendant plusieurs années. Forte de cette riche expérience elle décida  de s’installer à son propre compte depuis maintenant  8 ans en menant les mêmes activités. Elle jouit d’une grande  réputation et notoriété car ses marchandises hautes de gamme sont très prisées et ses clients sont très nombreux.
Dans l’intention de renforcer son activité afin de réaliser beaucoup de bénéfices elle fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elle est en relation depuis 4 ans. Après  4 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels tous correctement bien remboursés, elle est à son 3ème  prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 20 paires de chaussures et 20 pièces de tissus. Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières en Guinée Conakry. Madame  Koumba C. vend au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt, elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui servira à rembourser les intérêts du prêt et aider son mari à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille.
Son ambition est d’ouvrir un magasin de stockage de céréales à Ségou.
texts.en:
Mrs. Koumba C., 45, is married and the mother of 3 children; she lives with her husband and children in the Pelengana Sud district of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Practical nurse by profession, she got into the business world through a merchant where she lives, for whom she used to sell, retail and door-to-door, clothing and fans for several years. With this excellent experience, she decided to set herself up in the same sort of business 8 years ago. She has a good reputation and is well-known since her first-class merchandise is much sought after and she has numerous customers.

With the intention of bolstering her business so as to make more profit, she came to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom she is has been working for 4 years. After 4 solidarity loans and 2 individual loans, all correctly reimbursed, she is on her third individual loan.

She intends to use this loan to buy 20 pairs of shoes and 20 lengths of fabric. She does her buying of raw materials in Guinée Conakry. Mrs. Koumba C. sells retail, for cash or credit, to a clientele composed of men and women. With this loan she expects to make a monthly profit of 100,000 F CFA which she will use to reimburse the interest on the lan and help her husband support the family.

Her ambition is to open a warehouse for cereals in Ségou.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase shoes and fabrics for re-sale

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Madame Mariam C. est âgée de 38 ans,  mariée et mère de 5 enfants, elle vit chez son   époux  avec ses  enfants  dans une famille monogamique au quartier Ségou Coura de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant vite abandonné l’école, elle commença très tôt les activités génératrices de revenus auprès  de sa mère qui vendait des céréales. Après plusieurs années passées auprès de cette dernière, elle maîtrise parfaitement les rouages du commerce  de céréales et jouit d’une grande réputation dans son quartier, au marché et dans certains services administratifs car elle donne du riz à crédit payable mensuellement aux fonctionnaires.
Dans le souci d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, elle fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elle est en relation depuis 4 ans. Après 4 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels tous correctement bien remboursés, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser ce montant pour acheter 8 sacs de riz et 5 sacs de mil. Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières à Konodimini auprès des producteurs. Madame Mariam C. vend au comptant en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 60 000FCFA qui lui permettra de prendre certaines charges familiales et de participer à certains événements sociaux (mariage, baptême etc.).
Son ambition est d’ouvrir un magasin de stockage de céréales.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mariam C. is 38 years old, married with 5 children, and lives with her husband and children in a monogamous household in the Ségou Coura area of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having abandoned her schooling early on, she began participating in revenue-generating activities with her mother, who sold cereals. After many years of working with her mother, she has perfectly mastered the nuts and bolts of the cereal selling business and enjoys an excellent reputation in her area, at the market, and in certain administrative services because she provides rice to civil servants on credit, payable monthly. With the hope of increasing her working capital, she turned to the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom she has been working for 4 years. After 4 solidarity (group) loans and 2 individual loans, all repaid properly, she is seeking her third individual loan. She intends to use this amount to buy 8 bags of rice and 5 sacks of millets. She supplies herself with raw materials from the producers in Konodimini. Mrs. Mariam C. sells her goods in cash at retail and on credit to a clientele composed of men and women. With this loan, she intends to realize a monthly profit of 60,000 FCFA, which will allow her to take charge of certain family expenses and to participate in certain social events (marriages, baptisms,etc.). Her ambition is to open a store that stocks cereals.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and re-sell cereals

loans.name: Rokia

texts.fr:
Madame  Rokia  K. est âgée de 29 ans et vit avec son époux et ses 3 enfants dans le quartier Médine de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Titulaire d’un certificat d’aptitude professionnelle en comptabilité, elle s’est initiée au commerce auprès à sa mère qui fut jadis une commerçante et une grande restauratrice à Ségou. Depuis élève elle aidait cette dernière tenir sa comptabilité et distribuer ses articles. Riche de cette expérience, elle  décida d’évoluer en solo pour exercer les activités d’achat et de vente d’habits et de chaussures depuis 9 ans .Elle jouit d’une grande réputation et notoriété à Ségou.
Pour augmenter son fonds de commerce afin de faire face à la demande  de sa clientèle, elle fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elle est en relation  depuis 36 mois. Après 4 prêts solidaires et 1 prêt individuel tous correctement bien remboursés, elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel qui sera utilisé pour acheter 30 complets de bazins moins  riches et 5 complets de bazins riches. Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières à Bamako (capitale du Mali). Madame Rokia   K. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.  
Avec ce prêt elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30 000 FCFA qui lui permettra de faire face à certains événements sociaux. son ambition est d’ouvrir une boutique de vente d’habits.
texts.en:
Mrs. Rokia K. is 29 years old and lives with her husband and 3 children in the Médine area of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Holder of an official certification in accounting, she was initiated into the business world through her mother, who was formerly a shopkeeper and significant caterer in Ségou. Since her student days, she helped her mother manage her accounts and distribute her goods. Enriched by this experience, she decided nine years ago to develop her own business buying and selling clothing and shoes. She enjoys an excellent reputation and fame in Ségou. To increase her working capital in order to meet the demands of her clientele, she turned to the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom she has been working for 36 months. After 4 solidarity (group) loans and 1 individual loan, all repaid properly, she is seeking her second individual loan, which will be used to buy 30 outfits of medium-quality damask and 5 outfits of rich damask. She gets her raw materials in Bamako (the capital of Mali). Mrs. Rokia K. sells her goods in cash and on credit to a clientele composed of men and women. With this loan, she intends to realize a monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA, which will allow her to provide for various traditional social events. Her ambition is to open a boutique selling clothes.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and re-sell clothing

loans.name: Djiguitougou Group

texts.fr:
Composé de deux veuves et de deux mariées monogames, les femmes du groupe Djiguitougou sont âgées en moyenne de 43 ans avec 5 enfants. Elles vivent toutes  dans  le quartier Darsalam de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali). 
Liées par des relations de voisinage elles font le commerce de condiments alimentaires, de la restauration et la transformation de l’oignon. En plus de ces activités  elles vendent  de temps à autres des draps de lit et des vêtements brodés à base de popeline
 Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle elles ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  elles sont à leur 5ème  prêt solidaire après avoir bien remboursé les quatre prêts précédents.
 Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter : 5 sacs de mil (dont une partie est transformée en beignets pour être  vendue) ,3 sacs de gombo séchés, 8 sacs d’oignon frais (qui seront épluchés, lavés, découpés en petits morceaux, séchés à l’aide d’un séchoir puis emballés dans des sachets en plastiques).
 Une bonne partie de cet oignon est gardée jusqu’en l’hivernage où l’oignon est rare sur les marchés. Elles se ravitaillent au marché de Médine et à Kindjeli auprès des producteurs et grossistes. Elles vendent au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes, de femmes à domicile ou en ambulant.
 Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 45 000 FCA  qui sera utilisé pour  rembourser les intérêts du prêt et subvenir aux dépenses de la famille.
 Elles ont pour ambitions  d’avoir une maison à usage d’habitation et l’ouverture d’une boutique de vente de draps de lit.
texts.en:
Composed of two widows and two married women from monogamous households, the women of the Djiguitougou group are on average 43 years old and have an average of 5 children. They all live in the Darsalam neighborhood of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali).

Linked by the fact that they are neighbors, they sell condiments, cooked food, and processed onions. Moreover, they sometimes sell bedsheets and embroidered clothing made of poplin.

Wishing to satisfy the needs of their clientele, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are on their 5th solidarity loan, after having reimbursed the other four loans successfully. This loan will be used to buy 5 sacks of millet (part of which will be made into fried cakes to sell), 3 sacks of dried okra, and 8 sacks of fresh onions (which will be peeled, washed, cut into small pieces, dried in a dryer, then packaged up in plastic.)

A good part of this processed onion will be kept until the off-season, where onions are rare in the markets. They do their buying in the market of Médine and in Kindjeli from farmers and wholesalers. They sell for cash or credit to a clientele composed of men and of housewives, out of their homes or door-to-door.

They hope to make a monthly, average profit of 45,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and cover family expenses. Their ambition is to have a house of their own to live in and to open a shop selling bedsheets.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy millet, dried okra, and fresh onions

loans.name: Tiessiri. Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Tiessiri est composé de deux veuves et de quatre mariées qui vivent dans des grandes familles élargies dans le quartier Hamdallaye de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali).Les femmes du groupe Tiessiri ont en moyenne de 40 ans,   4 enfants et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage. Elles des activités diverses et variées.
 Après  fait 6 de prêts solidaires tous correctement bien remboursés, elles sont à leur 7ème  prêt de groupe.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter : des ustensiles  en  plastiques :1 douzaine de baignoire, 2 douzaines de seau, 6 douzaines de bol, 2 douzaines de plateau et 2 douzaines de tasses ; 400 kg de bananes ; 4 sacs de riz (préparé et vendu en plats alimentaires), 2 paniers de condiments ;   4 sacs de sucre ,2 sacs de gingembre ,1 sac de feuilles d’oseille de Guinée, 2 carton de lait en poudre pour le yaourt, 2 paquets de sachets plastiques et 2 cartons d’essence. Elles se ravitaillent en ustensiles à Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso), en riz à la foire de Ségou  et quant aux autres articles grand marché de Bamako (capitale du Mali). Elles vendent au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, à domicile, en ambulant au marché du château de Ségou et dans les foires hebdomadaires de Katiéna, Yolo et de Konodimini. Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 62 000 FCFA  qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt, la participation aux évènements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes et funérailles) et l’aide aux conjoints dans la prise en charge de certaines dépenses au niveau de la famille.
 Leur objectif est d’avoir une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The Tiessiri group is composed of two widows and four married women who live in large extended families in the Hamdallaye area of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali). The women of the Tiessiri group are on average 40 years old, have 4 children, and know each other through familial and marriage connections. They run a variety of diverse businesses. After obtaining 6 solidarity (group) loans, all repaid properly, they are seeking their 7th group loan. They intend to use this loan to buy plastic utensils, 1 dozen tubs, 2 dozen buckets, 6 dozen bowls, 2 dozen trays, 2 dozen cups, 400 kg of bananas, 4 bags of rice (to be prepared and sold as part of food dishes), 2 baskets of condiments, 4 bags of sugar, 2 bags of ginger, 1 bag of hibiscus blossoms, 2 cartons of powdered milk for yogurt, 2 packets of plastic bags, and two boxes of essences. They supply themselves with utensils in Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso), with rice at the market in Ségou, and the other goods at the grand market in Bamako (the capital of Mali). They sell their goods in cash and on credit to a clientele composed of men and women at home, on the road, at the chateau marketplace in Ségou, and at the weekly market-days in Katiéna, Yolo, and Konodimini. They foresee realizing an average monthly profit of 62,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay the loan, provide for traditional social events (marriages, baptisms, and funerals), and help their spouses in taking care of certain family expenses. Their goal is to have a house to live in.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials to prepare local drinks and food dishes, and to sell plastic utensils and fruit

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Composé uniquement de femmes mariées, les six membres du groupe Danaya ont une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans et de 6 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles avec leurs enfants, frères, sœurs et époux dans le village de Sirakorodie, sous préfecture de Fana, dans la préfecture de DIOÏLA région de KOULIKORO, république du Mali. 
Pour des raisons de voisinage et de commerce, elles se sont connues et  font essentiellement le commerce de volailles et des œufs de pintades. 
Pour atténuer les difficultés liées au manque de fonds afin d’acheter beaucoup de volailles, elles ont adhéré à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur  premier prêt de groupe. 
Avec ce prêt elles désirent acheter 150 têtes de volailles (Pintades, poules, canards) et 500 œufs de pintades. Les volailles seront achetées avec les fournisseurs de Sirakorodie et ses villages environnants pour être ensuite vendus sur le marché de Fana.
 Elles seront par la suite revendues en détail et au comptant à une clientèle  composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Ces femmes comptent obtenir chacune avec ce prêt un bénéfice par cycle de  45 000 FCFA qui les servira à entretenir les enfants.
texts.en:
Composed solely of married women, the six members of the Danaya group are on average 34 years old with 6 children. They live in traditional extended households with their children, brothers, sisters, and husbands in the village of Sirakorodie, Fana sub-prefecture, in the prefecture of DIOÏLA, KOULIKORO region, in the Republic of Mali. By being neighbours and having business connections, they got to know each other, and essentially are involved in the commerce of poultry and guinea-fowl eggs. To mitigate the difficulties linked to the lack of funds and to buy lots of poultry, they joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are seeking their first group loan. With this loan, they intend to buy 150 heads of poultry (guinea-fowl, hens, and ducks) and 500 guinea-fowl eggs. The poultry will be bought from the suppliers in Sirakorodie and its surrounding villages to then be sold at the market in Fana. They will subsequently be sold at retail and in cash to a clientele composed of men and women. With this loan, these women intend to obtain a total profit of 45,000 FCFA each, which will serve them in looking after their children.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Tiessiri Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq  membres du groupe TIESSIRI sont tous mariés. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans,  6 enfants et vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles avec leurs enfants, frères, sœurs et époux dans le village de SIRAKORODIE, sous préfecture de FANA, dans la préfecture de DIOÏLA région de KOULIKORO, république du Mali. A travers les liens mariages et de voisinage, ces clientes se sont connues et font  le commerce de céréales. 
Afin d’augmenter leur stock pour mieux satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur premier prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe)
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter 800 kg de maïs, 200 kg de sorgho, 700 kg de haricot. Toutes ces céréales seront achetées avec les fournisseurs de SIRAKORODIE et ses villages environnants. Les produits seront directement vendus sur le marché de Fana en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent avoir chacune avec ce prêt un bénéfice par cycle  de  25 000 FCFA qui les servira à surmonter les frais d’éducation des enfants.
texts.en:
The five members of the TIESSIRI groups are all married, and average 33 years of age and 6 children. They live in traditional conjugal families, with their children, brothers, sisters, and husband, in the SIRAKORODIE village, subprefecture of Fana, in the DIOÏLA prefecture (KOULIKORO region, Republic of Mali). They got acquainted through bonds of marriage and neighborhood. Their business consists in selling cereals. In order to bolster their stock and to better satisfy the needs of their clientele, they decided to join Kiva's partner, the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, from which they are seeking their first solidarity loan (group loan).

With this loan, they intend to buy 800 kg of corn, 200 kg of sorghum, and 700 kg of bean. All these cereals will be purchased from providers in SIRAKORODIE and in the surrounding villages. The products will be directly retailed at the Fana market for cash, to a clientele comprising both men and women. During this loan cycle, they foresee turning an average profit of XOF 25'000 (ca US$ 50) each, to be used to pay for their children's education.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 800 kg of corn, 200 kg of sorghum, and 700 kg of bean

loans.name: Bikadi Group

texts.fr:
Composé de six femmes, les  membres du groupe BIKADI sont tous des femmes mariées. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 31 ans et de 4 enfants et vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles avec leurs enfants, frères, sœurs et époux  dans le village de TINGOLE, sous préfecture de FANA, dans la préfecture de DIOÏLA région de KOULIKORO, république du Mali. 
A travers es liens sociaux et de voisinage, elles se sont connues et exercent en générale le commerce de céréales. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter leur chiffre d’affaire et de faire plus de stock, elles ont adhéré à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur septième prêt de groupe dont quatre prêts de campagne. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, 2 tonnes de maïs, 500 kg de sorgho, 700 kg de haricot. Toutes ces céréales seront achetées avec les producteurs de TINGOLE et ses villages environnants. Une partie des produits sera stockée jusqu’aux périodes de soudures, l’autre partie sera vendue en détail et au comptant sur le marché de TINGOLE à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent obtenir chacune avec ce prêt un bénéfice par cycle de 47 000 FCFA qui les servira à appuyer leurs époux dans la prise en charge des dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Composed of six women, the members of the group BIKADI are all married and average 31 years of age and 4 children. They live in traditional conjugal families with their children, brothers, sisters, and spouses in the village of TINGOLE in FANA sub-prefecture (DIOÏLA prefecture in the KOULIKORO region) in the Republic of Mali. Through social and community ties, they came to know one another. They in general do the same work selling grains.

Concerned about increasing their turnover and to build a bigger stock of goods, they've joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their seventh group loan, which included four rural loans. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

With this loan, the group members intend to buy 2 tonnes of corn, 400 kg of sorghum, and 700 kg of beans. All these grains will be purchased from producers in and around TINGOLE. A portion of the goods will be stored until times of shortages. The other portion will be sold retail in cash transaction to customers composed of men and women at the TINGOLE marketplace.

The group members each plan to earn a profit of 47,000 francs CFA per cycle that will serve to support their spouses in covering family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grain

loans.name: Danyerela Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danyerela est composé de huit  femmes qui sont toutes mariées et ont une moyenne d’âge de 27 ans et de 2 enfants. Elles vivent  la plus part dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles avec leurs enfants, frères, sœurs et époux dans le village de TINGOLE, sous préfecture de FANA, dans la préfecture de DIOÏLA relevant de la deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Par des relations de mariage, elles se sont connues et exercent le commerce des condiments alimentaires. 
Dans l’objectif d’améliorer ce commerce elles ont adhéré à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur septième prêt de groupe dont quatre prêts agricoles. Elles ont correctement remboursé tous les prêts précédents. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter 400 kg d’oignons, 20 boites de 2 kg de concentrée de tomate, 30 paquets de cube maggi et une quantité importante de divers condiments. Les produits seront achetés sur le marché de Bamako (capitale du Mali) pour être ensuite revendus dans le village de TINGOLE en détail, au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes. 
Les femmes du groupe Danyerela comptent obtenir chacune avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 7 500 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour entretenir les enfants.
texts.en:
The Danyerela group is composed of 8 women who are all married and have an average age of 27, with 2 children on average. They mostly live in traditional extended families with their children, brothers, sisters, and husbands in the village of Tingole, Sous-prefecture of Fana, Prefecture of Dioila, which comes under the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali.

They met because of being in-laws and they sell condiments. With a view to improving their businesses, they joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their 7th group loan, of which 4 were agricultural loans. They have correctly reimbursed all the preceding loans.

With this loan they intend to buy 400 kg of onions, 20 tins of 2 kg each of tomato concentrate, 30 packets of Maggi cubes, and a large quantity of various other condiments. The products will be bought in the marketplace in Bamako (capital of Mali) to be sold in the village of Tingole, retail, for cash or credit, to a clientele composed of women.

The women of the Danyerela group expect each to make a monthly profit of 7,500 F CFA which will be used to take care of their children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments for re-sale

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les sept femmes du groupe Djiguisseme sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans et de 5 enfants. Elles vivent en majorité dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies dans le village de TINGOLE, sous préfecture de FANA dans la préfecture de DIOÏLA région de KOULIKORO république du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des relations commerciales et font essentiellement  le commerce des fruits et légumes. 
Avec l’objectif d’améliorer leurs activités, elles ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur sixième prêt de groupe dont quatre prêts agricoles. Les précédents prêts ont été bien remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter 200 kg de papayes, 300 kg de bananes, 100 kg d’aubergines et 80 kg de carottes. Les produits seront achetés dans les jardins potagers de TINGOLE et ses villages environnants pour ensuite être revendus sur le marché de FANA en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Ces femmes comptent obtenir chacune, par mois un bénéfice de 10 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour subvenir aux frais scolaires des enfants.
texts.en:
The seven women of the group Djiguisseme are all married and average 34 years of age and 5 children. They live for the most part in traditional extended conjugal families in the village of TINGOLE in FANA sub-prefecture (DIOÏLA prefecture in the KOULIKORO region) in the Republic of Mali. They came to know one another through business ties, and they essentially do commerce in fruits and vegetables.

With the objective of improving their businesses, the group members decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are now on their sixth group loan. Four of these loans included agricultural loans. The preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

With this loan, they plan to buy 200 kg of papayas, 300 kg of bananas, 100 kg of eggplants, and 80 kg of carrots. The goods will be purchased from gardens in and around TINGOLE and then resold retail in cash transactions to customers composed of men and women at the FANA marketplace.

The group members each intend to earn a profit of 10,000 francs CFA per month that will be used to cover schooling costs for the children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Ruziki Kigogo Group

texts.en:
Helene S., age 32, is married with three children (ages 15, 12 and 7). She has a business selling vegetables and fruits in Kigogo Fresh. She started the business 5 years ago and works daily from 6am until 10pm. Helen is able to earn about US$ 62 per month.

This will be Helene's eighth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, and she is excited to get started! She intends to use the loan to increase her stock and to buy material to make bricks to build her home.

Helene will share this loan with her loan group, Riziki Kigogo. The group has 16 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Helen is the first on the right in the blue dress.

loans.use: buying more vegetables and fruit for re-sale and bricks for her house

loans.name: Kelenya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kelenya est composé de huit  femmes mariées, qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans et de 3 enfants. Elles vivent en majorité dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies dans le village de TINGOLE, sous préfecture de FANA de la préfecture de DIOÏLA, région de KOULIKORO république du Mali.
 Par des liens de voisinage, ces femmes se sont connues et font le commerce de condiments alimentaires
Dans l’intention d’élargir la taille de leur activité elles ont adhéré à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et  sont à leur septième prêt de groupe dont quatre prêts agricoles. Les précédents prêts ont été bien remboursés.
 Avec ce prêt ces femmes comptent acheter 150 kg de choux, 200 kg d’aubergines, 200 kg de sel de cuisine et une importante quantité de divers  condiments. Une partie des produits sera achetée sur le marché de FANA et l’autre partie avec les jardiniers de TINGOLE et environs pour être ensuite revendu sur le marché locale de TINGOLE. Les condiments seront vendus au comptant et en détail à une clientèle composée de femmes. 
Les femmes du groupe Kelenya comptent obtenir chacune,  avec ce prêt un bénéfice par cycle de 15.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé dans leur activité pour augmenter le chiffre d’affaire.
texts.en:
The Kelenya group is composed of 8 married women who have an average age of 28 and on average, 3 children. They mostly live in traditional extended families in the village of Tingole, Sous-prefecture of Fana, Prefecture of Dioila, Koulikoro region, Republic of Mali.

Due to their being neighbors, these women met; they all sell condiments. With the intention of expanding their businesses, they joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their 7th loan of which four were agricultural loans. The preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

With this loan, these women intend to buy 150 kg of cabbages, 200 kg of eggplant, 200 kg of cooking salt, and a large quantity of various condiments. Some of the products will be bought at the market in Fana, and the rest from the market gardeners of Tingole and its environs; they will be sold at the local market of Tingole. The condiments will be sold for cash, retail, to a clientele composed of women.

Each of the women of the Kelenya group expects to make a profit during this loan cycle of 15,000 F CFA which will be used in their businesses to raise their earnings.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments

loans.name: Tarek

texts.en:
Tarek is a 44-year-old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Tarek has owned a paper factory for thirty years. He produces paper. Tarek requested a loan of 1500 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his factory. This is the first time that Tarek has requested a loan.

Tarek is speciA. because he has competitive prices and he produces good quality paper. His clients are companies. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Tarek decided on doing his business because he wanted to have an independent job. In the future, he plans on improving his factory.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for his factory

loans.name: Rami

texts.en:
Rami is a 43-year-old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon, with his wife. Rami owns a bakery. He makes “saj”and “mankoucheh”. The “saj” is the metal oven where you make the saj bread. It's a traditional Lebanese cooking dome used to make Markouk (“thinned”) bread and doughy confections or Mankoucheh. A mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza, most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it anytime of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning.

Rami requested a loan of 2000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw materials such as oil, flour, thyme, cheese, and to have some liquidity. This is his second loan cycle and he has always paid on time.

His previous loan helped him improve his bakery. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Rami first started his business, he had to face competition. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to improve his financial situation. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials and have some liquidity

loans.name: Lekman

texts.en:
Lekman is a 53-year-old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Lekman has been selling clothes out of his house for seven years. He also works at sewing. Lekman requested a loan of 500 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase cloth and thread for his work. Lekman has been a micro-credit client for five years now and has always paid on time.

His previous loans helped him improve his work as well as his financial situation. His clients can be anybody. When he first started his business, he had health problems. Lekman decided on doing his business because of his financial need. In the future, he plans on purchasing a shop.

loans.use: to purchase cloth and thread for his work

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Constitué de huit femmes, les membres du groupe Sabougnouma sont mariés avec une moyenne d’âge de 24 ans et de 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles  dans le village de TINGOLE, sous préfecture de FANA, dans la préfecture de DIOÏLA région de KOULIKORO république du Mali.  
Par des liens de parenté et de mariage, ces femmes se sont connues et font comme activité génératrice de revenus la restauration dans des gargotes à TINGOLE.
Dans l’intention de rehausser le niveau de leur activité elles ont adhéré au programme crédit de  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur sixième prêt de groupe dont quatre prêts agricoles. Les précédents prêts ont été correctement remboursés.
 Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt 500 kg de riz, 300 kg de maïs, 200 kg d’arachide et une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires. Les plats cuisinés (couscous, riz avec sauces, arachide grillé etc.) sont vendus dans leurs gargotes à TINGOLE à une clientèle est composée de manœuvres, d’apprentis chauffeurs et bien d’autres personnes.
Ces femmes comptent obtenir chacune  un bénéfice par cycle de 40 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé dans leurs activités de restauration.
texts.en:
Composed of eight women, the members of the group Sabougnouma are married and average 24 years of age and 2 children. The live in traditional conjugal families in the village of TINGOLE in FANA sub-prefecture (DIOÏLA prefecture, KOULIKORO region) in the Republic of Mali. Through ties of kinship and marriage, these women came to know one another. They earn revenues from catering food in eateries in TINGOLE.

With the intention of boosting their level of business, the group members joined the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are now on their sixth group loan. Four of these loans included agricultural loans. The preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

With this loan, the group members plan to buy 500 kg of rice, 300 kg of corn, 200 kg of peanuts, and a large quantity of condiments. The prepared dishes (couscous, rice with sauces, roasted peanuts, etc.) are sold in their eateries in TINGOLE to customers composed of laborers, driver apprentices, and many other people.

These women each intend to earn a profit of 40,000 francs CFA per cycle. The profits will be used in their restaurant businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Restaurants

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en:
Hasan is a 30-year-old, divorced man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon, with his two children. Hasan has owned a bakery for two years. He sells all types of bread. Hasan requested a loan of 1100 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop. This is the first time that Hasan has requested a loan.

Hasan is speciA. in his work because he knows how to treat his customers. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he had difficulty managing his time because he still felt like an employee. Hasan decided on doing his business because he had always wanted to open a bakery. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: Hasan will use the loan to purchase merchandise for his shop.

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en:
Hasan is a 29-year-old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon. Hasan has been selling fruits and vegetables for a year. He requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his work. This is the first time that Hasan has requested a loan.

His customers are his friends, neighbors, and people from his region. Hasan decided on doing his business because he wanted to have an independent job. In the future, he plans on expanding and improving his business.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for his work

loans.name: Hala

texts.en:
Hala is a 46-year-old woman who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon, with her husband. Hala has been doing embroidery for six years. Hala requested a loan of 500 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her work. This is her second loan cycle and she has always paid on time.

Hala is speciA. in her work because she does it well. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. In the future, Hala plans on improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for her work

loans.name: Sindiya Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe Sindiya de l’association Benkadi sont en majorités des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et de 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies dans le village de TINGOLE, sous préfecture de FANA, dans la préfecture de DIOÏLA région de KOULIKORO république du Mali.  
Pour des raisons commerciales (le commerce des fruits et légumes), elles se sont découvertes les unes les autres. Avec l’idée d’augmenter leurs ressources financières afin de pouvoir acheter plus de produits, elles ont adhéré à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Ces femmes sont à leur sixième prêt de groupe dont quatre prêts agricoles. Tous les précédents prêts ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt ces femmes comptent acheter 300 kg de bananes, 150 kg d’aubergines, 400 kg de choux et 200 kg d’oranges.  
Ces produits seront achetés dans les jardins potagers de TINGOLE et ses villages environnants pour être revendus à FANA en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Ces femmes espèrent obtenir chacune  par mois, un bénéfice de 6.500 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour entretenir les enfants.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Sindiya group of the Benkadi association are mostly married women, who average 30 years of age and 4 children. They live in extended traditional conjugal families in the TINGOLE village, in the FANA subprefecture, prefecture of DIOÏLA (KOULIKORO region, Republic of Mali). They got to know each other through their businesses (they sell fruits and vegetables). In view of increasing their financial resources to be able to purchase more products, they joined Kiva's partner, the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso. They are seeking their sixth group loan. Out of the previous loans, four were for agriculture, and all previous loans were repaid without problems.

With this loan, these women intend to buy 300 kg of bananas, 150 kg of eggplants, 400 kg of cabbages, and 200 kg of oranges. These products will be purchased from vegetable gardens in TINGOLE and in the surrounding villages, to be retailed for cash in FANA, to a clientele comprising both men and women. These women hope to turn a monthly profit of XOF 6'500 (ca US$ 14) each, to be used to provide for their children.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 300 kg of bananas, 150 kg of eggplants, 400 kg of cabbages, and 200 kg of oranges

loans.name: Clair

texts.en:
Clair is a 43-year-old woman who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon. Clair owns a lottery shop. She requested a loan of 2000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to expand her business by purchasing merchandise because she wants to open a grocery store.

This is the first time that Clair has requested a loan. Clair is special in her work because she is the only one in her region. Her clients are her friends, neighbors, and people from her region. Clair decided on doing her work because she took after her father, who did this work. In the future, she plans on expanding her business.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Fares

texts.en:
Fares is a 47-year-old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Fares has owned a garage for 25 years. He repairs cars. He requested a loan of 2500 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his garage. This is his fourth loan cycle and he has always paid on time.

His previous loans helped him improve his garage. His clients are his friends and neighbors. Fares decided on doing his business because of his experience in that line of work. In the future, he plans on expanding his work.

loans.use: to purchase tools for his garage

loans.name: Carol

texts.en:
Carol is a 36-year-old, divorced woman who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon, with her child. Carol has owned a grocery store since 2005. She also sells vegetables. Carol requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her store. This is the first time that Carol has requested a loan.

Carol is special in her work because she knows how to treat her customers. Her customers are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she didn’t have the start-up capital. Carol decided on doing her business after she got divorced in order to improve her financial situation. In the future, she plans on expanding her business.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Sindjiya Group

texts.fr:
Composé de cinq femmes, les membres du groupe Sindjiya de l’association Dabawara sont tous mariées et ont une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans et de 5 enfants. Elles vivent en majorité dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles  dans le village de TINGOLE, sous préfecture de FANA, dans la préfecture de DIOÏLA région de KOULIKORO république du Mali. 
A travers des relations voisinage et de commerce, elles se sont connues et font le commerce de céréales. 
Dans l’objectif de renforcer leurs activités elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles  sont à leur septième prêt de groupe dont quatre prêts agricoles. Les précèdent prêts ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter 1,5 tonnes de maïs, 900 kg de sorgho et 400 kg de haricot. Les produits seront achetés auprès des producteurs de TINGOLE et ces villages environnants pour être revendus en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles  envisagent d’obtenir  chacune avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de  8 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé dans d’autres activités génératrices de revenues.
texts.en:
The Sindjiya group is composed of five married women, who average 34 years of age and 5 children. Most of them live in traditional conjugal families in TINGOLE, a village in the FANA subprefecture (DIOÏLA prefecture, region of KOULIKORO, Republic of Mali). They sell cereals, and got acquainted through bonds of neighborhood and business. In view of bolstering their businesses, they decided to join Kiva's partner, the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, from which they are seeking their seventh solidarity loan. The previous loans included four agricultural loans, and were all repaid without problems.

With this loan, they intend to buy 1.5 ton of corn, 900 kg of sorghum, and 400 kg of beans. The products will be bought from producers in TINGOLE and in the surrounding villages, to be retailed for cash, to a clientele comprising both men and women. They foresee turning a monthly profit of XOF 8'000 (ca US$ 16) each, to be invested in other money-making businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 1.5 ton of corn, 900 kg of sorghum, and 400 kg of beans

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a thirty-nine-year-old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon with his wife and their four children. Ali has owned a home product shop for four years. He has requested a loan of $2000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan. Ali is special in his work because he has a big variety of products. His clients are his friends, neighbors and people from his region. When he first started his business, he had only a small amount. Now he is the owner of the shop. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his shop.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is twenty-nine years old and lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon. Ahmad has owned a barber shop for five years. Ahmad requested a loan of $1500 from A. Majmoua in order to purchase beauty products for his salon. This is his second loan cycle and he has always paid on time. Ahmad is exceptionA. in his work because he does it so well. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he had no difficulties. He decided to start this business because of his experience. In the future, he plans to improve his salon.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products for his salon.

loans.name: Abass

texts.en:
Abass is forty-five years old and lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Abass has owned a bakery for nine years. He does “saj”and “mankoucheh”. The “saj” is the metal oven where the saj bread is baked. A saj is a traditional Lebanese cooking dome used to make Markouk (“thinned”) bread and doughy confections or Mankoucheh. A mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza, the most common toppings being zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it anytime of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning. Abass requested a loan of $2000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw materials like oil, flour, thyme, cheese, coffee, and also a refrigerator. This is the first time that Abass has requested a loan. 
Abass is exceptional in his work because he does it well and his products are known for their good flavor. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he had few difficulties because he always wanted to open a bakery. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials and a refrigerator.

loans.name: Sinignessigui Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe Sinignessigui sont en majorités des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 23 ans et de 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies dans le village de TINGOLE, sous préfecture de FANA, dans la préfecture de DIOÏLA région de KOULIKORO république du Mali.
 Par des relations de commerce, ces femmes se sont connues et exercent  le commerce des condiments alimentaires.
Dans le souci d’améliorer leurs activités elles ont adhéré à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de groupe dont quatre prêts agricoles. Les précédents prêts ont été bien remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt ces femmes comptent acheter 300 kg d’oignons, 30 boites de 2 kg de concentrée de tomates, et une grande quantité de condiments divers. Tous ces condiments sont achetés sur le marché de Bamako pour être ensuite revendus sur le marché local de TINGOLE en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.
 Elles espèrent d’obtenir chacune  avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 7 500 FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les frais de santé des enfants.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group Sinignessigui are for the most part married women who average 23 years of age and 2 children. They live in traditional extended conjugal families in the village of TINGOLE in FANA sub-prefecture (DIOÏLA prefecture, KOULIKORO region) in the Republic of Mali. These women know one another through business ties, and they do commerce in condiments.

Wanting to improve their businesses, they’ve joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their fifth group loan, four of which were agricultural. All the preceding loans were correctly repaid.

With this loan, these women intend to buy 300 kg of onions, thirty 2-kg cans of tomato paste, and a large quantity of various condiments. All these condiments are purchased at the Bamako marketplace and then resold retail at the local marketplace of TINGOLE in cash transactions to customers composed essentially of women.

The group members each hope to obtain through this loan a monthly profit of 7,500 francs CFA that will be used to cover the health care costs of the children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condimetns

loans.name: Timinandiya Group

texts.fr:
Toutes mariées, les cinq femmes qui composent le groupe Timinandiya  ont une moyenne d’âge de 29 ans et de 3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles dans le village de TINGOLE, sous préfecture de FANA, dans la préfecture de DIOÏLA région de KOULIKORO république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de mariage et de voisinage et  font essentiellement  le commerce de charbon de bois.
 Dans l’intention de faire assez de stock et de satisfaire le besoin de la clientèle elles ont adhéré à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur sixième prêt de groupe dont quatre prêts agricoles. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt ces femmes comptent acheter 5 tonnes de charbon de bois auprès des charbonniers de TINGOLE et des villages environnants pour ensuite les revendre au bord de la route principale BAMAKO-SEGOU. Le charbon de bois est conditionné dans des sacs de 100kg et vendus au comptant à une clientèle composé essentiellement de voyageurs qui passent pour Bamako (capitale du Mali). 
Ces femmes comptent obtenir avec ce prêt un bénéfice de 10 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour aider les époux.
texts.en:
All of them married, the five women who make up the group Timinandiya average 29 years of age and 3 children. The group members live in traditional conjugal families in the village of Tingole in Fana sub-prefecture (Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region) in the Republic of Mali. These women know one another through ties of marriage and community, and they essentially do commerce in charcoal.

Intending to build up enough stock to satisfy customer needs, they’ve joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their sixth group loan, four of which were agricultural. All the preceding loans were correctly repaid.

With this loan, these women intend to buy five tonnes of charcoal from charcoal suppliers in and around Tingole in order to resell it along the roadside of the main road connecting Bamako and Segou. The charcoal is packaged into 100-kg sacks and sold in cash transactions to customers composed essentially of travelers on their way to Bamako (capital of Mali).

These women plan to obtain through this loan a profit of 10,000 francs CFA that will be used to help the spouses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Afi Maimounatou

texts.fr: Cette dame est une infirmière et réside dans le quartier d’attiégou un quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé, disposant d’un cabinet médical depuis 2006,elle sollicite de WAGES un premier crédit pour acheter du matériel médical, des lits et d’autres médicaments de première urgence afin de satisfaire plus convenablement ses patients. Maimounatou afi est mariée et a 02 enfants.
texts.en:
This is a lady who is a nurse. She resides in Attiégou, an outlying district of the city of Lomé. With a medical office since 2006, she's requesting an initial loan from WAGES to buy medical equipment, beds, and more first aid medicines in order to satisfy her patients more appropriately. Maimounatou Afi is married and has two children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy medical equipment and essential medecines

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia es socia del Bancomunal las Palmeras.
Julia tiene 76 años es viuda, tiene nueve hijos que están casados.
Julia  es de Ancash llego a Lima de joven, empezó haciendo chompas, compraba lana y las tejía a mano, también aprendió a remallar, aprendió a  coser y hacer pantalones, su esposo era sastre. Murió hace cinco años, dejándole las maquinas.  
Ahora julia se dedica junto con su hija  a confeccionar buzos.
Julia necesita un préstamo de 1600 soles, para la compra de material para confección de buzos. 
Desde que esta en Finca, su negocio ha mejorado, las charlas que se dan le han ayudado para manejar mejor su negocio, también los prestamos que finca hace, ha sido de gran ayuda. 
El sueño de Julia es que su negocio mejore y seguir prosperando.
texts.en:
Julia is a member of Bancomunal las Palmeras. She is a 76-year-old widow and has nine married children. She is from Ancash but came to Lima as a young girl. When she began her work, she would buy the wool and weave the sweatshits by hand. She also learned how to mend weaves and sew pants. Her husband was a tailor. When he died five years ago he left her his machinery. Julia, with her daughter, now works making sweatshirts. This 1600 sol loan will be used to buy the raw materials she needs. Since she has been in Finca, her business has grown; the training sessions they give, as well as the loans they have given her, have helped her improve her businesss. Julia's dream is to see her business continue to grow and prosper.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Julia needs a 1600 soles loan to buy material to make sweatshirts.

loans.name: Biré

texts.fr: Monsieur potou Biré est un commerçant qui réside dans le quartier d’Akodessewa, il a pour activité principale la vente de pièces à détachées de moulin qu’il exerce dans une boutique qu’il a appelé « Frank Basi Agric », il a commencé ce commerce en 2007. Ce commerce lui réussit bien car très peu de gens l’exercent, beaucoup de détenteurs de moulin  viennent acheter les pièces pour réparer leur moulin chez lui. Le stock de marchandises dont il dispose actuellement ne lui permet pas de répondre à sa clientèle, il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 01 moteur Gx160, 03 dents n°1 et n°2, 02 moulin à piment et des dynamos électriques
texts.en:
Mr. Potou Biré is a merchant who resides in the Akodessewa district. His main work involves selling spare parts for mills. He operates this business in a shop he calls “Frank Basi Agric”. He started up in 2007. This commerce is doing well for him because few people work in it. Many mill owners come to buy parts from him to repair their mills. The stock of merchandise he has currently doesn’t allow him to respond to his customers. He’s requesting a loan from WAGES to buy a Gx160 motor, three No. 1 and No. 2 dents, two mills for chili pepper, and some electric generators.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy spare parts for mills

loans.name: Vilma

texts.es:
Vilma es socia del Bancomunal Las Palmeras.
Vilma es separada tiene dos hijos ya mayores que están casados.
Vilma es de Cajamarca, estudio enfermería, trabajaba en un hospital pero tuvo mala experiencia y lo dejo, se caso y su esposo no quería que trabaje por que era muy celoso.
Vilma se dedica a la venta de ropa interior, lleva a provincias y reparte en los  puestos de mercados.  
Vilma necesita un préstamo de 1400 soles, para la compra de ropa interior, brasieres fajas, medias.
Desde que esta en Finca, su capital de trabajo a aumentado, ahora ha podido poner otro negocio, ella aprendió a ser responsable y puntual con los pagos, le gusta la puntualidad de las reuniones, son muy amenas.   
El sueño de Vilma es poner una óptica y viajar a Panamá para traer lentes.
texts.en:
Vilma is a member of the “Las Palmeras” Community Bank. Vilma is separated, has two children who are now grown and married. Vilma is from Cajamarca, she studied nursing, and she used to work in a hospital but she had a bad experience and left. She married and her husband didn’t want her to work because he was very jealous. Vilma sells underwear. She goes to the surrounding areas and delivers to the stands in the markets. Vilma needs a loan of 1400 soles to buy underwear, bras, girdles, stockings. Since she has been with Finca, her working capital has increased, now she has been able to open another business. She learned to be responsible and punctual with the payments; she likes the punctuality of the meetings and they are very entertaining. Vilma dreams of opening an optical shop and traveling to Panama to bring eyeglasses.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy underwear, bras, girdles, stockings.

loans.name: Esmeralda Rosario

texts.es:
Esmeralda es socia del Bancomunal Las Palmeras.
Esmeralda es separada, tiene 46 años dos hijos de 20  y 13 años, este ultimo esta en la escuela estatal y el mayor estudia en un instituto.
Trabaja en el área de geriatría todos los días por las mañanas, y por las tardes se dedica a coser. 
Esmeralda necesita un crédito de 800 soles, para la compra de materiales para vestuarios, vestidos de fiesta y  ternos.
Desde que esta en Finca, esta experimentado ser socia de su propio negocio, esta aprendió a ser responsable y cumplida, le ha gustado las clases de microempresa, por que le aclara mas la visión de negocio, ha conocido mas mujeres negociantes y eso le da mucho animo. 
El sueño de Esmeralda es tener un taller de costura.
texts.en:
Esmeralda is a member of the “Las Palmeras” Community Bank. Esmeralda is separated, is 46 years old and has two children ages 20 and 13, the younger is in school and the older studies in an institute. She works in geriatrics every day in the morning and in the afternoon she sews. Esmeralda needs a loan for 800 soles to buy materials for outfits, party dresses and suits. Since she has been with Finca, she has experienced being a member through her own business. She has learned to be responsible and prompt, she has enjoyed the microbusiness classes because they provide her a clearer vision for her business. She has met other female businesswomen and this inspires her greatly. Esmeralda dreams of having a seamstress shop.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy material for outfits, party dresses and suits.

loans.name: Ana

texts.es:
Ana es socia del Bancomunal Las Palmeras.
Ana es conviviente tiene 55 años, cuatro hijos todos mayores que trabajan y estudian. 
Desde el año pasado Ana  enfermo de hernia  y tuvo que dejar su negocio de venta de menús y se dedico a la venta de productos por catálogos. 
Ana necesita un préstamo de 800 soles, para la compra de productos de belleza.
Desde que esta en Finca, le ha ayudado bastante, aprendió a organizar el dinero ha no gastarse todo el dinero y a juntar de las ganancias para los prestamos que saca en Finca. 
El sueño de Ana es arreglar su casa para  poner una tienda en su casa.
texts.en:
Ana is a member of the “Las Palmeras” Community Bank. Ana is married, 55 years old, has 4 grown children who all work and study. Last year Ana was ill because of a hernia and she had to abandon her business selling meals and she switched to selling products via catalog. Ana needs a loan for 800 soles to buy beauty products. Since she has been with Finca, Finca has helped her a lot. She learned to organize the money and not spend it all and along with the earning for the loans that she gets from Finca. Ana dreams of improving her home in order to open a store in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy beauty products

loans.name: Patricia

texts.es:
Patricia es socia del Bancomunal Las Palmeras.
Patricia es conviviente tiene 43 años tres hijos de 20, 19, y 1 año, sus hijos estudian en el instituto y también trabajan. 
Patricia trabajó desde mucho tiempo lavando ropa y cocinando en casas, hasta que decidió ponerse a vender  ropa usada y ropa nueva en pista nueva.
Patricia necesita un préstamo de 600 soles, para la compra de ropa usada y ropa nueva.
Desde que esta en Finca, Patricia aprendió a invertir su dinero y ahorra, su economía ha mejorado.
El sueño de Patricia es tener un local para su negocio de ropa.
texts.en:
Patricia is a member of the "Las Palmeras" community bank. Patricia is in a common-law marriage; she is 43 years old and has three children aged 20, 19 and one. Her older children study as well as work. Patricia had been working for a long time washing clothing and cooking in private homes, until she decided to begin selling second-hand and new clothing.
